VS650.title: Comparative Abdominal Surgery
VS650.description: New techniques in surgery of abdominal viscera.

VS651.title: Comparative Abdominal Surgery Laboratory
VS651.description: Reparative and reconstructive abdominal surgical procedures.

VS655.title: Echocardiography in Veterinary Medicine
VS655.description: Technical proficiency in obtaining echocardiographic images; fundamental understanding of diagnostic criteria for common cardiac disease in dogs and cats.

VS660.title: Neurology and Neurosurgery
VS660.description: Diagnostic and surgical techniques for the nervous system.

VS661.title: Neurology and Neurosurgery Laboratory
VS661.description: Laboratory practice of comparative neurology (large and small animal), neurosurgical techniques and procedures.

VS665A.title: Advanced Topics in Veterinary Cardiology: Cardiopulmonary Pathophysiology
VS665A.description: The pathobiology, advanced diagnostics, and treatment strategies for animals and humans with spontaneous cardiovascular disease.

VS665B.title: Advanced Topics in Veterinary Cardiology: Heart Failure and Cardiac Biomarkers
VS665B.description: Review of the pathophysiology of heart failure. Discuss the diagnostic and therapeutic approach to heart failure. Clinical trial design will be reviewed prior to summarizing recent clinical trial results in humans and dogs.

VS665C.title: Advanced Topics in Veterinary Cardiology: Invasive Catheterization & Hemodynamics
VS665C.description: Technical aspects of cardiac catheterization, focusing on pathophysiologic data that can be obtained during invasive catheterization procedures and interventional treatment options available.

VS665D.title: Advanced Topics in Veterinary Cardiology: Cardiac Electrophysiology & Arrhythmias
VS665D.description: Advanced review of cardiac electrophysiology including ion channels, action potentials, cardiac conduction, automaticity, and cellular mechanisms of arrthythmogenesis. Interpretation of electrocardiogram and cardiac arrhythmia diagnosis in animals and humans. Basic principles of treatment of cardiac interventions including electrophysiology studies and interventions.

VS665E.title: Advanced Topics in Veterinary Cardiology: Cardiovascular Imaging
VS665E.description: Highlight the pathobiology, advanced diagnostics, and treatment strategies for animals with spontaneous cardiovascular disease.

VS665F.title: Advanced Topics in Veterinary Cardiology: Congenital Heart Disease
VS665F.description: Overview and in-depth analysis of congenital malformations of the heart and great vessels in veterinary species, with comparison to the same diseases in humans. Complex lesions are emphasized, with a focus on pathophysiology, diagnostic findings, and therapeutic interventions.

VS673.title: Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery
VS673.description: Surgical approaches to the thorax and the central and peripheral cardiovascular system.

VS674.title: Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery Lab
VS674.description: Surgical procedures applied to the chest, heart, and vessels.

VS701.title: Postgraduate Medicine I
VS701.description: Comprehensive review, update of immunology, emergency medicine, dermatology, and endocrinology.

VS702.title: Postgraduate Medicine II
VS702.description: Comprehensive review, update of neurology, gastroenterology, and ophthalmology.

VS703.title: Postgraduate Medicine III
VS703.description: Comprehensive review, update of oncology, cardiology, reproduction, opthamology, and radiology.

VS704.title: Postgraduate Medicine IV
VS704.description: Comprehensive review, update of hematology, nephrology, urology, respiratory, hepatic, and pancreatic.

VS716.title: Advanced Studies in Reproduction
VS716.description: Biochemical and physiological basis for problems in reproduction.

VS718.title: Cancer Biology Clinical Practicum
VS718.description: Exposes graduate students engaged in laboratory cancer research to cancer from a clinical perspective, through VTH clinical rotations.

VS733.title: Advanced Veterinary Epidemiology
VS733.description: Advanced epidemiological and statistical techniques for the design and analysis of research projects.

VS750.title: Clinical and Applied Pharmacology
VS750.description: Factors involved in drug dosing and variability of drug response. Applications in veterinary and human medicine.

VS760.title: Methods in Orthopaedic Research
VS760.description: Methods utilized in othopaedic research will be presented by reviewing basic principles followed by examples of use in research projects.

SPCM100.title: Communication and Popular Culture (GT-AH1)
SPCM100.description: Survey of media studies approaches to understanding popular culture.

SPCM130.title: Relational and Organizational Communication (GT-SS3)
SPCM130.description: Basic communication processes and skills central to relating and organizing in interpersonal, small group, and organizational contexts.

SPCM200.title: Public Speaking
SPCM200.description: Fundamentals of public speaking emphasizing content, organization, delivery, audience response.

SPCM201.title: History and Theory of Rhetoric (GT-AH3)
SPCM201.description: Major concepts of rhetoric from ancient to modern times and their relationship to present-day approaches to communication.

SPCM207.title: Public Argumentation
SPCM207.description: Key communication principles for democracy, including issue analysis, evidence, reasoning, decision-making, debate, dialogue, and deliberation.

SPCM232.title: Group Communication
SPCM232.description: Principles and methods of group communication emphasizing face-to-face and electronically mediated problem solving and decision making.

SPCM278A.title: Communication Skills: Convention/Meeting Planning
SPCM278A.description: Applied communication skills in specific contexts.

SPCM278B.title: Communication Skills: Interviewing
SPCM278B.description: Applied communication skills in specific contexts.

SPCM278C.title: Communication Skills: Film Festivals
SPCM278C.description: Applied communication skills in specific contexts.

SPCM278D.title: Communication Skills: Friendship
SPCM278D.description: Applied communication skills in specific contexts.

SPCM278E.title: Communication Skills: Intercultural Competence
SPCM278E.description: Applied communication skills in specific contexts.

SPCM278G.title: Communication Skills: Parliamentary Procedure
SPCM278G.description: Applied communication skills in specific contexts.

SPCM278H.title: Communication Skills: Organizational Training
SPCM278H.description: Applied communication skills in specific contexts.

SPCM278I.title: Communication Skills: Social Media
SPCM278I.description: Applied communication skills in specific contexts.

SPCM300.title: Advanced Public Speaking
SPCM300.description: Advanced technique in public speaking; emphasis on argument construction and refutation, style, and manuscript delivery.

SPCM311.title: Historical Speeches on American Issues
SPCM311.description: Significant speeches and speakers as they reflected and affected American issues from colonial period through early 20th century.

SPCM320.title: Communication and Human Trafficking
SPCM320.description: Examines historical and contemporary anti human trafficking movements, assessing the communication strategies employed by anti-trafficking advocates and organizations. Assesses the role language plays in shaping societal attitudes toward victims, survivors, and perpetrators of human trafficking.

SPCM331.title: Nonverbal Communication
SPCM331.description: Non-language communication; systems and functions of nonverbal communication behaviors.

SPCM333.title: Professional Communication
SPCM333.description: Technological, interpersonal, and ethical dimensions of professional communication, emphasizing interviews, teams, and presentations at work.

SPCM334.title: Co-Cultural Communication
SPCM334.description: Cultural concerns of communication among co-cultures of United States; diversity; self-awareness as cultural imperative for enhanced communication.

SPCM335.title: Gender and Communication
SPCM335.description: Analysis and exploration of communication as it relates to gender and women's and men's roles and identities.

SPCM337.title: Persuasion
SPCM337.description: Rhetorical and behavioral theories of persuasion applied to persuasive practice in public and interpersonal arenas of social influence.

SPCM341.title: Evaluating Contemporary Television
SPCM341.description: Rhetorical standards applied to content, ethical, and artistic aspects of American televised discourse; emphasizing nonentertainment programming.

SPCM342.title: Critical Media Studies
SPCM342.description: Analysis of communication media; history; structure, regulation, policy, and impact upon society.

SPCM346.title: Digital Media Cultures
SPCM346.description: Critical-cultural analysis of the internet and computer-mediated communication.

SPCM347.title: Visual Communication
SPCM347.description: Media/visual aesthetics and literacy, the symbolic and affective dimensions of the codes, conventions, and formulas of media.

SPCM349.title: Freedom of Speech
SPCM349.description: Historical and philosophical precedents to freedom of speech; development of free speech principles in the U.S.; ethical obligations of speakers.

SPCM350.title: Evaluating Contemporary Film
SPCM350.description: Theory and development of film criticism; application of critical approaches to modern fiction and nonfiction film.

SPCM354.title: History and Appreciation of Film
SPCM354.description: Screening and evaluation of landmark fiction and nonfiction films; assessment of cinema as an art form and a social force.

SPCM356.title: Asians in the U.S. Media
SPCM356.description: Asian representations in the U.S. media from the 19th century to the present.

SPCM357.title: Film and Social Change
SPCM357.description: Ways in which the medium of motion pictures has sparked significant social changes at home and abroad.

SPCM360.title: The Personal Lens – Making Media
SPCM360.description: Harnessing smart phone technology to produce video; telling personal stories via video that engage local and global communities; exploring traditional and novel forms of storytelling, representation, documentary, media appropriation, and cultural jamming in the context of fair use; using the internet to distribute self-produced content and communicate with audiences.

SPCM370A.title: Study Abroad: Bridging Cultures-USA-Italy
SPCM370A.description: Theory, concepts, principles, research methods, and practical skills in the areas of intercultural and cross-cultural communication, construction and negotiation of Italian identity (italianità), and strategies of an effective dialogue with a global mindset. The aim of the course is to transform its participants into culturally aware and skilled global citizens, with the empirical experience of cultural bridging.

SPCM370C.title: Study Abroad--South Korea: Cinema, Culture, and History

SPCM378.title: Virtual Workplace Communication
SPCM378.description: Interpersonal/organizational dimensions and communicative processes underpinning virtual/remote/distributed workers and workplaces.

SPCM401.title: Rhetoric in Social Movements
SPCM401.description: Case studies of campaigns and social movements; genesis, leadership, and use of traditional and electronically mediated rhetoric to achieve objectives.

SPCM407.title: Public Deliberation
SPCM407.description: Communication in collaborative decision-making and community problem-solving, examined through the lens of deliberative democracy.

SPCM408.title: Applied Deliberative Techniques
SPCM408.description: Skills development and direct experience in convening, facilitating, and reporting public forums tied to Center for Public Deliberation activities.

SPCM411.title: Contemporary Speeches on American Issues
SPCM411.description: Significant speeches and speakers as they reflect and affect issues, 1930 to present.

SPCM412.title: Evaluating Contemporary Rhetoric
SPCM412.description: Exploration and evaluation of contemporary persuasive communication in order to understand and assess a variety of forms of messages and symbols.

SPCM431.title: Communication, Language, and Thought
SPCM431.description: Influence of rhetoric, ranging from spoken language to electronically mediated communication, on human understanding and Western thought.

SPCM432.title: Interpersonal Communication
SPCM432.description: Theoretical and conceptual foundations of the dynamics, dimensions, and functions of communication in interpersonal relationships.

SPCM433.title: Communication in Organizations
SPCM433.description: Communication theory and strategy for empowerment of non-supervisory and supervisory personnel.

SPCM434.title: Intercultural Communication
SPCM434.description: Cultural influences on communication between people of different nations; communication rules/norms in specific cultures, cultural adaptation.

SPCM435A.title: Study Abroad--Spain: Social Support and Communication
SPCM435A.description: Theory and research regarding personal and community experiences of social support, its influences on interpersonal relationships and health, and its social functions within the context of study abroad and intercultural experiences in Spain.

SPCM436.title: Conflict Management and Communication
SPCM436.description: Theories and principles of communication in conflict management; application to conflict resolution situations.

SPCM453.title: Global Media Cultures
SPCM453.description: How media and globalization influence each other.

SPCM455.title: Narrative Fiction Film as a Liberal Art

SPCM470A.title: Study Abroad: Cinematic Rome
SPCM470A.description: Evaluate and discuss ten primary films, along with excerpts from a number of others. Topics: Images of Ancient Rome; Italian Fascism and Its Memory; Italian Neorealism; Images of “Americans” in Rome, and Rome in America; Fellini’s Rome; and Urban Angst, Roman Style. Analyze how Rome functions as a “character” in the movies, the artistic representations of Roman monuments and streetscapes, and the rhetorical functions of Italian cinema.

SPCM479.title: Communication Studies Capstone
SPCM479.description: Synthesis of central issues in Communication Studies; examination of their relevance to students' professional, personal, and civic endeavors.

SPCM486.title: Practicum
SPCM486.description: Directed experience of communication techniques and procedures in the community with periodic faculty consultation.

SPCM508.title: Deliberative Theory and Practice
SPCM508.description: Survey of current theory and practice connected to deliberative democracy.

SPCM511.title: Topics in Public Address
SPCM511.description: Theoretical and methodological issues in public address research; analysis of public discourse of selected movements or periods in U.S. history.

SPCM538.title: Relating and Organizing for Health
SPCM538.description: Organizational, interpersonal, and intercultural dimensions of communicating in health care organizations.

SPCM540.title: Rhetoric, Race, and Identity
SPCM540.description: Critical race theory and its relevance to rhetorical studies.

SPCM570.title: Instructional Communication Theory and Practice
SPCM570.description: Communication theory and research in instructional contexts. Designed for current or prospective teachers.

SPCM601.title: History of Rhetorical Theory
SPCM601.description: Rhetorical theories and theorists from the classical period to the present.

SPCM604.title: Rhetoric of Everyday Life
SPCM604.description: Contemporary theories of rhetoric and of everyday life.

SPCM611.title: Topics in Public Address
SPCM611.description: Theoretical and methodological issues in public address research; analysis of public discourse of selected movements or periods in U.S. history.

SPCM612.title: Rhetorical Criticism
SPCM612.description: Traditional and contemporary methods for analyzing persuasive discourse.

SPCM620.title: Rhetoric and Public Affairs
SPCM620.description: Rhetoric’s role in contemporary politics and civil society.

SPCM623.title: Feminist Theories of Discourse
SPCM623.description: Exploration and evaluation of contemporary feminist theories of rhetoric and discourse.

SPCM632.title: Theories of Interpersonal Communication
SPCM632.description: Theories of communication in development, maintenance, and deterioration of friendship, couple, family, group, and business relationships.

SPCM633.title: Discourse, Work, and Organization
SPCM633.description: How organizing processes and discursive practices create, maintain, and destroy diverse forms of work in society.

SPCM634.title: Communication and Cultural Diversity
SPCM634.description: Ethnographic approach to communication issues and concerns in a global context.

SPCM638.title: Communication Research Methods
SPCM638.description: Historical and philosophical context of communication research; relationship between theory and method; dominant forms of communication research.

SPCM639.title: Communication Theory
SPCM639.description: Examination of communication philosophies and perspectives; analysis of modern theories of face-to-face communication.

SPCM646.title: Media Theory
SPCM646.description: Survey of the broad range of rhetorical/qualitative theories that inform media studies.

SPCM647.title: Media Industries
SPCM647.description: Political economy of the media both in the U.S. and globally, including how the media system operates and with what effects.

SPCM648.title: Media Texts
SPCM648.description: Practical and theoretical implications for criticism in treating media products as texts; various approaches to textual or discourse analysis.

SPCM649.title: Media Audiences
SPCM649.description: Theoretical and methodological issues concerning how audiences use and interpret media.

SPCM650.title: Contemporary Issues in Media
SPCM650.description: Ever-changing media culture and landscape and how it affects personal, professional, and public lives.

SPCM675.title: Speech Communication Pedagogy
SPCM675.description: Instructional practices and theories in speech.

SPCM686.title: Practicum
SPCM686.description: Direction of communication studies fieldwork connected to the CSU Center for Public Deliberation under professional supervision.

SPCM701.title: Seminar in Academic Writing
SPCM701.description: Best practices of academic writing for publication in communication studies.

SPCM702.title: Professional Writing and Public Scholarship
SPCM702.description: Writing in specialized professional contexts. Adapting scholarly information for extra-disciplinary and lay audiences.

SPCM712.title: Critical/Cultural Analysis in Communication
SPCM712.description: Advanced instruction in critical/cultural analysis as understood by the field of Communication Studies.

SPCM792A.title: Seminar: Rhetoric and Civic Engagement
SPCM792A.description: Advanced readings in particular themes, questions, and topics pertaining to rhetoric and/or civic engagement.

SPCM792B.title: Seminar: Relational/Organizational Communication
SPCM792B.description: Advanced readings in particular themes, questions, and topics pertaining to relational and/or organizational communication.

SPCM792C.title: Seminar: Media and Visual Culture
SPCM792C.description: Advanced readings in particular themes, questions, and topics pertaining to media and/or visual culture.

SPCM793.title: Seminar: Communications Research Methods
SPCM793.description: Advanced research method(s) in the field of Communication Studies.

SPCM798.title: Research
SPCM798.description: PhD students in Communication will work on Qualifying Exam/Portfolio.

CO130.title: Academic Writing (GT-CO1)
CO130.description: Academic writing, critical thinking, and critical reading through study of a key academic issue.

CO150.title: College Composition (GT-CO2)
CO150.description: Understanding and writing for rhetorical situations; critical reading and response; writing source-based argument for academic and public audiences.

CO300.title: Writing Arguments (GT-CO3)
CO300.description: Reading, analyzing, researching, and writing arguments.

CO301A.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Arts and Humanities (GT-CO3)
CO301A.description: Learning writing strategies for addressing general audiences in arts and humanities.

CO301B.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Sciences (GT-CO3)
CO301B.description: Learning writing strategies for addressing general audiences in sciences.

CO301C.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Social Sciences (GT-CO3)
CO301C.description: Learning writing strategies for addressing general audiences in social sciences.

CO301D.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Education (GT-CO3)
CO301D.description: Learning writing strategies for addressing general audiences in education.

CO302.title: Writing in Digital Environments (GT-CO3)
CO302.description: Writing strategies, patterns and approaches for online materials.

CO401.title: Writing and Style
CO401.description: Advanced expository and persuasive writing emphasizing modes, strategies, and styles for a variety of audiences and purposes.

CO402.title: Principles of Digital Rhetoric and Design
CO402.description: Advanced study of rhetorical contexts shaping online texts. Includes instruction in coding and digital design.

CIS120.title: Business Programming Fundamentals
CIS120.description: File and operating systems for business application development. Business program development using a high-level programming language.

CIS200.title: Business Information Systems
CIS200.description: Use of information technology (IT) to enable knowledge workers, support business processes, and grow the business.

CIS210.title: Information Technology in Business
CIS210.description: Introduction to information systems: the IS profession; hardware, software, and programming; web and database applications; data analysis tools.

CIS240.title: Application Design and Development
CIS240.description: Software engineering methods including design, implementation, and testing using structured and event-driven techniques, logic, and data structures.

CIS301.title: End User Computing
CIS301.description: End user applications in a Graphical User Interface environment including spreadsheet, word processing, and presentation graphics; Internet concepts.

CIS310.title: Data Preparation for Business Analytics
CIS310.description: Focus on the knowledge and skills used for identifying, collecting, transforming, refining, integrating, and structuring data for performing analytics.

CIS320.title: Project Management for Information Systems
CIS320.description: Project management concepts including work breakdown structure, estimating, scheduling, tools, and reports.

CIS340.title: Advanced Application Design and Development
CIS340.description: Design and construction of business applications using object-orientation and advanced data structures.

CIS350.title: Operating Systems and Networks
CIS350.description: Multiuser and network operating systems; basic networking concepts including security, transmission, performance, and topologies.

CIS355.title: Business Database Systems
CIS355.description: Physical and logical design, implementation, and administration of databases.

CIS360.title: Systems Analysis and Design
CIS360.description: Traditional and cutting-edge systems analysis and design techniques, with emphasis on object-oriented approaches.

CIS370.title: Business Analytics
CIS370.description: Concepts, processes, techniques, and tools to extract, cleanse, organize, transform, store, analyze, and visualize data to support business decision making.

CIS410.title: Web Application Development
CIS410.description: Web development techniques and strategies including Active Server Pages using VBScript, JavaScript, ColdFusion; security, web design.

CIS411.title: Enterprise Resource Planning Systems
CIS411.description: Introduction to enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems concepts, business processes impacted by ERP, systems and software integration.

CIS413.title: Advanced Networking and Security
CIS413.description: Modern communication standards, protocol systems; network security, security policies, attack and protection mechanisms, legal and ethical issues.

CIS455.title: Advanced Database Management
CIS455.description: Advanced data management topics including performance tuning, concurrency control, security, object-oriented databases, and data warehousing.

CIS487.title: Internship
CIS487.description: Supervised and planned work experience paralleling concentration in industry.

CIS492.title: Seminar
CIS492.description: Current topics in computer-based information systems.

CIS496B.title: Group Study: Small Business Information Systems

CIS496C.title: Group Study: Communications and Distributed Systems

CIS496D.title: Group Study: Information Systems Performance Measurement

CIS496E.title: Group Study: Current Issues in Business Computing Systems

CIS505.title: Database Concepts
CIS505.description: An introduction to business database systems for non-CIS majors. Covers introductory database concepts, terminology, structures, relationships, and querying with SQL.

CIS563.title: Information Assurance and Security
CIS563.description: Examine information assurance and security from an enterprise risk management perspective. Enterprise risk management provides a framework for identifying, evaluating, prioritizing, and mitigating IT-related risks based on the organization’s objectives, strategy, risk appetite, and culture. Information assurance is the practice of managing information-related risks to ensure that (only) authorized parties have access to the “right” information at the “right” time.

CIS570.title: Business Intelligence
CIS570.description: Harnessing vast data stores to solve problems, enhance decision-making, discover new business opportunities, and to derive additional benefits.

CIS575.title: Applied Data Mining and Analytics in Business
CIS575.description: Data mining is a process of selecting, exploring and modeling large amounts of data to identify patterns and relationships among key variables.

CIS576.title: Business Data Visualization
CIS576.description: Methods to solve data visualization problems; critique and evaluate current systems; develop skills in the construction of data visualization.

CIS600A.title: Project Management: Information Technology
CIS600A.description: Strategic role in and management of information technology and software development projects.

CIS600B.title: Project Management: Impact Enterprise
CIS600B.description: Fundamentals of managing projects in impactful enterprises including coverage of common tools and techniques such as work breakdown structures, project networks, cost estimating and risk planning.

CIS605.title: Business Visual Application Development
CIS605.description: Design, construction, and testing of business application systems including leading-edge visual, E-commerce languages, and tools.

CIS606.title: Application Software Infrastructure
CIS606.description: Design, construction, and testing of business application software infrastructure including hardware, operating software, and communications network.

CIS610.title: Software Development Methodology
CIS610.description: Methods for all phases of software development focusing upon the establishment of economical software that is reliable and cross platform.

CIS611.title: Object-Oriented Systems
CIS611.description: Object-oriented and web-based software; object model describing classes; relationships to other objects, attributes, and operations.

CIS620.title: IT Communications Infrastructure
CIS620.description: Technical aspects of information communications, business considerations; wireless technology, architecture, and applications.

CIS623.title: Cybersecurity
CIS623.description: Detailed examination of modern security topics, blending coverage of many of the domains of the CISSP with those of the CEH: Access Control, Network Security, Risk Management, Software Development Security, Cryptography, Architecture, Operations, Business Continuity, Legal/Ethical issues, as well as attack, defense and counter-measure mechanisms.

CIS655.title: Business Database Systems
CIS655.description: Database analysis, design, administration; data modeling; data sublanguages, query facilities; distributed database systems.

CIS665.title: E-Business Application Technologies
CIS665.description: Developing E-business (B2B and B2C) through construction and deployment.

CIS670.title: Advanced IT Project Management
CIS670.description: Advanced tools, techniques and skills for advanced risk management, change movement, and performance/control measures in cross-functional projects.

CIS675.title: Agile Management and Product Development
CIS675.description: Business model process optimization; managing rapid product development; incorporating constituent feedback throughout the product life cycle.

CIS676.title: Information Technology Management
CIS676.description: Strategic information technology management of business, technical, system and information services.

CS110.title: Personal Computing
CS110.description: Hardware/software concepts, Internet services, OS commands, electronic presentations, spreadsheets, databases, programming concepts.

CS150.title: Culture and Coding (GT-AH3)
CS150.description: Survey of computer science, formal logic, and computational thinking. Explores the historical, gender, and cultural perspectives on the role of technology in society. Includes learning a basic programming language. Students will be expected to write small programs, and construct written arguments on ways in which technology influences our modern culture. Previous computer science experience not necessary.

CS152.title: Introduction to Programming (CS0)-Python
CS152.description: Introductory Python programming for students with no prior programming experience. Topics include variables, types, operators, expressions, conditionals, loops, functions, lists, dictionaries, strings, file input/output, and modules.

CS155.title: Introduction to Unix
CS155.description: Unix shell commands, utilities (editors, sorting, file management), shell scripting.

CS156.title: Introduction to C Programming I
CS156.description: Basic elements of language structure, data types, expressions, program control flow and modularity.

CS157.title: Introduction to C Programming II
CS157.description: More basic design types, function usage and strings. Arrays, user-defined types and structures, enumerated types, recursion, dynamic storage allocation.

CS163.title: CS1---No Prior Programming Experience
CS163.description: Computer programming for students without previous programming experience. Topics include variables, assignment, expressions, operators, booleans, conditionals, characters and strings, control loops, arrays, objects and classes, file input/output, interfaces, recursion, lists, and sorting.

CS164.title: CS1--Prior Programming Experience
CS164.description: Computer programming for students with limited programming experience. Problem decomposition for good design; expressions, operators, booleans, conditionals, characters and strings, control loops, arrays, objects and classes, file input/output, interfaces, recursion, lists, and sorting.

CS165.title: CS2--Data Structures
CS165.description: Object oriented concepts, assertions, inheritance, polymorphism, algorithms and data structures using an object oriented language.

CS192.title: First-Year Seminar-Computer Science
CS192.description: Computer science as a field of study and a major program at CSU. Addresses career exploration, research experience opportunities, post-graduation planning, and building a skill base of successful academic strategies.

CS220.title: Discrete Structures and their Applications
CS220.description: Integer representations and properties, propositions, predicates, sets, functions, program proofs, induction, counting, complexity; Python implementations of these concepts.

CS253.title: Software Development with C++
CS253.description: Developing and modifying large software. Relating programming language to its machine implementation. C++ programming for experienced programmers.

CS270.title: Computer Organization
CS270.description: Data representation, arithmetic, assembly and C language, digital logic and systems, Boolean algebra, circuits, CPU and memory models, state machines.

CS295.title: Independent Study
CS295.description: Investigation of special topics under direction of computer science faculty.

CS310H.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Mixed Reality Design

CS314.title: Software Engineering
CS314.description: Principles, concepts, and techniques associated with team-based development of large, complex software systems. Topics include teamwork, configuration management, project management, requirements engineering, and systematic testing techniques. Use software tools in the context of a Scrum-based Agile development project.

CS320.title: Algorithms--Theory and Practice
CS320.description: Analysis, design, implementation and applications of algorithms.

CS345.title: Machine Learning Foundations and Practice
CS345.description: Machine learning algorithms and tools for predictive modeling presented using case studies that inform their use in real-world applications.

CS356.title: Systems Security
CS356.description: Computer and system security, authentication, access control, malicious software, and software security.

CS370.title: Operating Systems
CS370.description: Introduction to operating systems including memory organization, I/O control, multitasking, process control, coordination, and resource management.

CS410.title: Introduction to Computer Graphics
CS410.description: Graphics hardware and software; drawing simple objects; coordinate transformations in 2D and 3D; modeling and viewing complex 2D and 3D objects.

CS414.title: Object-Oriented Design
CS414.description: Object-oriented methods for large-scale software systems. Software design for reuse using patterns. WWW applications in languages, e.g., Java.

CS415.title: Software Testing
CS415.description: Systematic approaches to software testing, theoretical foundations, and the current state of practice. Techniques and tools that improve software testing and overall development skills.

CS420.title: Introduction to Analysis of Algorithms
CS420.description: Efficiency analysis, correctness proofs, design strategies, illustrations from domains such as graph theory, scheduling and optimization, geometry.

CS422.title: Automata, Logic, and Computation
CS422.description: Foundations for modeling and analysis of computational systems. Topics include finite-state automata, regular expressions, pushdown automata, context-free languages, Turing machines and decidability, reducibility, logical theories.

CS425.title: Introduction to Bioinformatics Algorithms
CS425.description: Algorithms for analysis of large scale biological data.

CS430.title: Database Systems
CS430.description: Database analysis, design, administration, implementation, hierarchical, network relational models; data sublanguages; query facilities.

CS435.title: Introduction to Big Data
CS435.description: Fundamental issues in Big Data. Examine issues related to data organization, storage, retrieval, analysis and knowledge discovery at scale. Topics include large-scale data analysis, scalable computing frameworks, data storage systems, and semi-structured data models. Involves hands-on programming assignments and term project using real-world datasets.

CS440.title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
CS440.description: Concepts, representations, and algorithms for applications of problem solving search, logical reasoning and machine learning.

CS445.title: Introduction to Machine Learning
CS445.description: Fundamental concepts and methods of computational data analysis, including pattern classification, prediction, visualization, and recent topics in deep learning.

CS453.title: Introduction to Compiler Construction
CS453.description: Functional components of a compiler: modules, interfaces, lexical and syntax analysis, error recovery, resource allocation, code generation.

CS454.title: Principles of Programming Languages
CS454.description: Language design concepts; functional programming; interpreter support for environments, procedures, recursion, types, objects; language paradigms.

CS455.title: Introduction to Distributed Systems
CS455.description: Distributed systems including model of distributed computations; concurrency; thread pools and scalable servers; distributed mutual exclusion; cloud computing; distributed graph algorithms; data representation formats; atomic transactions; large-scale storage systems; distributed shared memory; and overlays.

CS456.title: Modern CyberSecurity
CS456.description: Contemporary cyber-security issues; techniques, programs, tools and methods for examining contemporary cyber-attacks and cyber-defenses.

CS457.title: Computer Networks and the Internet
CS457.description: Principles of communications, local area networks, communication protocols, TCP/IP, and the Internet.

CS458.title: Blockchain Principles and Applications
CS458.description: Presents various aspects of blockchain technology including distributed ledgers and consensus, internal mechanisms, smart contracts and DApps (distributed applications). Focus on Naivecoin, Bitcoin and Ethereum as case studies. Explore various application areas for blockchains including elections, supply chain management and others. Engage hands-on in the design, implementation and evaluation of DApps.

CS464.title: Principles of Human-Computer Interaction
CS464.description: History and trends in human-computer interaction; user-centered design techniques; prototyping; experimental methods for the evaluation of technology.

CS470.title: Computer Architecture
CS470.description: Instruction set; hardwired, microprogramming; memory; arithmetic; I/O and buses; performance evaluation; pipelining, RISC.

CS475.title: Parallel Programming
CS475.description: Parallel programming techniques for shared-memory and message-passing systems; process synchronization, communication; example languages.

CS486.title: Practicum
CS486.description: Supervised work experience in approved computer science setting with periodic consultation of faculty.

CS510.title: Image Computation
CS510.description: Image generation theory and implementation, image manipulation/interpretation. Ray tracing, geometric and photometric manipulation, image matching.

CS514.title: Software Product and Process Evaluation
CS514.description: Software development process modeling and evaluation; software metrics, testing, verification, validation; experimental methods in software engineering.

CS515.title: Software Maintenance & Evolution
CS515.description: Software maintenance fundamentals, software evolution principles, software properties and paradigms, software decay and aging, software change management, software quality, software refactoring, mining software repositories, defect prediction and effort estimation, and software documentation.

CS517.title: Software Specification and Design
CS517.description: Rigorous techniques for modeling, specifying, and analyzing software requirements and designs; reusable software development.

CS518.title: Distributed Software System Development
CS518.description: Principles of developing distributed systems; middleware technologies and techniques for building complex distributed component-based systems.

CS520.title: Analysis of Algorithms
CS520.description: Asymptotic complexity, algorithm complexity, and problem complexity; the Master Method; parallel algorithms; algorithm design.

CS522.title: Foundations of Cyber-Physical Systems
CS522.description: Principles of design, specification, modeling, and analysis of cyber-physical systems and software. Topics include model-based design, formal methods for specification and verification, and control theory.

CS530.title: Fault-Tolerant Computing
CS530.description: Achieving high reliability and fault tolerance. Fault modeling, testing, reliability evaluation, redundancy, fault tolerance. (NT-O)

CS533.title: Database Management Systems
CS533.description: Theory and implementation of concurrency control, recovery, and query processing as it applies to centralized and distributed systems.

CS535.title: Big Data
CS535.description: Topics in scalable computing models, optimization algorithms, large-scale non-traditional data storage frameworks including graph, key-value, and column-family storage systems; data stream analysis; scalable prediction models and in-memory storage systems.

CS540.title: Artificial Intelligence
CS540.description: Knowledge representation and reasoning, search, planning, evolutionary computation, data mining, information retrieval, intelligent Web, agent systems.

CS545.title: Machine Learning
CS545.description: Computational methods that allow computers to learn; neural networks, decision trees, genetic algorithms, bagging and boosting.

CS553.title: Algorithmic Language Compilers
CS553.description: Compiler construction; lexical scanner generators, parser generators, dataflow analysis, optimization.

CS555.title: Distributed Systems
CS555.description: Principles, paradigms, protocols and algorithms underlying modern distributed systems.

CS556.title: Computer Security
CS556.description: Topics in computer security: concepts, threats, risks, access control models, trusted systems, cryptography, authentication.

CS557.title: Advanced Networking
CS557.description: Core internet protocols, including transport, routing, and security protocols.  Protocol design principles. Network measurements and assessment.

CS559.title: Quantitative Security
CS559.description: Quantitative assessment of security risks in computing systems. Approaches involve data-based analysis of vulnerabilities, their exploitation, the impact of security breaches and the economy of risk-control measures.

CS567.title: 3D User Interfaces
CS567.description: Introduction to the theory of interaction design for 3D user interfaces (3DUI). Interaction (selection, manipulation, travel, and wayfinding), virtual environments, and application to 3DUI. Relevance of 3DUI principles to traditional displays, virtual reality, augmented reality, and mixed reality.

CS570.title: Advanced Computer Architecture
CS570.description: Pipelined CPU design. Superscalar architectures and instruction-level parallelism. Cache and memory hierarchy design. Storage systems.

CS575.title: Parallel Processing
CS575.description: Parallel and distributed computing models, algorithms, mapping and performance evaluations, parallel computing tools and applications.

CS614A.title: Advanced Topics in Software Engineering: Specification and Design

CS614B.title: Advanced Topics in Software Engineering: Testing and Verification

CS614C.title: Advanced Topics in Software Engineering: Software Environments and Tools

CS614D.title: Advanced Topics in Software Engineering: Software Measurement, Analysis, & Evaluation

CS614E.title: Advanced Topics in Software Engineering: Application Domains

CS620.title: Advanced Topics in Algorithms
CS620.description: Designing and analyzing algorithms and data structures; illustrations from a variety of problem domains.

CS635.title: Advanced Fault-Tolerant Computing
CS635.description: Advanced topics and recent developments in high reliability and fault-tolerant systems.

CS640.title: Advanced Artificial Intelligence I
CS640.description: Research topics in artificial intelligence:  genetic algorithms, neural networks, connectionist models; machine learning; planning, automated reasoning.

CS641.title: Advanced Artificial Intelligence II
CS641.description: Advanced research topics in artificial intelligence.

CS645.title: Advanced Machine Learning: Neural Networks
CS645.description: Study of machine learning research literature and implementations of algorithms for neural networks and reinforcement learning.

CS646.title: Machine Learning in Bioinformatics
CS646.description: Recent research on the applications of machine learning in bioinformatics.

CS655.title: Advanced Topics in Distributed Systems
CS655.description: Issues related to robustness, replication, consistency, scalability, isolation and privacy in large-scale distributed systems.

CS656A.title: Advanced Topics in Computer Security: Formal Models of Computer Security
CS656A.description: Advanced research topics in computer security.

CS656B.title: Advanced Topics in Computer Security: Models for Privacy and Application Security
CS656B.description: Advanced research topics in computer security.

CS656C.title: Advanced Topics in Computer Security: Network Security
CS656C.description: Advanced research topics in computer security.

CS657.title: Advanced Topics in Computer Networking
CS657.description: Advanced research topics in computer networks.

CS670B.title: Topics in Architecture/Systems: Performance Evaluation and Modeling

CS670D.title: Topics in Architecture/Systems: Architecture of Advanced Systems

CS675.title: Advanced Parallel Computing
CS675.description: Parallel computing, computational models, parallel languages and algorithms, distributed simulation, Internet and mobile computing, parallel search.

CS787.title: Internship
CS787.description: Summer internship experience in computer science.

CS793.title: Research Seminar in Computer Science
CS793.description: Research methods in specific areas of computer science.

CT310.title: Web Development
CT310.description: Web development languages used to create fully functional dynamic web sites; server and client scripting, database access and security issues.

CT320.title: Network and System Administration
CT320.description: Installation of network and operating system services, management and support; upgrades, security, backups.

CON101.title: Introduction to Construction Management
CON101.description: Introduction to the construction industry; including methods, practices, trends, careers, and constituencies involved in the design and construction process.

CON131.title: Graphic Communications for Construction
CON131.description: Reading technical drawings, 2D/3D visualization, manual drafting techniques, introduction to design software applications.

CON151.title: Construction Materials and Methods
CON151.description: Materials and methods utilized in the construction of the built environment.

CON192.title: Construction Management Seminar
CON192.description: Introduction to the construction management major, career paths, industry sectors, campus resources, and tools for academic success. Information and skills necessary to succeed in the construction management major.

CON251.title: Materials Testing and Processing
CON251.description: Testing of construction materials for standards and quality. Conduct material tests, document and interpret results.

CON253.title: Surveying and Construction Layout
CON253.description: Surveying fundamentals related to construction: project layout, measurement procedures, vertical controls, line and grade, and surveying instrument operation.

CON261.title: Construction Surveying
CON261.description: Surveying fundamentals related to construction: building layout, measurement procedures, vertical controls, line and grade, and surveying instrument operation.

CON265.title: Plan Reading and Quantity Survey
CON265.description: Practice in construction document reading, interpretation and analysis for quantity surveying and material quantity organizing using industry-recognized methods including, but not limited to, a project manual-based work breakdown structure.

CON267.title: Construction Management Pre-Internship
CON267.description: Skills and concepts related to successful internships within the construction management industry.

CON270.title: Introduction to Road Construction
CON270.description: Steps necessary to construct a paved roadway from conception, land acquisition and finance through paving operations and trafficking.

CON317.title: Safety Management
CON317.description: Construction safety management, accident prevention, and hazard control. Federal, state, and local regulation compliance.

CON350A.title: Study Abroad--Construction Management: European Perspectives
CON350A.description: A study of the physical resources and the human behaviors, which inform design and construction. Exploration of infrastructure and its relationship to resources, materials, and the culture in which it exists. Review of international perspectives of the built environment of Europe, past and present trends, and what the future holds. Survey of construction over time and trends in the preservation of existing infrastructure.

CON351.title: Construction Field Management
CON351.description: Applications of materials and methods in construction; administrative and organizational planning for construction field practice.

CON352.title: Metal Fabrication for Construction
CON352.description: Shaping, cutting, and joining of structural and non-structural metal. Emphasis on jobsite safety, economics, and efficiency.

CON353.title: Field Management for Construction
CON353.description: Applications of materials and methods in construction; administrative and organizational planning for construction field practice.

CON358.title: Structural Systems for Construction I
CON358.description: Behavior of structural components and systems, overview of structural engineering analysis and the design process for construction.

CON359.title: Structures I
CON359.description: Behavior of structural components and systems, overview of structural engineering analysis and the design process.

CON360.title: Electrical Systems in Construction
CON360.description: Electrical terminology, theory, components, systems, and applications within the construction industry.

CON365.title: Construction Estimating
CON365.description: Industry-recognized methods for work item analysis, quantity surveying, resource estimating, and bid development using a work breakdown structure.

CON366.title: Construction Equipment and Methods
CON366.description: Equipment and methods used in heavy-highway, heavy-civil and utility construction. Equipment and crew productivity. Equipment ownership and operating costs. Estimating, planning and directing heavy construction operations.

CON367.title: Construction Contracts/Project Administration
CON367.description: Construction contracts and clauses, stakeholder responsibilities, disputes, resolution methods and risk. Utilization of construction administration documents, systems and procedures to meet project requirements.

CON370.title: Asphalt Pavement Materials and Construction
CON370.description: Constituents of asphalt pavements; manufacture of asphalt cement, emulsions, and cutbacks; material properties and behavior.

CON371.title: Mechanical and Plumbing Systems
CON371.description: Heating, ventilation, air conditioning, plumbing, and fire suppression in the built environment.

CON382A.title: Study Abroad: European Perspectives
CON382A.description: A study of the physical resources and the human behaviors, which inform design and construction. Exploration of infrastructure and its relationship to resources, materials, and the culture in which it exists. Review of international perspectives of the built environment of Europe, past and present trends, and what the future holds. Survey of construction over time and trends in the preservation of existing infrastructure.

CON458.title: Structural Systems for Construction II
CON458.description: Review and analysis of shop drawings and details for structural systems. Overview of cast-in-place and prestressed concrete systems. Design of structural wood systems, connections, and formwork for cast-in-place concrete.

CON459.title: Structures II
CON459.description: Design of formwork, falsework, and shoring.

CON461.title: Construction Scheduling
CON461.description: Strategies and techniques for efficient project control, scheduling of project activities and projects with an emphasis on Critical Path Methodology.

CON462.title: Financial Management for Construction
CON462.description: Financial statements, financial ratios, time value of money, cash flow analysis and financial reporting for construction companies.

CON464.title: Construction Leadership
CON464.description: Leading projects and people in a construction business and application of skills in a construction-based community service learning project.

CON465.title: Construction Management Professional Practice
CON465.description: Professional practice using an understanding of the contractual and working relationships among all participants in the design/construction process.

CON469.title: Soil Mechanics for Construction
CON469.description: Analysis of the physical characteristics and properties of soil for construction project decision making. Interpretation of soils reports, conducting of testing procedures and evaluation of soils for use as a construction material. Assessment of the impact of soil characteristics on construction activities and project risk.

CON471.title: Project Management for Mechanical Systems
CON471.description: Fundamental principles of mechanical systems. Presentation and practice of management principles relevant to mechanical projects.

CON476.title: Sustainable Practice-Design and Construction
CON476.description: Major components of sustainable design/construction:  energy, healthy buildings, cultural, natural resources, use, other environment/economic issues.

CON477.title: Residential Aging-in-Place and Green Building
CON477.description: Aging-in-place and green building aspects of the residential construction market.

CON492A.title: Seminar: Emerging Construction Technologies
CON492A.description: Emerging technologies in construction management practice. Applications of current and cutting-edge software, hardware, processes, tools and equipment in the industry.

CON492B.title: Seminar: Construction Issues and Trends
CON492B.description: Issues and trends impacting construction project management and field operations. The impact of current trends on project management practice, risk mitigation and project controls.

CON492C.title: Seminar: Heavy Civil Project Management
CON492C.description: Applications of project management practice for heavy civil construction projects. Exploration of heavy civil construction project management principles and concepts through industry-specific case studies, processes and tutorials.

CON492D.title: Seminar: Commercial Project Management
CON492D.description: Applications of project management practice for commercial construction projects. Exploration of commercial construction project management principles and concepts through industry-specific case studies, processes and tutorials.

CON492E.title: Seminar: Residential Project Management
CON492E.description: Applications of project management practice for residential construction projects. Exploration of residential construction project management principles and concepts through industry-specific case studies, processes and tutorials.

CON502.title: Research in Construction Management I
CON502.description: Research, discuss, and present current issues and trends in the construction industry related to business, management, engineering, and technology.

CON503.title: Research in Construction Management II
CON503.description: Models and methods of disciplined inquiry used in diverse application-based organizations. Preparation to use disciplined inquiry methods to solve applied problems in construction management or related fields. Topics include problem/topic selection, writing research questions and objectives, literature reviews, selection of research methods, data collection and analysis, and conclusions and implications.

CON511.title: Project Procurement and Preconstruction
CON511.description: Advanced project procurement procedures with a focus on early design phase planning applications and preconstruction management techniques.

CON512.title: Post-Award Construction Management
CON512.description: Advanced topics related to post-award construction management issues with a focus on multiple project controls and project risk management.

CON521.title: Sustainable Building & Infrastructure Systems
CON521.description: Issues and state-of-the-art resources needed to construct, remodel/retrofit, operate and maintain the built environment (buildings and infrastructure). Specifically, resources will include major materials, components and technologies, as well as energy and water resources are needed in the different life-cycle phases of the building or infrastructure project.

CON561.title: Applied Productivity Improvement
CON561.description: Existing and emerging tools for productivity enhancement in project and production environment.

CON565.title: Legal Aspects of Construction Process
CON565.description: Common points of dispute; methods of avoiding disputes among owner, architect, engineer, and contractor.

CON568.title: Construction Industry Institute Practices
CON568.description: Senior executives from the Construction Industry Institute (CII) present best practices developed by CII over the last 25 years.

CON569.title: Regulatory Impact on Construction
CON569.description: Role government plays in the design and construction of the built environment.

CON571.title: Facility Planning and Management
CON571.description: Planning, organizing and managing large educational and/or commercial facilities.

D110.title: Understanding Dance (GT-AH1)
D110.description: Broad examination of dance as an art form and expression of cultural beliefs and values within a vast historic landscape.

D126.title: Dance Improvisation
D126.description: Organic movement and inventive dance movement through improvisational skills, body physicality, space/direction/level imagery and partnering.

D160.title: Musical Tap Forms
D160.description: Basic tap dance forms with emphasis on terminology, study of rhythm, and tap styles; historical development of tap in American culture.

D186.title: Production Practicum
D186.description: Experiential production learning including management of properties, light, soundboard, video/projection, curtain/rail, and wardrobe operations.

D192.title: Dance First Year Seminar
D192.description: Foundational knowledge and practical tools for navigating life as a dance practitioner in college and beyond.

D220A.title: Dance Techniques III: Modern
D220A.description: Exploring fundamentals of intermediate level modern dance technique with attention to movement initiation, breath, articulation, and expression.

D220B.title: Dance Techniques III: Ballet
D220B.description: Ballet technique at the intermediate level with a focus on building strength, enhancing bodily and spatial awareness, refining mechanics, and working as an ensemble.

D220D.title: Dance Techniques III: Pointe
D220D.description: Investigation of intermediate pointe technique required to perform classical, contemporary, and partnered ballet repertoire.

D221A.title: Dance Techniques IV: Modern
D221A.description: Exploring nuances of high intermediate level modern dance technique with attention to movement initiation, breath, articulation, and expression.

D221B.title: Dance Techniques IV: Ballet
D221B.description: Ballet technique at the high intermediate level with a focus on building strength, enhancing bodily and spatial awareness, refining mechanics, and working as an ensemble.

D224.title: Music for Dance
D224.description: An exploration of World and Western Classical Music as it relates to dance performance, choreography, and pedagogy. Emphasis is placed on aural analysis of soundscapes, proper use of terminology, and practical application. No prior knowledge of music is necessary. Introduction to fundamental elements of music, including rhythm, tonality, and compositional structure.

D226.title: Dance Choreography I
D226.description: Elements of dance composition including space, levels, rhythm, dynamics, qualities of movement, form, and style.

D286.title: Performance Practicum
D286.description: Learning, rehearsal, and performance of dance repertoire staged or choreographed by faculty and/or guest artists.

D292.title: Seminar - The Dancing Body
D292.description: Through a combination of theory and practice, explore inside the dancing body to discover structures and functions of the bones, joints, muscles, and more. Specifically geared towards dance practitioners; basic principles of anatomy, kinesiology, and somatics.

D320B.title: Dance Techniques V: Ballet
D320B.description: Investigating intermediate/advanced level technique required to perform classical and contemporary ballet repertoire.

D321B.title: Dance Techniques VI: Ballet
D321B.description: Investigation of pre-professional/advanced level technique required to perform classical and contemporary ballet repertoire. Students will examine the stylistic nuance and intersection of multiple ballet methodologies.

D324.title: Teaching Creative Movement for Children
D324.description: Theoretical and practical experience in teaching creative movement.

D326.title: Dance Choreography II
D326.description: Advanced choreographic elements: group work, music influence, and nontraditional performance venues.

D330.title: Dance Repertory Ensemble
D330.description: Study and performance of original and historic dance repertoire of the classical and contemporary variety. Immersive rehearsal periods emulate experiences of dance artists working in professional settings.

D340.title: Dance Repertory Outreach
D340.description: Preparation of arts integration units, residencies, and lecture demonstrations based on original and/or historic dance repertoire investigated during the previous semester in D330, to be performed at local elementary, middle, high schools, and/or other community venues.

D392.title: Dance Seminar
D392.description: Knowledge and skills to prepare for post-graduate applications, interviews, auditions, and professional orientation for careers in dance.

D424.title: Ballet Technique Pedagogy
D424.description: Theory and practice of ballet technique teaching methods.

D427.title: History of Non-Western Dance Forms
D427.description: Examination of non-Western dance forms with attention to a diversity of artistic, religious, social, political, and cultural contexts. With intellectual and embodied approaches, consider who moves, how they move, and how movement constructs identity.

D428.title: History of Western Dance Forms
D428.description: Examination of Western dance forms with attention to artistic, religious, social, political, and cultural contexts. With intellectual and embodied approaches, consider who moves, why they move, and how movement constructs identity.

D432.title: Dance Therapy
D432.description: Use of dance forms in therapy for mentally and physically handicapped.

D434.title: Modern Technique Pedagogy
D434.description: Theory and practice of modern dance technique teaching methods.

D471.title: Dance Capstone Concert
D471.description: Culminating capstone experience for senior dance majors combining all elements of dance concert production: choreography, rehearsal, performance, publicity/marketing, audience development, management, technical production and design. Supporting paper, production portfolio, and video documentation required.

D487.title: Dance Internship
D487.description: Supervised work experience in professional dance companies, schools, performing arts centers, and related affiliations.

D527.title: Contemporary Dance
D527.description: Techniques of dance movement and choreography.

DSCI100.title: First Year Seminar in Data Science
DSCI100.description: Introduction to problems and techniques in data science.

DSCI235.title: Data Wrangling
DSCI235.description: Introduce tools and techniques for handling, cleaning, extracting, and organizing data.

DSCI320.title: Optimization Methods in Data Science
DSCI320.description: Linear and non-linear programming, convex sets and functions, convex and non-convex optimization problems, duality, Newton's methods, barrier methods, linear equality and inequality constraints. Emphasis on computation methods and programming.

DSCI335.title: Inferential Reasoning in Data Analysis
DSCI335.description: Sources of data collection errors and uncertainties, type of studies, interaction versus confounding, fair use of data, confidentiality and disclosure.

DSCI336.title: Data Graphics and Visualization
DSCI336.description: Data graphics and visualization techniques for data science.

DSCI369.title: Linear Algebra for Data Science
DSCI369.description: Techniques in linear algebra related to data science. Matrices, bases, subspaces, linear independence, dimension, change of basis, projections, linear systems of equations, least squares, matrix factorizations. Singular value decomposition, angles between subspaces.

DSCI445.title: Statistical Machine Learning
DSCI445.description: Algorithms and statistical methods for regression, classification, and clustering; hands-on experience in analyzing data and running machine learning experiments.

DSCI473.title: Introduction to Geometric Data Analysis
DSCI473.description: Geometric techniques for analyzing high-dimensional and complex data. Techniques for data reduction and analysis.

DSCI475.title: Topological Data Analysis
DSCI475.description: Topological techniques for analyzing high-dimensional or complex data. Topics include clustering, dendrograms, a visual introduction to topology, data modeling and visualization, and selected topics from nonlinear dimensionality reduction, graph-based models of data, Reeb graphs, multi-scale approaches to data, and persistent homology.

DSCI478.title: Capstone Group Project in Data Science
DSCI478.description: Group-project-based capstone, in which small groups of students from each Data Science degree concentration work collectively on a problem in data science.

DSCI510.title: Linux as a Computational Platform
DSCI510.description: Use of the Linux operating system for computational work using command-line tools; basic Linux commands, running and managing jobs, installing software.

DSCI511.title: Genomics Data Analysis in Python
DSCI511.description: Analyzing complex data sets using Python.

DSCI512.title: RNA-Sequencing Data Analysis
DSCI512.description: Hands-on experience with tools for analysis of next generation sequencing data.

DM120.title: Textiles
DM120.description: Fibers, fabrics, and finishes basic to selection, use, and care.

DM192A.title: First Year Seminar: Apparel and Merchandising
DM192A.description: Introduction to the apparel and merchandising major and its concentrations, career options, campus resources, tools for academics, and industry topics.

DM192B.title: First Year Seminar: Pre-Interior Architecture and Design
DM192B.description: Introduction to interior architecture and design major, career options, campus resources, tools for academics, and industry topics.

DM272.title: Consumers in the Marketplace
DM272.description: Analysis and evaluation of psychological, social, economic, sustainability, and cultural factors that influence consumers in the marketplace.

DM400.title: U.S. Travel-New York City
DM400.description: Interview/analyze designers, manufacturers, buying offices, retail stores, magazine firms, interior design and architecture firms, etc.

DM470A.title: International Design and Merchandising: Apparel
DM470A.description: Historical, cultural, and business aspects of international design and merchandising in selected countries.

DM470B.title: International Design and Merchandising: Interior Design
DM470B.description: Historical, cultural, and business aspects of international design and merchandising in selected countries.

DM474.title: Fashion Show Production and Event Planning
DM474.description: Planning and implementing full production fashion show of student-designed collections, including promotions and fund-raising activities.

DM482.title: Travel Abroad
DM482.description: Historical, cultural, aesthetic, and business aspects of design and merchandising in the selected country(ies).

DM482A.title: Study Abroad: Design/Merchandising–Scotland/England
DM482A.description: Historical, cultural, aesthetic, and business aspects of international design and merchandising in the selected country(ies).

DM482B.title: Study Abroad--China: Design and Merchandising
DM482B.description: Historical, cultural, aesthetic, and business aspects of international design and merchandising in China.

DM492.title: Professional Practice
DM492.description: Professional standards and corporate structure of apparel and merchandising companies in apparel design, product development, and/or merchandising.

DM501.title: Research and Theory-Design and Merchandising
DM501.description: Theory and various approaches and philosophies of research in design and merchandising. Critical evaluation and synthesis of scholarly literature.

DM510.title: Consumer Behavior
DM510.description: Evaluation of psychological, sociological, and cultural theories of consumer behavior through examination of factors that influence decision making.

DM540.title: Promotional Strategies in Merchandising
DM540.description: Integrated marketing communications while fostering cultural and global awareness, social responsibility and ethical decision-making.

DM542.title: Advanced Computer-Aided Textile Design
DM542.description: Use of computer-aided design system to produce fabric designs for apparel or interior professional end use.

DM551.title: Research Methods
DM551.description: Design and methods of research applicable to design and merchandising.

DM563.title: Care and Exhibit of Museum Collections
DM563.description: Hands-on experience in management, care, exhibition, and interpretation of museum collections.

DM570.title: Creativity in Design
DM570.description: Multiple perspectives in creativity integrating theory and research impacting design.

DM573.title: Entrepreneurship Theories in Apparel & Design
DM573.description: Theoretical and applied perspectives of entrepreneurship for US and global production, distribution, and consumption of apparel and interior design products and services.

DM575.title: Human Factors in Design
DM575.description: Theories and contemporary issues related to human factors in consumer product design.

IDEA110.title: Designing Your University Life
IDEA110.description: Application of practical design thinking tools, ideas, and decision-making strategies to construct an individualized approach to finding and designing academic and practical experiences. Topics include the purpose of college, strategies for educational way finding, and the integration of work and worldview.

IDEA210.title: Introduction to Design Thinking (GT-AH1)
IDEA210.description: Design thinking is a creative, flexible process that fosters innovation. Content and projects promote building creative competence and an appreciation for thinking across disciplines to develop a new mindset and skillset that guides innovation. Learning tools to develop compelling ideas for meaningful societal and marketplace impact will be explored.

IDEA310A.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Paper Products
IDEA310A.description: Employing design theories and methods to projects using paper-based media that promote “iterative tinkering” through exploration of various design processes.

IDEA310B.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: 3D Modeling
IDEA310B.description: Employing design theories and methods to 3D modeling projects that promote “iterative tinkering” through exploration of various design processes using computer software.

IDEA310D.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Digital Imaging
IDEA310D.description: Design theories and methods employing digital imaging projects that promote “iterative tinkering” experiences through exploration of various design processes.

IDEA310E.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Foundations of Woodworking
IDEA310E.description: Employ design thinking theories and methods to wood projects that promote “iterative tinkering” through exploration of various design processes in a maker space setting.

IDEA310F.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Foundations of Textile Design
IDEA310F.description: Employ design thinking theories and methods to textile projects that promote “iterative tinkering” through exploration of various design processes in a maker space setting.

IDEA310G.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Infographics
IDEA310G.description: Employ design theories and methods to infographic projects that promote “iterative tinkering” through exploration of various design processes.

IDEA310H.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Mixed Reality Design

IDEA310I.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Foundations of Metal Fabrication
IDEA310I.description: Employing design thinking theories and methods to projects using metal-based media that promote “iterative tinkering” through the exploration of various design processes related to metals.

IDEA310J.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Graphic Noveling
IDEA310J.description: Employing design thinking theories and methods to projects using graphic novel storytelling to promote “iterative tinkering” through an exploration of various design processes.

IDEA310K.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Technical Sketching and Illustration
IDEA310K.description: Employing design thinking theories and methods to projects using technical sketching and illustration that promotes “iterative tinkering” through exploration of various design processes.

IDEA310L.title: Design Thinking Toolbox : Creating Things That Think
IDEA310L.description: Employing design thinking theories and methods to projects using microcontrollers and single-board computers that promote “iterative tinkering” through the exploration of various design processes related to embedding computation devices into a design.

IDEA310M.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Co-designing with Communities
IDEA310M.description: Employing design thinking theories and methods to projects using best practices for participatory design with community partners as co-designers to promote “iterative tinkering” and equitable relationships.

IDEA310N.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Post-Digital Imaging/Printmaking
IDEA310N.description: Employing design thinking theories and methods to projects using post-digital imaging that promotes “iterative tinkering” through the exploration of various design processes related to screen-printing and other forms of post-digital imaging.

IDEA320B.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Advanced  3D Modeling
IDEA320B.description: Employing design thinking theories and methods to advanced 3D modeling projects that promote “iterative tinkering” experiences through exploration of design processes.

IDEA320E.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Advanced Woodworking
IDEA320E.description: Employing design thinking theories and methods to projects using wood-based media that promote “iterative tinkering” through the exploration of various design processes and advanced woodworking techniques, such as furniture design.

IDEA320F.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Advanced Textile Design
IDEA320F.description: Employing design thinking theories and methods to advanced projects using textile-based media that promote “iterative tinkering” through exploration of various design processes related to textiles.

IDEA320I.title: Design Thinking Toolbox: Advanced Metal Fabrication
IDEA320I.description: Employing design thinking theories and methods to projects using metal fabrication-based media that promote “iterative tinkering” through the exploration of various design processes related to advanced metal fabrication.

IDEA384.title: Supervised College Teaching
IDEA384.description: Skills for facilitating effective learning in design thinking courses.

IDEA450.title: Design Thinking Collaborative
IDEA450.description: Culminating interdisciplinary experience that offers an opportunity to partner with industry or community partners to propose solutions to vexing real-world problems. Content and activities include a semester-long project to create a problem brief, develop and test prototypes, and deliver professional presentations to diverse audiences.

IDEA482C.title: Study Abroad--Todos Santos: Ventures in Social Entrepreneurship

IDEA487.title: Internship
IDEA487.description: Application of design thinking knowledge and integrating it into real-world experiences. Weekly meetings with internship site supervisor foster the development of professional skills and feedback to enhance performance, conduct, ethics, and communication skills for the workplace.

IDEA496.title: Group Study
IDEA496.description: Instructor-supervised investigation of areas of special interest in interdisciplinary and collaborative topics related to design thinking.

IDEA510.title: Processes of Human-Centered Design Thinking
IDEA510.description: Introduction to theoretical concepts, philosophies, and psychosocial processes associated with design thinking in design and non-design contexts. Drawing from perspectives in design cognition, cognitive psychology and the learning sciences, human-centered interaction, and creativity. Examine how design thinking facilitates understanding of our environment; identify and manage ill-defined societal problems, and communicate with diverse stakeholders and team members.

IDEA520.title: Methods for Human-Centered Design Thinking
IDEA520.description: Introduces designing and conducting human-centered research and co-design methods common to innovation frameworks such as design thinking. Practical strategies are introduced for exploratory (problem-finding), generative, and evaluative (user testing) processes utilizing research methods that are original to design, adapted from other disciplines, and traditionally used across disciplines.

IDEA525A.title: Mixed Reality for Design Thinking: Trends
IDEA525A.description: Overview of developments in virtual, augmented, and mixed reality technologies and how they are shaping design and non-design fields and industries.

IDEA525B.title: Mixed Reality for Design Thinking: Storytelling
IDEA525B.description: Exploration and analysis of storytelling in immersive virtual, augmented, and mixed reality technology applications and how techniques aid in understanding diverse human perspectives, including socio-cultural, racial, socio-economic, neurological, and physical differences, among others.

IDEA525C.title: Mixed Reality for Design Thinking: Inclusive Design
IDEA525C.description: Mixed reality technologies and applications have unique potential for immersive learning and therapeutic experiences. Hardware and software applications do not often consider diverse users (e.g., those who have physical, neurological, sensory, mental/behavioral, or other differences) . Explore mixed reality hardware and software applications with respect to inclusive design principles and theories.

IDEA525D.title: Mixed Reality for Design Thinking: Data Visualization
IDEA525D.description: Exploration and analysis of immersive virtual, augmented, and mixed reality technology applications in understanding complex information and systems, including biological, environmental, and technological, among others.

IDEA525E.title: Mixed Reality for Design Thinking: Application Prototyping
IDEA525E.description: Introduction to topics and methods in designing virtual, augmented, and mixed reality applications.
