Learn how to create virtual (i.e., artificial) worlds using a game engine to provide hands-on experience and promote "iterative tinkering” through exploration of various design processes.

IDEA525F.title: Mixed Reality for Design Thinking: Prototyping Games
IDEA525F.description: Concepts of hand-fabricated and digital/computer game development and their application to fields such as education, health, and business. Collaborate in teams to design and prototype games for social change and civic engagement. Through readings, discussion, and presentations, explore principles of game design and the social history of games.

ECOL505.title: Foundations of Ecology
ECOL505.description: Overview of the science of ecology; what questions are asked, how they are answered.

ECOL571.title: Advanced Topics in Ecology
ECOL571.description: Current research topics presented and analyzed by visiting scientists.

ECOL592.title: Interdisciplinary Seminar in Ecology
ECOL592.description: Concepts and principles of basic and applied ecology in an interdisciplinary context.

ECOL600.title: Community Ecology
ECOL600.description: Current theories and tests of the dynamics and regulation of plant and animal communities.

ECOL610.title: Ecosystem Ecology
ECOL610.description: Concepts, methods, issues in ecosystem science: energy and matter cycling; systems perspectives, simulation modeling, sustainability, global change.

ECOL620.title: Applications in Landscape Ecology
ECOL620.description: Spatial patterning of landscape elements and dynamics of ecological systems; spatial heterogeneity. Influence on biotic and abiotic processes.

ECOL693.title: Research Seminar
ECOL693.description: Critique of research programs, plans, and ecological theory.

ECON101.title: Economics of Social Issues (GT-SS1)
ECON101.description: Economic analysis of poverty, crime, education, and/or other social issues. Basics of micro, macro, and political economy.

ECON202.title: Principles of Microeconomics (GT-SS1)
ECON202.description: Introduction to decision-making by households, firms, and government, and resulting allocation of resources through markets.

ECON204.title: Principles of Macroeconomics (GT-SS1)
ECON204.description: Determinants of national output, employment, and price level; inflation and unemployment; fiscal and monetary policy.

ECON211.title: Gender in the Economy (GT-SS1)
ECON211.description: Role gender plays in economies; the way gender affects economic outcomes for individuals and societies.

ECON212.title: Racial Inequality and Discrimination (GT-SS1)
ECON212.description: Economic inequality based on race or ethnicity in the United States. Economic debates about sources, consequences, and remedies.

ECON304.title: Intermediate Macroeconomics
ECON304.description: Theory of national income, its measurement and determinants; analysis of inflation, growth, debt, and public policy.

ECON306.title: Intermediate Microeconomics
ECON306.description: Analysis of competitive and noncompetitive markets in terms of efficiency of resource utilization.

ECON310.title: Poverty and the Welfare State
ECON310.description: Description and analysis of US poverty; the "underclass"; feminization of poverty; working poor; the welfare state.

ECON315.title: Money and Banking
ECON315.description: Monetary theory and policy; description of financial institutions and markets.

ECON320.title: Economics of Public Finance
ECON320.description: Impact of taxes, government expenditures on allocation of resources, distribution of income; evaluation of government expenditure program, tax policies.

ECON325.title: Health Economics
ECON325.description: Economic analysis of health care markets, health insurance markets, and public policy regarding health care.

ECON327.title: Law and Economics
ECON327.description: Economic analysis of the common law.

ECON370.title: Comparative Economic Systems
ECON370.description: Place of the economy in different societies; nature and evolution of capitalism; crisis of command economies and capitalist restoration.

ECON372.title: History of Economic Institutions and Thought

EDOD653.description: Learn to conduct consultative conversations, develop value propositions, and create detailed request for service (RFS) proposals that direct the development to high impact-on demand assets. Oversee and participate in the development of HI-OD assets based on organizational opportunities.

EDOD667.title: Power-Politics-Influence in Organizations
EDOD667.description: Creation and execution of power relationships, political engagements, and communications in organizations.

EDOD670.title: Strategic Human Resource Development
EDOD670.description: Examine fundamentals of strategy from a HRD perspective, utilizing management tools, recent research and contemporary theory.

EDOD671.title: Establish Relations, Diagnose Organizations
EDOD671.description: Build relationships with clients and examine current practices to diagnose organizational learning and performance issues.

EDOD672.title: Change Facilitation
EDOD672.description: Roles and responsibilities of change agents and the fundamentals of change: principles, practices, processes, and resistance strategies.

EDOD673.title: Plan and Implement Change Interventions
EDOD673.description: Plan strategies and facilitate change interventions to improve organizational learning and performance.

EDOD674.title: Analyze Workplace Learning
EDOD674.description: Analyze workplace learning and performance issues drawing on foundational principles.

EDOD675.title: Design, Develop, Implement Workplace Learning
EDOD675.description: Design, develop, and implement workplace learning and performance interventions drawing on foundational principles.

EDOD676.title: Evaluate Workplace Learning
EDOD676.description: Evaluate workplace learning and performance interventions drawing on foundational principles. Examine satisfaction, learning, and performance results.

EDOD677.title: Action Learning and Inquiry
EDOD677.description: Literature reviews and data collection methods as the basis for diagnosing organizational learning and performance issues.

EDOD678.title: Assess Change Interventions
EDOD678.description: Assess and institutionalize change interventions to improve organizational learning and performance.

EDOD706.title: Organizational Learning, Performance, Change
EDOD706.description: History, development, and current status of organizational learning, performance and change theory, research and practice (praxis).

EDOD761.title: Evaluation and Assessment of Interventions
EDOD761.description: Evaluation and assessment of organizational learning, performance, and change (OLPC) interventions.

EDOD765.title: Strategic Planning of Education for Work
EDOD765.description: Human capital as component of strategic planning of education; training and development at national, regional, and organizational levels.

EDOD766.title: Scenario Planning in Organizations
EDOD766.description: Theory and practice of scenario planning. Application of scenario planning in organizations.

EDOD768.title: Workforce Development
EDOD768.description: Characteristics and elements of workforce development with special attention to the roles and responsibilities of employers and managers.

EDOD769.title: Theory and Practice of Change
EDOD769.description: Theory, history, characteristics, nature, levels, and types of change and modern conceptual and integrated models of change.

EDOD770.title: Organizational Culture
EDOD770.description: Theories, methods, and practices for evaluating, analyzing, and changing organizational culture.

EDOD771.title: Social Foundations of the Workplace
EDOD771.description: Social, cultural and political systems in organizations and their implications for employees.

EDOD772.title: Theory Building in Applied Disciplines
EDOD772.description: Theory building in workplace environments. Develop a theory and examine and critique existing theories.

EDOD773.title: Systems Leadership
EDOD773.description: A systems conceptualization and approach to leadership and leadership development.

EDRM600.title: Introduction to Research Methods
EDRM600.description: Methods of research, scientific methods, problem identification, research design, preparation and evaluation of research reports.

EDRM602.title: Action Research
EDRM602.description: Provide educators with knowledge and skills to plan and implement school-based research to improve teaching and learning.

EDRM606.title: Principles: Quantitative Data Analysis
EDRM606.description: Quantitative data analysis in social science research; descriptive statistics; fundamentals of inference.

EDRM612.title: Assessing Students in Educational Settings
EDRM612.description: Various ways of assessing students including traditional, authentic, and portfolio techniques for P-20 education.

EDRM663.title: Autoethnography & Reflective Practice I
EDRM663.description: Introduces basic autoethnographic research skills that underpin the creation of the culminating SAHE program portfolio. Foundational research methods, the portfolio process, cultivating reflective practice, and critical analysis skills are necessary to both conduct autoethnography and develop as a practitioner-scholar.

EDRM664.title: Autoethnography and Reflective Practice II
EDRM664.description: Apply advanced theoretical concepts and refine autoethnographic data collection, analysis, and writing skills. Focus on use of literature, refining a personal plan to complete the portfolio, and continuing to use data and reflection as tools of effective practice.

EDRM665.title: Qualitative Methods in Student Affairs
EDRM665.description: Introduction to the epistemologies and methodologies related to qualitative frameworks used in student affairs research. How to design a basic qualitative study, including research questions, data collection and analysis, as well as findings and discussion appropriate for topics related to student affairs.

EDRM666.title: Program Evaluation
EDRM666.description: Models and practices of program evaluation in both public and private sector organizations.

EDRM667.title: Student Affairs Assessment and Evaluation
EDRM667.description: Models and practices of assessment and evaluation in collegiate settings.

EDRM700.title: Quantitative Research Methods
EDRM700.description: Design, data analysis, interpretation of results, and evaluation of educational research studies.

EDRM701.title: Applied Linear Models-Educational Research
EDRM701.description: General linear model applications in educational research emphasizing conceptual understanding and characteristics of non-experimental designs.

EDRM702.title: Foundations of Educational Research
EDRM702.description: Philosophical, theoretical, and ethical foundations of educational research.

EDRM703.title: Applied Longitudinal Data Analysis
EDRM703.description: Methods and empirical applications of individual growth modeling and discrete-time event history analysis in educational research.

EDRM704.title: Qualitative Research
EDRM704.description: Examination of qualitative research theory, methods, and applications to education and the social sciences.

EDRM705.title: Qualitative Data Analysis
EDRM705.description: Examination of qualitative methods of data analysis, data presentation, and use of computer.

EDRM706.title: Analysis of Variance--Education Research
EDRM706.description: Analysis of variance applications in educational research; experimental design and analysis of data from experiments.

EDRM707.title: Quantitative Data Collection Methods/Analysis
EDRM707.description: Selection or development of questionnaires, tests, structured interviews, and observations. Reliability and validity. Reporting educational studies.

EDRM708.title: Narrative Inquiry
EDRM708.description: Theory, methods and design of narrative approaches to research including data collection and analysis applications.

EDRM711.title: Ethnographic Research
EDRM711.description: Theoretical underpinnings, research design, ethics and practical application of ethnographic research in a naturalistic setting.

EDCO500.title: Career and Employment Concepts
EDCO500.description: Career and lifestyle studies that provide an understanding of career development, employment concepts, and career counseling resources.

EDCO550.title: Professional School Counseling

EDCO552.title: School Counseling Program Delivery/Evaluation
EDCO552.description: Effective school counseling program development, delivery, and evaluation.

EDCO625.title: Foundations of Counseling
EDCO625.description: Foundations and techniques of individual guidance and counseling.

EDCO650.title: Theories of Counseling and Development
EDCO650.description: Theories of individual counseling and development.

EDCO651.title: Group Guidance and Counseling
EDCO651.description: Theory and techniques of group guidance and counseling.

EDCO652.title: Ethics in Counseling/Career Development
EDCO652.description: Awareness and critical analysis of ethical and legal issues in counseling and career development.

EDCO653.title: Counseling for Cultural Diversity
EDCO653.description: Influence of cultural differences in delivering culturally responsive counseling.

EDCO655.title: Brief Counseling
EDCO655.description: Continued development, knowledge, and use of counseling theories and skills such as solution focus counseling/therapy and motivational interviewing techniques. Develop understanding of the change model (Transtheoretical Model) to assist in helping clients make desired changes in their lives.

EDCO656.title: Counseling Assessment and Appraisal
EDCO656.description: The topics include (a) history and philosophy of educational, psychological, and vocational testing; (b) introduction to the basic statistical concepts surrounding test validation, scoring and interpretation; (c) essential criteria for evaluating and selecting appropriate assessment instruments; (d) principles of standardized administration and scoring; (e) interpretation of test results and appropriate consultation.

EDCO660.title: Career Development Counseling

EDCO661.title: Career and Life Design Counseling
EDCO661.description: Career and life design counseling knowledge, skills, and practices with a focus on emerging career development and career counseling theories, concepts, and models; career programming and evaluation; and career development and counseling advocacy.

EDCO662.title: Counseling Children and Adolescents
EDCO662.description: Counseling theories and interventions applied to the child and adolescent client population.

EDCO665.title: Career Development Institute
EDCO665.description: Current issues related to employment, employee development, career planning, and labor market information are examined. Site visits and career development audits of local employers as well as other structured activities and assignments encourage students to consider educational and labor market trends and career development within a global society.

EDCO670.title: Introduction to Mental Health Counseling
EDCO670.description: How psychopathology is experienced and displayed by the client and the key principles in diagnosing mental health disorders.

EDCO675.title: Mental Health Counseling and Treatment
EDCO675.description: The clinical mental health counseling (CMHC) field and counseling treatment, with a focus on emerging current trends, multicultural considerations, professional issues, and credentialing of CMHCs. Topics include clinical interviewing, case conceptualizations, and treatment and diagnosis of specialty populations.

ECE102.title: Digital Circuit Logic

Projects will be initiated by students or outside sources and will consist of small-scale service/outreach projects or market-driven projects that simulate a business environment.

ECE495A.title: Independent Study

ECE495B.title: Independent Study: Open Option Project
ECE495B.description: Students will work on an array of different electrical and computer engineering projects independently or under the guidance of industry mentors. Projects will be initiated by students or outside sources and will consist of small-scale service/outreach projects or market-driven projects that simulate a business environment.

ECE495C.title: Independent Study: Vertically Integrated Projects
ECE495C.description: Explore and develop comprehensive applications of electrical and computer engineering technologies as a member of a team, especially as they relate to active research areas of CSU faculty members.

ECE573.title: Semiconductor Optoelectronics Laboratory
ECE573.description: Experimental characterization techniques for semiconductor optoelectronic devices and design and testing of related electronic circuits.

ECE574.title: Optical Properties in Solids
ECE574.description: Light propagation and interaction with materials; linear and non-linear optical properties.

ECE575.title: Experiments in VLSI System Design I
ECE575.description: Set of labs designed to enhance students' understanding of the materials in

ECE587.title: Internship

ECE604.title: Nonlinear Optics
ECE604.description: Principles of nonlinear optics, symmetry properties, multiple order nonlinear phenomenon, and nonlinear spectroscopy.

ECE611.title: Nonlinear Control Systems

ECE612.description: Introduction to modern robust control theory techniques for analysis and design of large-scale uncertain multivariable systems.

ECE614.title: Principles of Digital Communications
ECE614.description: Information theory, optimal receiver design, waveform coding, error correcting coding.

ECE622.title: Energy Networks and Power Distribution Grids

ECE642.description: Maxwell's equations, radiation, boundary value problem, dyadic Green's functions, scattering theory.

ECE650.description: Fundamental principles of short wavelength electromagnetic radiation.

ECE661.description: Embedded systems design: networks on chip, novel memory architectures, synthesis algorithms, optimization for low power, fault tolerance, security.

ECE666.title: Topics in Robotics
ECE666.description: Recent advances in robotics, automation, and intelligent systems.

ECE670B.title: Topics in Architecture/Systems: Performance Evaluation and Modeling

ECE742.title: Topics in Electromagnetics
ECE742.description: Applications of wave propagation and scattering to microwave radar, Doppler radar, meteorological radar applications.

ECE752.title: Topics in Signal Processing
ECE752.description: Adaptive filtering, spectral estimation, sonar/radar signal processing, and detection/classification schemes.

ECE777.title: X-Ray Lasers
ECE777.description: Fundamentals, design, and implementation of soft X-ray lasers and X-ray optics.

ENGR101.title: Grand Challenges in Engineering
ENGR101.description: National Academy of Engineering's Grand Challenges in Engineering: overview, roles of engineering disciplines, engineering and societal challenges.

ENGR102.title: Problem Solving for Engineers
ENGR102.description: Engineering problem solving: dimensional analysis; precision, accuracy, repeatability; problems from all major engineering disciplines.

ENGR298.title: Undergraduate Research
ENGR298.description: Directed undergraduate research with a faculty mentor.

ENGR300.title: 3D Printing Lab for Engineers
ENGR300.description: Basics of 3D printing, technology, workflows, techniques and related software, focused on practical usage and project development in engineering. Topics include technology of devices, usage, calibration and tuning, repair and maintenance, and techniques for maximizing part quality with minimal waste.

ENGR370.description: Faculty-led study abroad program that includes cultural, language, and engineering instruction. Course will be held at a host institution in China with instruction at CSU before the travel portion of the course.

ENGR382A.title: Study Abroad: Grand Challenges in Engineering--China
ENGR382A.description: Faculty-led study abroad program that includes cultural, language, and engineering instruction. Course will be held at a host institution in China.

ENGR389.title: Engineering Cooperative Experience
ENGR389.description: Semester-long full-time industry engineering experience in a position relevant to the student’s major field.

ENGR422.title: Technology Entrepreneurship
ENGR422.description: Principles of technology-based entrepreneurship, including recognizing, analyzing, and acting on technology-based business opportunities; and development of an opportunity analysis.

ENGR498.title: Undergraduate Research
ENGR498.description: Directed undergraduate research with a faculty mentor.

ENGR502.title: Engineering Project and Program Management
ENGR502.description: Engineering program management fundamentals, program planning and control strategies, risk assessment, work breakdown structures and costing options.

ENGR510.title: Engineering Optimization: Method/Application
ENGR510.description: Optimization methods; linear programming, network flows, integer programming, interior point methods, quadratic programming, engineering applications.

ENGR596.title: Group Study-Systems Engineering Skills
ENGR596.description: Topics related to building specialized skills relevant for the systems engineering field.

ENGR597.title: Group Study in Systems Engineering
ENGR597.description: Special and contemporary topics in the field of systems engineering.

ENGR622.title: Energy Networks and Power Distribution Grids

ENGR667.title: Advanced Model-Based Systems Engineering
ENGR667.description: Theory and application of formal systems architecture modeling.

ENGR786.title: Applied Systems Engineering Practicum
ENGR786.description: Research techniques, critical thinking, evaluation criteria, and methods of technical writing.

ENGR799A.title: Dissertation: PhD
ENGR799A.description: Dissertation for PhD in System Engineering Program.

EAP100.title: International Undergraduate Success

Emphasis on learning about academic expectations at American universities, developing effective strategies for academic success, and improving academic English skills. Discover the resources available on the CSU campus that help academic success.

EAP102.description: Development of advanced academic skills for undergraduate international students. EAP150.title: International Graduate Student Success

EAP153.title: Writing for International Graduate Students

E140.title: The Study of Literature (GT-AH2)

E142.description: Authors from a range of international, cross-national, cultural, and ethnic backgrounds focusing on themes of immigration, exile, or education.

E210.title: Beginning Creative Writing

E232.title: Introduction to Humanities (GT-AH2)

E236.title: Short Fiction

E238.title: Contemporary Global Fiction (GT-AH2)
E238.description: Contemporary fiction chosen for its relevance to global and cultural awareness.

E240.title: Introduction to Poetry
E240.description: Development of critical skills necessary to understand and enjoy poetry.

E242.title: Reading Shakespeare (GT-AH2)
E242.description: Reading of Shakespeare texts, using various approaches of interpretation for understanding and relation to our contemporary cultural situation.

FW468.title: Bird Ecology and Conservation
FW468.description: Introduction to the principles and the practice of avian ecology and conservation. Class discussions, outdoor labs and field trips emphasize major threats to birds and opportunities for overcoming those challenges. Learn to identify local birds by sight and sound, employ field methods (e.g., bird banding), participate in long-term applied research projects, collect and analyze data independently, and interact with conservation practitioners.

FW469.title: Conservation and Management of Large Mammals
FW469.description: Principles of behavior, ecology, population dynamics, and conservation related to large mammals.

FW471.title: Wildlife Data Collection and Analysis
FW471.description: Analysis methods used in wildlife management and research; adaptive resource management with emphasis on learning through field and computer labs.

FW472.title: Issues in Animal Conservation and Management
FW472.description: Current and emerging issues in fish and wildlife conservation and management at the state, national, and global scales.

FW473A.title: Travel Abroad: Conserving Desert/Marine Animals
FW473A.description: Ecology and conservation of animals from desert, marine, intertidal, and shore ecosystems and application to problems of animal conservation in an international setting.

FW475.title: Conservation Decision Making
FW475.description: Structured approaches to conservation and management of vertebrates; articulating objectives, developing management options, and predicting outcomes.

FW477.title: Wildlife Habitat Use and Management
FW477.description: Wildlife habitat evaluation, classification, and improvement; analysis of habitat use patterns; planning and implementation of management plans.

FW487.title: Internship
FW487.description: Field experience in fish and wildlife management.

FW540.title: Fisheries Ecology
FW540.description: Population, community, and ecosystem management for fishes and other aquatic organisms in freshwater habitats.

FW544.title: Ecotoxicology
FW544.description: Ecological effects of contaminants on populations, communities, and ecosystems.

FW551.title: Design of Fish and Wildlife Studies
FW551.description: Principles, types of studies, and philosophy of science in design of experimental, observational, and sampling studies for wildlife investigations.

FW552.title: Applied Sampling for Wildlife/Fish Studies
FW552.description: Survey sampling theory and techniques, including distance sampling, with emphasis on wildlife and fish studies.

FW553.title: Adaptive Fish and Wildlife Management
FW553.description: Formal approaches to making management decisions about wildlife and fish populations, using tools of decision analysis.

FW555.title: Conservation Biology
FW555.description: Ecological factors in conservation of biological diversity.

FW556.title: Leopold's Ethic for Wildlife and Land
FW556.description: Philosophy, art, history, and science of wildlife and land management from writings of Aldo Leopold.

FW557.title: Wildlife Habitat Management on Private Land
FW557.description: Management of cover, food, and water for wildlife and fish in the Great Plains. Emphasis on practices compatible with other uses of private land.

FW558.title: Conservation Genetics of Wild Populations
FW558.description: Examine the background, concepts, and tools required to determine how genetic data can be used to evaluate wild vertebrate species and communities of conservation concern.

FW562.title: Fish and Wildlife Population Dynamics
FW562.description: Factors that influence population abundance and density, and how they change over time. It blends ecology, evolution, genetics, and mathematical modeling into a unified field. Concentrate on understanding single-species population growth models, including metapopulation concepts, as well as multi-species topics such as predation and competition.

FW563.title: Analyses for Managing Wild Populations
FW563.description: Design of wildlife population studies and the analysis of mark-recapture and occupancy data. Discussion of scientific philosophy, statistical theory, sampling design, and the application of the latest quantitative approaches to the analysis of population data.

FW564.title: Science of Managing Human-Wildlife Conflicts
FW564.description: Human-wildlife conflicts, and in particular, damage caused by wildlife, often termed wildlife damage. Topics such as animal behaviors, population dynamics, public attitudes, economics, and effective strategies in understanding the various types of conflicts and how to manage them.

FW567.title: Wildlife Disease Ecology
FW567.description: Ecological, epidemiological, and evolutionary principles of disease in fish and wildlife populations; contemporary issues in disease ecology.

FW568.title: Sustaining River Ecosystems in Changing World

FW573.title: Travel Abroad-Wildlife Ecology/Conservation
FW573.description: Study tour of various overseas ecosystems and natural resources conservation programs; discussions with local ecologists/managers.

FW575.title: Wildlife Habitat Evaluation for Educators
FW575.description: Teachers or leaders implement wildlife habitat evaluation procedures in classroom or community programs and evaluate performance of students.

FW576.title: Wildlife Policy, Administration, and Law
FW576.description: Evolution of policy affecting wildlife and humans using historical, current, philosophical, legal, and administrative constructs.

FW577.title: Management of Wildlife Habitat
FW577.description: Identifying and implementing management techniques for evaluating, classifying , and improving wildlife habitat to sustain and conserve populations.

FW578.title: Conservation Decision Analysis
FW578.description: Identifying decision making processes and adaptive management techniques used in conservation; consideration of objectives, options and outcomes.

FW605.title: Advanced Physiological Ecology of Fishes
FW605.description: Physiological ecology of fishes; functional adaptations and adjustments used to cope with environmental and physiological states.

FW662.title: Wildlife Population Dynamics
FW662.description: Population models; experimental evidence and analysis of theories of population regulation; case studies.

FW663.title: Sampling & Analysis Vertebrate Populations
FW663.description: Sampling and analysis of fish and wildlife populations, including survival estimation, capture-recapture sampling, and transect sampling.

FW677.title: Wildlife Habitat Management
FW677.description: Habitat models; vegetation manipulation and monitoring for wildlife; extended field trips.

FW692.title: Seminar: Fish, Wildlife, and Conservation Biology

FW696.title: Group Study: Fish, Wildlife, Conservation Biology
FW696.description: Group study projects on topics in fish, wildlife, and conservation biology.

FSHN125.title: Food and Nutrition in Health
FSHN125.description: Nutritional quality and safety of food related to human health.

FSHN150.title: Survey of Human Nutrition
FSHN150.description: Basic nutrition principles and concepts; their application to personal health and interactions with societal and environmental issues.

FSHN192.title: First Year Seminar
FSHN192.description: Facilitate a successful transition to college for new incoming students by emphasizing personal growth and identifying campus resources.

FSHN300.title: Food Principles and Applications
FSHN300.description: Application of food preparation theories to modification and evaluation of food products.

FSHN301.title: Food Principles and Applications Laboratory
FSHN301.description: Techniques and manipulative skills for preparation and evaluation of standard and modified food products.

FSHN350.title: Human Nutrition
FSHN350.description: Metabolism of macro and micronutrients; physiologic basis underlying dietary recommendations for human health. Nutrients, dietary requirements for physical well-being; evaluation of various diets.

FSHN360.title: Nutrition Assessment
FSHN360.description: Principles of anthropometric, dietary, and biochemical assessment of nutritional status.

FSHN392.title: Dietetic Practice Seminar
FSHN392.description: Pre-professional skills to prepare students for the pursuit of careers in the field of dietetics.

FSHN428.title: Nutrition Teaching and Counseling Techniques
FSHN428.description: Objectives, principles, and organization of subject matter for nutrition education and counseling.

FSHN444.title: Nutrition and Aging
FSHN444.description: Effect of aging on nutrient needs and impact of nutrition on successful aging and health in the elderly.

FSHN445.title: Early Childhood Health, Safety, and Nutrition

FSHN450.title: Medical Nutrition Therapy
FSHN450.description: Use of nutrition therapy in the treatment of acute conditions and chronic disease states.

FSHN451.title: Community Nutrition
FSHN451.description: Influences on nutritional status, assessment of nutrition problems and needs, planning and evaluation of nutrition intervention programs.

FSHN455.title: Food Systems: Impact on Health/Food Security
FSHN455.description: Conventional and alternative food systems and their impact on nutrition, health, food security, and the environment.

FSHN459.title: Nutrition in the Life Cycle
FSHN459.description: Nutritional aspects associated with each phase of human life cycle including pregnancy, infancy, childhood, adolescence, and early and late adulthood.

FSHN470.title: Integrative Nutrition and Metabolism
FSHN470.description: Influence of nutrition on roles and action of hormones and gene expression on metabolism.

FSHN486C.title: Practicum: Food Service Management
FSHN486C.description: Supervised off-campus experience in food service management.

FSHN492.title: Seminar in Dietetics and Nutrition
FSHN492.description: Capstone seminar in nutrition and dietetics.

FSHN496A.title: Group Study in Dietetics and Nutrition: Energy, Weight Management
FSHN496A.description: Current topics in nutrition and professional skills for the dietetics profession.

FSHN496B.title: Group Study in Dietetics and Nutrition: Sustainable Food Issues
FSHN496B.description: Current topics in nutrition and professional skills for the dietetics profession.

FSHN496C.title: Group Study in Dietetics and Nutrition: Nutrition and Chronic Disease
FSHN496C.description: Current topics in nutrition and professional skills for the dietetics profession.

FSHN496D.title: Group Study in Dietetics and Nutrition: Nutrition for Athletes
FSHN496D.description: Current topics in nutrition and professional skills for the dietetics profession.

FSHN496E.title: Group Study in Dietetics and Nutrition: Food Safety
FSHN496E.description: Current topics in nutrition and professional skills for the dietetics profession.

FSHN496F.title: Group Study in Dietetics and Nutrition: Service Marketing
FSHN496F.description: Current topics in nutrition and professional skills for the dietetics profession.

FSHN496G.title: Group Study in Dietetics and Nutrition: Food and Consumer Issues
FSHN496G.description: Current topics in nutrition and professional skills for the dietetics profession.

FSHN496H.title: Group Study in Dietetics and Nutrition: Public Health and Policy
FSHN496H.description: Current topics in nutrition and professional skills for the dietetics profession.

FSHN496I.title: Group Study in Dietetics and Nutrition: Special Topics
FSHN496I.description: Current topics in nutrition and professional skills for the dietetics profession.

FSHN500.title: Food Systems, Nutrition, and Food Security
FSHN500.description: Global and local food systems and their potential influence on nutrition and food security.

FSHN501.title: Research Methods in Dietetics
FSHN501.description: Testing and generating theory. Methods for collecting and analyzing quantitative and qualitative data, critique of research and proposal development.

FSHN503.title: Issues in Dietetics Practice
FSHN503.description: Environment in which foodservice, hospitality, and healthcare organizations operate; impact of change on hospitality and healthcare organizations.

FSHN504.title: Micronutrients
FSHN504.description: Coordination of structure and function related to metabolic needs as a basis for evaluating micronutrient needs in normal or altered metabolic states.

FSHN505.title: Nutrition and Physical Activity in Aging
FSHN505.description: Physiological changes during aging and impacts on health and disease; focus on successful aging with emphasis on physical activity and nutrition.

FSHN506.title: Nutrition and Human Performance
FSHN506.description: Relationship of specific nutrients and optimal nutrition to physical efficiency and performance.

FSHN507.title: Nutrition Education in the Community
FSHN507.description: Principles and practices of teaching individuals and groups to translate nutrition knowledge into action. Emphasis on research and evaluation.

FSHN508.title: International Nutrition and World Hunger
FSHN508.description: Magnitude, causes, and nature of hunger and under-nurturing; programs and policies to alleviate hunger.

FSHN509.title: Nutrition Counseling and Education Methods
FSHN509.description: Application of learning theories and nutrition counseling with individuals and groups in the community and clinical settings.

FSHN510.title: Pediatric Clinical Nutrition
FSHN510.description: Physiological, biochemical and nutritional aspects of disease processes relevant to infants and children up to 18 years of age.

FSHN511.title: Maternal and Child Nutrition
FSHN511.description: Behavioral, physiological and public health issues impacting dietary and nutritional factors that support growth and development.

FSHN512.title: Nutritional Aspects of Oncology
FSHN512.description: Relationships between nutrition and cancer including the role of nutrition in specific cancers, cancer prevention and patient management.

FSHN520.title: Advanced Medical Nutrition Therapy
FSHN520.description: Role of nutrition in etiology and treatment of selected disorders.

FSHN525.title: Nutrition Education Theories and Practice
FSHN525.description: Examination of current theories, skills, and models used in nutrition education programs as preparation for research and practice.

FSHN530.title: Principles of Nutrition Science & Metabolism
FSHN530.description: Science of nutrition, including the ingestion and digestion of food, the absorption, transport, and metabolism of macro and micronutrients, energy balance and bodyweight regulation, and relationships to health and risk of disease. Structure, functional roles, and metabolic regulation of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins during conditions of fasting, feeding, and exercise. The role of vitamins and minerals in cellular and whole body homeostasis.

FSHN531.title: Diet, Nutrition, and Chronic Disease
FSHN531.description: Principles related to the role of diet and nutrition in obesity, digestive health, type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and cancer with a focus on current evidence and best practices for prevention.

FSHN532.title: Emerging Issues in Nutrition
FSHN532.description: Principles related to emerging areas of nutrition and their role in health promotion. Focus is on current research related to micronutrients and supplements, sports nutrition, food safety and technology, food systems, nutrition and aging, and nutrigenomics.

FSHN540.title: Nutrigenomics and Advanced Lipid Metabolism
FSHN540.description: How nutrients regulate gene expressions (nutrigenetics) and how genotype influences an individual's nutrient requirements (nutrigenomics).

FSHN550.title: Advanced Nutritional Science I
FSHN550.description: Protein, vitamin, mineral metabolism;  human studies, animal models.

FSHN551.title: Advanced Nutritional Science II
FSHN551.description: Carbohydrate, lipid, energy metabolism; human studies, animal models.

FSHN587C.title: Internship: Food Service Management
FSHN587C.description: Supervised practice in food service management.

FSHN600.title: Responsible Conduct of Research
FSHN600.description: Responsible conduct of research (RCR) including ethical frameworks, publication practices, human and animal research and data management. Case studies and professional codes of conduct will be used to explore conduct of ethical research in humans and animals and how to avoid and manage research misconduct.

FSHN620.title: Community Nutrition Planning and Evaluation
FSHN620.description: Community nutrition assessment; nutrition program planning and evaluation,  nutrition policy analysis.

FSHN628.title: Advanced Nutrition Counseling Techniques
FSHN628.description: Principles, strategies and techniques for interviewing, assessing and providing nutrition counseling in community settings.

FSHN640.title: Selected Topics in Nutritional Epidemiology
FSHN640.description: Overview of topics in nutritional epidemiology; study design, interpretation of findings, linkage of data to action.

FSHN650A.title: Recent Developments in Human Nutrition: Protein, Vitamins, and Minerals
FSHN650A.description: Appraisal of literature on human nutritional status.

FSHN650B.title: Recent Developments in Human Nutrition: Carbohydrates, Lipids, and Energy
FSHN650B.description: Appraisal of literature on human nutritional status.

FSHN650C.title: Recent Developments in Human Nutrition: Genomic, Proteomics, and Metabolomics
FSHN650C.description: Appraisal of literature on human nutritional status.

FSHN660.title: Women's Issues in Lifecycle Nutrition
FSHN660.description: Current nutritional issues related to selected stages of the lifecycle compared to normal adult nutritional needs.

FSHN661.title: International Nutrition
FSHN661.description: Roles of technological programs and international agencies in meeting nutritional needs.

FSHN675.title: Regulation of Energy Intake
FSHN675.description: Central and peripheral mechanisms controlling energy intake with emphasis on humans. Current theories, experimental approaches, and new research.

FSHN700.title: Cellular Nutrition
FSHN700.description: Essential nutrient requirements of cells and organs.

FSHN750.title: Nutritional Basis of Chronic Disease
FSHN750.description: Role of nutrition in the pathogenesis and prevention of specific chronic diseases.

FTEC110.title: Food-From Farm to Table
FTEC110.description: Commercial food processing, related to preservation and enhancing of food quality, safety, and value.

FTEC210.title: Science of Food Fermentation
FTEC210.description: Science, history, culture, gastronomy, safety, health, and nutrition aspects of fermented foods and beverages.

FTEC350.title: Fermentation Microbiology
FTEC350.description: Integration of fermentation science, microbiology, and chemistry.

FTEC351.title: Fermentation Microbiology Laboratory
FTEC351.description: Introduction to fermentation microbiological practices with relevance to production, quality control, and food safety in the food and beverage industry.

FTEC360.title: Brewing Processes
FTEC360.description: Influence of raw material selection, malting, mashing, boiling, and fermentation on quality of beverages.

FTEC375.title: Introduction to Fermentation Unit Operations
FTEC375.description: Principles related to processes and equipment design in fermented food and beverage industries. Survey of unit operations.

FTEC400.title: Food Safety
FTEC400.description: Safety of human food emphasizing safe production, processing, marketing, preparation, consumption, and regulations.

FTEC422.title: Brewing Science I
FTEC422.description: Assessment, quantification, and control of various aspects of commercial beer production.

FTEC430.title: Sensory Evaluation of Fermented Products
FTEC430.description: Application of sensory evaluation techniques to the study of fermented foods.

FTEC440.title: Packaging Technology
FTEC440.description: Science, technology, and management of packaging.

FTEC460.title: Brewing Science II
FTEC460.description: Applications of scientific and technical aspects of malting, brewing, fermenting, finishing, packaging, and evaluating of fermented beverages.

FTEC465.title: Food Production Operations
FTEC465.description: Production, operation, and management techniques used in the food industry at company, local and international levels.

FTEC478.title: Phytochemicals and Probiotics for Health
FTEC478.description: Examination of phytochemistry and probiotic organisms important in human health.

FTEC492.title: Seminar: Fermentation Science and Food Safety
FTEC492.description: Capstone seminar in fermentation science and food safety.

FTEC496A.title: Group Study Fermentation Science: Current Issues
FTEC496A.description: Explore emerging health issues associated with fermented foods and beverages.

FTEC496B.title: Group Study Fermentation Science: Functional Foods in Health
FTEC496B.description: Functional foods may be used to maintain overall good health and to prevent, manage, and/or treat disease. Apply nutrition science and fermentation science to learn how foods or food components are functional, their bioavailability, and the physiological effects related to human health.

FTEC570.title: Food Product Development
FTEC570.description: Food product concepts, feasibility, and evaluation.

FTEC572.title: Food Biotechnology
FTEC572.description: Interrelationships among microorganisms, food processing methods, advances in biotechnology and food quality, spoilage, shelf-life and safety.

FTEC574.title: Current Issues in Food Safety
FTEC574.description: Current food safety issues from field to table; microbiological, consumer, processing, and agricultural issues.

FTEC576.title: Cereal Science
FTEC576.description: Chemistry and functionality of cereal grain components and their importance in human nutrition.

F101.title: Intro to Forest and Rangeland Stewardship
F101.description: Introduce both first year and transfer students to the faculty, and expertise within the department of Forest and Rangeland Stewardship. Gain an appreciation for the majors selected.

F209.title: Introduction to Forest and Rangeland Ecology
F209.description: Ecological concepts pertaining to natural resources and the management of forests and rangelands. Analysis of species, population, and community interactions within an applied framework.

F224.title: Wildland Fire Measurements
F224.description: Wildland fire control and use measurements:  fuels, weather, topography, fire behavior, and fire ecology.

F230.title: Forestry Field Measurements
F230.description: Develop field skills using maps, compasses, and aerial photos; photo interpretation; tree and stand measurements; stand volume and value estimates.

F311.title: Forest Ecology
F311.description: Relationships of ecological concepts to the dynamics of forest ecosystems.

F312.title: Dendrology
F312.description: Identification, classification, nomenclature, morphology, phenology, ecology, geographic ranges, and natural history of trees. Explore the historical and current importance of trees to society. Focus on major forest tree species of North America, and includes several exotic species that commonly occur in urban areas.

F321.title: Forest Biometry
F321.description: Measurement and estimation of timber in logs, trees, and stands. Sampling with varying probabilities.

F322.title: Economics of the Forest Environment
F322.description: Economic principles and techniques applied to forested environments.

F324.title: Fire Effects and Adaptations
F324.description: Introduction to fire ecology including fire history, ecosystem effects, and organism responses.

F325.title: Silviculture
F325.description: Principles of silviculture and their application to major forest types of United States.

F326.title: Wildland Fire Behavior and Management
F326.description: Physical and managerial principles influencing fire, how fires shape our forests and approaches used to manage wildland fire.

F330.title: Timber Harvesting and the Environment
F330.description: Principles of timber harvesting and effects of logging on the environment.

F331.title: Wood Products in Society
F331.description: Role of wood products in society; spectrum of wood products; some field trips.

F421.title: Forest Stand Management
F421.description: Forest management plan preparation: forest condition and health assessment; evaluation of silvicultural treatments; implementation and monitoring.

F422.title: Quantitative Methods in Forest Management
F422.description: Design and analysis of optimization and nonoptimization models in forest managerial operations.

F425.title: Advanced Wildland Fire Behavior and Management
F425.description: Advanced strategies, tools, and techniques for wildland fire management: prediction, prevention, suppression, and use for resource benefit.

F430.title: Forestry Field Practices
F430.description: Forestry field course, S212 saw certification, collect stand inventory data, develop and implant stand prescription, and harvest and process trees.

F487.title: Professional Forestry Internship
F487.description: Professional-level field experience with forestry organization.

F510.title: Ecophysiology of Trees
F510.description: Environmental factors affecting physiology of woody plants; emphasis on water relations in trees and importance of water in physiological processes.

F520.title: Advanced Quantitative Methods in Forestry I
F520.description: Design and analysis of optimization models in forest management operations:  linear, goal, and dynamic programming.

F521.title: Advanced Quantitative Methods in Forestry II
F521.description: Analysis of forest inventory information; dynamic and stochastic models oriented to decision making and research in forestry.

F522.title: Advanced Forest Economics
F522.description: Analysis of forestry issues:  financial maturity, management intensity, federal policy, taxation, natural environments, and silviculture.

F524.title: Forest Fire Meteorology and Behavior
F524.description: Effects of atmospheric processes on wild and prescribed fires; interrelationships of weather, fuels, and topography on forest and range fires.

F525.title: Silvicultural Practices
F525.description: Comprehensive coverage of silvicultural practices as applied in US forestry.

F526.title: Multiple Resources Silviculture
F526.description: Concepts and techniques of silviculture and their application to forest ecology to meet a wide range of desired conditions and resource objectives. Develops knowledge of ecological applications directed at the management of forests with multiple considerations, including wildlife, recreation, forest health, and timber production.

F540.title: Fuels, Vegetation, and Fire Management
F540.description: Develop, test and display the impact of alternative fuels and vegetation treatments on vegetation development,  fuels and fire behavior.

F571.title: Applied Forest Ecology
F571.description: Concepts and theory of stand dynamics in relation to advanced ecological concepts within the Rocky Mountain Region and Intermountain West and applications of these concepts to natural disturbance-based management.

F572.title: Advanced Silviculture Practices
F572.description: Application of forest ecology principles and silvicultural techniques to meet a wide range of desired conditions and resource objectives.

F574.title: Climate Adaptive Forest Management
F574.description: Application of climate science and adaptive silviculture strategies to real-world forest management scenarios.

F575.title: Monitoring for Advanced Silviculture
F575.description: Best practices and principles for evaluating forest management effectiveness at various scales across the landscape.

F576.title: Advanced Silviculture Capstone
F576.description: Application of ecological principles, climate change science, and regional silvicultural principles to the management of a local forest stand.

F592.title: Advanced Silviculture Seminar
F592.description: Forestry professionals and faculty present different aspects of advanced silviculture skills to prepare students for the rigor of online, graduate-level courses and to create a plan and portfolio for their final project at the culmination of the certificate.

F610.title: Advanced Forest Ecology
F610.description: Patterns of tree mortality and their consequences for ecological communities, disturbance regimes, and ecosystem processes. The literature included is diverse ranging from ecophysiology to dendroecology to climate science, and the goal is to integrate this diverse literature to understand the ecological consequences of climate variability on forest ecosystems of the southern Rocky Mountains and globally.

F624.title: Fire Ecology
F624.description: Fire in forest and range ecosystems; principles and techniques for evaluating fire effects on vegetation, soils, watersheds, and wildlife.

F721.title: Forest Policy
F721.description: Policies and institutions affecting management of forest lands in U.S.

GEAL8400.title: English as a Second Language - General English Language Skills Workshop
GEAL8400.description: Not for academic credit.  English as a Second Language for non-native speakers. Through writing assignments, daily homework, class discussions, presentation skills practice, and the use of technology (such as Microsoft Word, Prezi, PowerPoint, and the Internet), learners will create one integrated-skills project to practice: researching and presenting information on topics from the Everyday English and Cultural Issues courses.

GEAL8410.title: English as a Second Language – General English Everyday English
GEAL8410.description: Not for academic credit.  English as a Second Language for non-native speakers. Students will learn the vocabulary and grammar needed to communicate, orally or in writing, in common, everyday situations.

GEAL8420.title: English as a Second Language – General English Cultural Issues
GEAL8420.description: Not for academic credit.  English as a Second Language for non-native speakers.Through reading and listening passages, students will learn the vocabulary and grammar needed to discuss and write about various cultural topics from around the world.

GEAL8430.title: English as a Second Language – Special Academic English Listening and Speaking
GEAL8430.description: Not for academic credit.  English as a Second Language for non-native speakers. Students will improve listening comprehension using texts; practice communicating with increasing fluency and accuracy about ideas from course themes.

GEAL8432.title: English as a Second Language – Special Academic English Reading and Writing
GEAL8432.description: Not for academic credit.  English as a Second Language for non-native speakers. Students will improve reading comprehension using texts; complete well-developed and organized writing tasks about ideas from course themes.

GEAL8433.title: English as a Second Language – Special Academic English Grammar
GEAL8433.description: Not for academic credit.  English as a Second Language for non-native speakers. Students will focus on grammatical structures present in reading and listening texts; incorporate learned grammatical structures in writing and speaking tasks.

GEAL8435.title: English as a Second Language – Special Non-Core English Skills Workshop
GEAL8435.description: Not for academic credit.  English as a Second Language for non-native speakers. Students will practice academic skills, vocabulary, learning strategies, communication and technology skills.

GR100.title: Introduction to Geography (GT-SS2)
GR100.description: Major geographic themes applied to selected regions; physical environment, human-land relationships, regional analysis.

GR102.title: Geography of Europe and the Americas (GT-SS2)
GR102.description: Examines the physical and human geographies of Europe, including the former Soviet Union, and the Americas from the Southern Cone to Canada. Focus is on the content of these geographies, why they exist, and their current significance; supported by extensive map analysis.

GR213.title: Climate Migrants
GR213.description: Explore the various drivers of migration, emphasizing climate and others including biogeographic, political, economic, and social factors.

GR220.title: Mapping, Cartography, and Spatial Thinking
GR220.description: Spatial thinking is the science and art of making maps that play a key role in enabling geographers to visualize space and spatial patterns, as well as, convey spatial information to others. Introduction to the science of spatial thinking, including collecting spatial information and making maps, modern geographic information sciences (GIS) that have evolved from cartography, and spatial analysis techniques that are fundamental to Geography.

GR303.title: Mountain Geography
GR303.description: The physical and human dimensions of mountains. Examples from mountains around the world with case studies from Colorado.

GR305.title: Geography of Global Health
GR305.description: Study, research and practice of global health using an ecological approach that integrates health with spatial thinking. Focuses on a common set of issues which transcends boundaries, both domestic and international, and a set of actions to address the geographic burden of disease. Key principles and concepts, history of global health transitions, common and emerging health issues.

GR311.title: GIS for Social Scientists
GR311.description: Applications of GIS techniques useful to the social sciences. Mapping techniques and GIS toolkits are practiced in lab.

GR315.title: Quantitative Geographical Methods
GR315.description: Methods to collect, analyze, display, and model geographic data.

GR320.title: Cultural Geography
GR320.description: Geographic analysis of cultural phenomena, elements emphasizing human-land relationships and spatial patterns of agriculture, cities, language, religion.

GR330.title: Urban Geography
GR330.description: Spatial distribution of urban areas and the geographic similarities and contrasts that exist between and within them.

GR331.title: Geography of Farming Systems
GR331.description: Geographic analysis of farming systems worldwide and by region; their development over time, human-land relationships, and spatial patterns.

GR333.title: Glaciers and Climate Change
GR333.description: Glacier mass balance, dynamics, past fluctuations, and glaciers' relation to climate change.

GR345.title: Geography of Hazards
GR345.description: Causes, effects, distributional patterns, and human adjustments to environmental hazards.

GR348.title: Biogeography
GR348.description: Species distribution of plants and animals in relation to earth history and environments, evolution, and ecology.

GR410.title: Climate Change: Science, Policy, Implications
GR410.description: Implications and consequences for earth systems including the cryosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, and human systems.

GR415.title: The Geography of Commodities
GR415.description: Social relations, international trade, and environmental impacts surrounding the production, transportation, exchange, and consumption of commodities.

GR420.title: Spatial Analysis with GIS
GR420.description: Theory, application of geographic information systems for spatial analysis; conceptual basis of GIS, nature and use of geographic data, case studies.

GR430.title: Land Change Science and Remote Sensing
GR430.description: Local case studies and global cases of land-use/land-cover changes in rural, peri-urban, and urban areas.

GR431.title: Land Change Science Lab
GR431.description: Utilize advanced remote sensing techniques and satellite images, air photos, and ancillary data to investigate land-use and land-cover changes.

GR448.title: Forest Biogeography and Climate Change
GR448.description: Forest adaptation and conservation in relation to global change with a focus on climate change.

GR482A.title: Study Abroad--Vietnam: Land Change Science and Remote Sensing
GR482A.description: Vietnam specific local case studies of land-use/land-cover changes in rural, peri-urban, and urban areas. Integrate these local cases as examples that relate to global cases looking at the drivers of land-use/land-cover changes. The broader implications of these changes are discussed, and examples of these implications are witnessed through field visits.

GR487.title: Internship
GR487.description: Academic-based work experience with selected organizations or agencies. Supervised application of principles of geography.

GR493.title: Capstone Seminar
GR493.description: Exploration of the linkages among the human and physical geography sub-fields, geographic techniques, and other natural and social sciences as well as how professional geographers approach issues.

GR548.title: Biogeography
GR548.description: Species distribution of plants and animals in relation to earth history and environments, evolution, and ecology.

GR592.title: Special Topics in Geography
GR592.description: Recent papers from the literature will be used to foster discussion among participants.

GEOL110.title: Introduction to Geology-Parks and Monuments (GT-SC2)
GEOL110.description: Understanding the physical processes, natural hazards, earth materials, and natural resources of planet Earth, and the relationship of humans to this planet. Outstanding examples of natural features from national and local parks and monuments, using narrated high-resolution (including aerial) video.

GEOL120.title: Exploring Earth - Physical Geology (GT-SC2)
GEOL120.description: Develops scientific understanding through introduction to earth processes, materials, resources, and hazards.

GEOL122.title: The Blue Planet - Geology of Our Environment (GT-SC2)
GEOL122.description: Develops scientific understanding through introduction to geological processes, natural hazards, earth resources, and their impacts on society.

GEOL124.title: Geology of Natural Resources (GT-SC2)
GEOL124.description: Develops scientific understanding through introduction to the origin, use and environmental impact of geological resources extracted from the Earth.

GEOL150.title: Physical Geology for Scientists and Engineers
GEOL150.description: Earth materials, structures, and surface processes. Geologic analysis using field data, topographic and geologic maps, and aerial photos.

GEOL154.title: Historical and Analytical Geology
GEOL154.description: Physical and biological history of Earth with introduction to laboratory, computer, and field techniques.

GEOL192.title: New Student Seminar--Exploring Geosciences
GEOL192.description: Geosciences as a field of study; exploration of the major and career paths; strategies for academic success and beyond.

GEOL201.title: Field Geology of the Colorado Front Range
GEOL201.description: Geology of the Rocky Mountain Front Range taught primarily through field trips and field exercises, emphasizing hands-on experiences. Learn to make basic field observations and measurements on a variety of rock types and surficial features.

GEOL232.title: Mineralogy
GEOL232.description: Crystal structures, crystal chemistry, rock-forming and economically important minerals, crystal growth and defects, physical properties of minerals.

GEOL250.title: The Solid Earth
GEOL250.description: Structure, flow, and composition of the deep Earth; introduction to geophysics; tests of plate tectonic theory.

GEOL332.title: Optical Mineralogy
GEOL332.description: Fundamental light optics in crystalline substances; optical indicatrix; isotropic, uniaxial, and biaxial substances; common minerals in thin section.

GEOL342.title: Paleontology
GEOL342.description: Description of invertebrates, vertebrates, and plants and their distribution in earth history.

GEOL344.title: Stratigraphy and Sedimentology
GEOL344.description: Description, genesis, correlation, and age of sediments, sedimentary rocks and layered rock sequences.

GEOL364.title: Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology
GEOL364.description: Identification, classification, geochemistry, petrogenesis of igneous and metamorphic rocks; textural interpretation of hand samples and thin sections.

GEOL366.title: Sedimentary Petrology and Geochemistry
GEOL366.description: Composition, identification, and classification of sedimentary rocks; geochemical processes affecting sedimentary rocks and surficial deposits.

GEOL372.title: Structural Geology
GEOL372.description: Stress and strain in rocks, geometry of deformed rocks, and tectonic principles.

GEOL376.title: Geologic Field Methods
GEOL376.description: Scientific, surveying, and mapping methods used in geologic field studies; proposal, map, and report preparation.

GEOL384.title: Supervised College Teaching
GEOL384.description: Instruction and practice in laboratory instruction in lower-division departmental courses.

GEOL401.title: Geology of the Rocky Mountain Region
GEOL401.description: Field course; geology of the local Rocky Mountain region.

GEOL436.title: Geology Summer Field Course
GEOL436.description: Geologic mapping, measuring sections, interpreting geologic history in Colorado. Required comprehensive reports, geologic maps, and cross sections.

GEOL442.title: Applied Geophysics
GEOL442.description: Geophysical exploration methods emphasizing hydrocarbon and mineral exploration, hydrogeology, and engineering applications.

GEOL447.title: Mineral Deposits
GEOL447.description: Occurrence, origin, and exploration of economic metallic mineral deposits.

GEOL452.title: Hydrogeology
GEOL452.description: Interaction of water and geologic materials; surface and groundwater; quantitative analysis and geologic effects on quality and flow of groundwater.

GEOL454.title: Geomorphology
GEOL454.description: Origin of landforms; morphology and processes.

GEOL530.title: Advanced Petrology
GEOL530.description: Igneous and metamorphic processes and products explored through thermodynamics, phase equilibria, and textural analysis.

GEOL535.title: Microtectonics
GEOL535.description: Focuses on microstructural features, processes, mechanisms, and measurements. Structurally interesting rocks especially on the microscale, development of structural fabrics and reactivation, analysis of fault rocks and kinematic indicators especially in fault and shear zones, stress measurement through microstructural indicators, shock deformation/metamorphism in impact structures, chemical changes with deformation, deformation mechanisms, and isotopic investigation of deformation.

GEOL540.title: Petrophysics and Well Log Interpretation
GEOL540.description: Petrophysics and well log interpretation as it relates to hydrocarbon exploration and production. Wireline logs, calculating rock and fluid properties from log measurements, and recognizing zones of potential hydrocarbons. Map and calculate volumes of hydrocarbons in the subsurface using the analysis of petrophysical properties from wireline well logs.

GEOL541.title: Geostatistics
GEOL541.description: Geostatistics for earth science applications. Aquifer and reservoir heterogeneity, spatial data analysis, variogram modeling, spatial estimation, kriging, and geostatistical simulation.

GEOL543.title: Carbonate Sedimentology
GEOL543.description: Recognition of carbonate grains, cement types, and carbonate depositional environments,  and their response to sea-level changes.

GEOL545.title: Shale Sedimentology
GEOL545.description: Recognize and interpret mud and mudstone facies and their depositional environments, as well as reconstructing their diagenetic history. Observe stacking patterns and reconstruct sea-level fluctuations from mudstone/shale successions and their impact on the 3D distribution of mudstones/shales.

GEOL546.title: Sedimentary Basin Analysis
GEOL546.description: Sedimentologic data base, correlation, mapping, facies models, classification, and evolution of sedimentary basins. Applications to petroleum exploration.

GEOL547.title: Ore Deposit Geochemistry
GEOL547.description: Geochemical techniques applied to the geology, exploration, and environmental analysis of ore deposits.

GEOL548.title: Petroleum Geology
GEOL548.description: Comprehensive treatment of the petroleum system with a focus on hydrocarbon exploration and production data and methods.

GEOL551.title: Groundwater Modeling
GEOL551.description: Groundwater modeling from a geologic perspective. Conceptual models and computer modeling of groundwater flow and solute transport.

GEOL552.title: Advanced Topics in Hydrogeology
GEOL552.description: Current literature, new techniques, legislative and political developments in hydrogeology, and appropriate case histories.

GEOL553.title: Use of Tracers in Hydrogeology
GEOL553.description: Use of environmental and applied tracers in hydrogeology to understand groundwater flow and transport properties. Environmental tracers are used to determine groundwater age and recharge rates, ground/water surface water interactions and to estimate the average temperature when the groundwater was recharged. Applied tracers are used to determine flow and transport processes in porous media to understand controls on solute transport, especially related to contaminant movement.

GEOL567.title: Sedimentary Geochemistry
GEOL567.description: Geochemical processes affecting sedimentary rocks and other surficial materials.

GEOL570.title: Plate Tectonics
GEOL570.description: Examination of the historical development of plate tectonic theory and its application to understanding geological processes.

GEOL572.title: Advanced Structural Geology
GEOL572.description: Rheology, deformation mechanisms, structural associations and advanced methods of structural analysis.

GEOL574.title: Geodynamics
GEOL574.description: Continuum mechanics applied to understanding of deformation within the earth. Stress and strain as tensors, with application to various geological settings; plate flexure and isostasy; steady state and time dependent heat conduction in a geological context; fluid mechanics of the earth.

GEOL575.title: Subsurface Geophysical Mapping
GEOL575.description: Advanced techniques for creating subsurface geological maps based on seismic reflection and well log data.

GEOL576.title: Exploration Seismology
GEOL576.description: Seismic exploration methods, including theory, data acquisition, and data processing.

GEOL578.title: Global Seismology
GEOL578.description: Quantitative introduction to seismology; basics of seismic data analysis; fundamentals of wave propagation; earthquakes; structure of the Earth.

GEOL579.title: Solid Earth Inverse Methods and Practices
GEOL579.description: Inverse and parameter estimation theory and applications in the earth sciences in the context of Frequentist and Bayesian approaches to estimating and interpreting data-driven models. Review of linear algebra, statistical, and other mathematical underpinnings, and of basic MATLAB programming. Linear and nonlinear inverse problems. Nonuniqueness, ill-posedness, rank-deficiency. Regularization methods for geophysical problems.

GEOL601.title: Professional Development for Geoscientists
GEOL601.description: The conduct of science, role of scientific publications, publication process, proposal writing, responsible conduct of research, and professional ethics.

GEOL652.title: Fluvial Geomorphology
GEOL652.description: Geomorphology of channels, slopes, and drainage systems.

GEOL662.title: Field Geomorphology
GEOL662.description: Field-based geomorphologic analysis of landscape forms and processes. Apply appropriate field techniques to address relevant research hypotheses related to advanced subject matter in geomorphology. Analyze and interpret field-based data, orally present findings in a symposium setting, and discuss and critically evaluate relevant literature.

GES101.title: Foundations of Environmental Sustainability
GES101.description: Concepts, foundations, and metrics of global environmental sustainability applied to global challenges.

GES120.title: Water Sustainability in the Western US
GES120.description: Water and the sustainability of its use in the West. Historical perspectives on the development of water resources in the West. Exploration of the issues involved in meeting the needs for water by people, agriculture and wildlife. Impacts of important human and natural influences on the use and sustainability of water supplies in the West.

GES130.title: Introduction to Sustainability Engagement
GES130.description: Introduction to sustainability engagement via experiential learning.

GES135.title: Applied Community Sustainability
GES135.description: Engaging with communities on real projects, teams of students develop workable solutions to problems related to food security, green infrastructure, urban wildlife conservation, and other sustainability topics. This course will be fully integrated with a writing course providing a complementary emphasis on values, ethics, meaning, critical thinking, writing, and speaking.

GES141.title: Introduction to Sustainable Energy
GES141.description: Fossil, nuclear, and renewable energy sources. Energy conversion, distribution, and storage. Energy and the environment. Energy economics and policy.

GES192.title: Global Environmental Sustainability Seminar
GES192.description: This seminar introduces students to methods, practices, and ways of knowing in the disciplines represented in this multi-disciplinary field of study.

GES330A.title: Sustainability in Practice: Project
GES330A.description: Engages students in real-world sustainability applications and empowers them to design and execute their own program or research project. A) Project. B) Service Learning.

GES330B.title: Sustainability in Practice: Service Learning
GES330B.description: Engages students in real-world sustainability applications and empowers them to design and execute their own program or research project. A) Project. B) Service Learning.

GES441.title: Analysis of Sustainable Energy Solutions
GES441.description: Methods of evaluating sustainable energy technologies, including life cycle assessment, energy return on investment, technoeconomic analysis, and political ecology.

GES450.title: Global Sustainability and Health
GES450.description: Impact of anthropogenic environmental change on human, animal and environmental health.

GES460.title: Law and Sustainability
GES460.description: Introduction to the domestic and international laws that influence and interact with the implementation of sustainability in the U.S. and abroad.

GES470.title: Applications of Environmental Sustainability
GES470.description: Integration of the dimensions of global environmental sustainability--environment, society, and economy--through case studies and team project.

GES520.title: Issues in Global Environmental Sustainability
GES520.description: Analysis of the different major dimensions/definitions of sustainability in current issues involving environmental, social and economic systems.

GES542.title: Biobased Fuels, Energy, and Chemicals
GES542.description: Science and engineering aspects of biobased fuel, energy, and chemical  production, including plant biology, thermochemical conversion, biomass deconstruction, fermentation, and biofuel properties. Aspects of sustainable production and economics will be discussed.

GRAD510.title: Fundamentals of High Performance Computing
GRAD510.description: UNIX; networks; scalar, vector, and parallel architectures; performance programming.

GRAD511.title: High Performance Computing and Visualization
GRAD511.description: Iterative methods for linear systems; Monte Carlo methods; visualization and image processing.

GRAD544.title: Ethical Conduct of Research
GRAD544.description: Principles and practice of ethical conduct of research.

GRAD550.title: STEM Communication
GRAD550.description: Review and practice of key communication principles for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) professionals.

GRAD575.title: Ethical Issues in Big Data Research

GRAD592.title: Water Resources Seminar
GRAD592.description: Interdisciplinary seminar emphasizing issues important to water resources community. Content relates to a preselected theme each semester.

GRAD792.title: Seminar on College Teaching
GRAD792.description: Role of college teacher emphasizing applied principles and practices derived from empirical research and collective experience of teaching professors.

AHS487.title: Internship in Human Services
AHS487.description: Application of skills learned in interdisciplinary program or major to a variety of human service settings.

HES100A.title: Beginning Physical Education: Aerobic Exercise
HES100A.description: Physical activities for the development of personal motor skills.

HES100J.title: Beginning Physical Education: Volleyball
HES100J.description: Physical activities for the development of personal motor skills.

HES100M.title: Beginning Physical Education: Basketball
HES100M.description: Physical activities for the development of personal motor skills.

HES100N.title: Beginning Physical Education: Racquetball
HES100N.description: Physical activities for the development of personal motor skills.

HES100O.title: Beginning Physical Education: Weight Training
HES100O.description: Physical activities for the development of personal motor skills.

HES102C.title: Physical Education Activities: Special Activities
HES102C.description: Physical activities for the development of personal motor skills.

HES102F.title: Physical Education Activities: Conditioning and Fitness
HES102F.description: Physical activities for the development of personal motor skills.

HES102G.title: Physical Education Activities: Athletics
HES102G.description: Physical activities for the development of personal motor skills.

HES120.title: Introduction to Health and Exercise Science
HES120.description: Health and Exercise Science major, career options, campus resources, tools for academic success, various health-related topics.

HES145.title: Health and Wellness
HES145.description: Personal health behaviors and personal choice in response to wellness.

HES207.title: Anatomical Kinesiology
HES207.description: Anatomical, physiological, and mechanical fundamentals of human movement.

HES232.title: Techniques of Teaching Group Exercise
HES232.description: Learn practical skills for the instruction of various group fitness activities. Emphasis is on physiological principles related to group fitness, as well as choreography, safety, and modifications for diverse populations and current trends.

HES232A.title: Techniques of Teaching Physical Activity: Weight Training
HES232A.description: Practical and theoretical aspects of teaching individual sports with special emphasis on materials, teaching techniques, and analyzing skills.

HES240.title: First Aid and Emergency Care
HES240.description: Principles, applied techniques emphasizing emergency rescue and care. Meets requirements for Red Cross Advanced First Aid and Emergency Care Credential.

HES303.title: Biomechanics and Neurophysiology
HES303.description: Study and elementary analysis of human motion based on anatomical, neurophysiological, and mechanical principles.

HES307.title: Biomechanical Principles of Human Movement
HES307.description: Study and elementary analysis of human motion based on anatomical and mechanical principles.

HES309.title: Methods of Coaching
HES309.description: Preparation to coach in an interscholastic athletic situation.

HES319.title: Neuromuscular Aspects of Human Movement
HES319.description: Neuromuscular anatomy and physiology of human movement. Applied/integrated topics: aging, muscle fatigue, training, force control, and neuromuscular disease.

HES340.title: Exercise Prescription
HES340.description: Theory and practice of exercise prescription for healthy individuals, cardiac patients, and other special populations according to the American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) guidelines. Includes the practice of proper lifting and spotting techniques, manipulation of training variables, and design of safe, effective, and efficient individual workout programs.

HES345.title: Population Health and Disease Prevention
HES345.description: Causes of disease throughout the lifespan and interventions designed to prevent disease.

HES354.title: Theory of Health Behavior
HES354.description: Health behavior (HB) theories and their application to health promotion (HP) programs. Multi-level factors that interactively impact human HBs, theoretical foundations for these factors, and the relationship between HBs & selected health outcomes.
