Discuss application of HB theories, and examine HP programs that have applied these theories in different settings and high risk populations.

HES355.title: Integration of Health Behaviors
HES355.description: Designed to guide students in applying their knowledge of health behavior change to individuals with various health challenges. Explores a variety of health topics including understanding stress and coping and managing stress, behavioral factors in chronic disease, and behavioral health.

HES379.title: Psychology and Sport
HES379.description: Reciprocal relationship between psychological factors and sport and exercise behavior.

HES403.title: Physiology of Exercise
HES403.description: Effects of exercise on tissues, organs, and systems of the body.

HES410.title: Bioethics: Concepts and Controversies
HES410.description: Origins of bioethics and analysis of cases/controversies in contemporary bioethics.

HES420.title: Electrocardiography and Exercise Management
HES420.description: Interpretation of 12-lead ECG tracings, administering exercise tests, and prescribing exercise program for healthy individuals and special populations.

HES434.title: Physical Activity Throughout the Lifespan
HES434.description: Impact of physical activity on biology and physiology of human development and aging processes.

HES444.title: Successful Aging: Role of Physical Activity
HES444.description: Biology and physiology of healthy aging and impact of disease and physical activity on aging processes.

HES455.title: Health Promotion Programming
HES455.description: Investigation of established health promotion programs with special emphasis on design, implementation, and evaluation of programming models.

HES476.title: Exercise and Chronic Disease
HES476.description: Interaction of physical activity with pathophysiology  and treatment of chronic diseases and conditions.

HES478A.title: Sports Medicine Capstone: Seminar
HES478A.description: Integration and reflection on health and exercise science disciplinary knowledge.

HES478B.title: Sports Medicine Capstone: Research
HES478B.description: A capstone experience that provides an opportunity to be involved with research in health and exercise science.

HES478C.title: Sports Medicine Capstone: Teaching
HES478C.description: A capstone course that provides an opportunity to be involved with instruction of a course in Health and Exercise Science.

HES478D.title: Sports Medicine Capstone: Service Learning
HES478D.description: A capstone experience that provides an opportunity to be involved with a service-learning project in the community that applies knowledge of Health and Exercise Science.

HES487.title: Internship
HES487.description: Practical application of knowledge, skills, and leadership in a professional situation.

HES492.title: Health and Exercise Science Seminar
HES492.description: Integration and reflection on health and exercise science disciplinary knowledge.

HES500.title: Environmental Exercise Physiology
HES500.description: Enhance the understanding of human physiology and how the various physiological systems respond to environmental stressors. Integrate previous knowledge of human physiology and apply it to the physiological response to heat stress, cold stress, hyperbaric atmosphere, hypobaric atmosphere, pollution, and sleep deprivation.

HES520.title: Advanced Exercise Testing and Prescription
HES520.description: Theory and practice of exercise testing and prescription in apparently healthy and diseased populations.

HES530.title: Clinical Biomechanics
HES530.description: Effect of external loads on internal tissues; concern for injury, injury prevention, and rehabilitation.

HES531.title: Muscle and Joint Mechanics
HES531.description: Integrate muscle, tendon, and location of bone attachment into a comprehensive understanding of human movement at the single- and multi-joint level.

HES545.title: Evolutionary Basis for Health and Fitness
HES545.description: Evolutionary basis for human health and fitness based upon dietary and exercise patterns for pre-agricultural humans.

HES556.title: Wellness and Health Promotion Concepts
HES556.description: Discussion of theory and application of health promotion in various settings.

HES600.title: Research Design in Health/Exercise Science
HES600.description: The research process including design, implementation, proposal synthesis and statistical considerations applied to health and exercise science.

HES602.title: Advanced Physiology of Exercise
HES602.description: Integrative exercise physiology covering metabolism, cardiovascular physiology, pulmonary physiology, and neuromuscular physiology in humans.

HES603.title: Advanced Topics in Exercise Physiology
HES603.description: Advanced principles of theoretical and applied exercise physiology at molecular, cellular, and systemic levels.

HES610.title: Exercise Bioenergetics
HES610.description: Biology of energy transfer reactions related to human locomotion and exercise performance in both healthy individuals and disease states.

HES619.title: Advanced Neural Control of Movement
HES619.description: Neuroanatomical, neurophysiological, and applied topics on the control of force and human movement.

HES620.title: The Science of Healthspan
HES620.description: A multidisciplinary approach to examining important biomedical topics in healthy aging. Covers topics in the field of biomedical research on healthy aging including: lifespan, healthspan, disease, interventions for maintaining health across the lifespan, and the biology, physiology and sociology of aging, from molecular events to clinical and population function.

HES645.title: Epidemiology of Health and Physical Activity
HES645.description: Foundation in chronic disease epidemiology that will enable students to evaluate the current epidemiologic literature.

HES650.title: Health Promotion Programming
HES650.description: Development of skills in health promotion program design, implementation and evaluation.

HES656.title: Comprehensive Stress Management
HES656.description: Relationship between stress and illness emphasizing methods to impact its detrimental effects.

HES686A.title: Practicum: Adult Fitness-Human Performance Clinical/Research Laboratory

HES686C.title: Practicum: Youth Fitness and Skill Development

HES686D.title: Practicum: Health and Exercise Science Research

HES686E.title: Practicum: Applied Health and Exercise Science

HES687.title: Internship
HES687.description: Practical application of knowledge and skills in a professional situation.

HES692.title: Seminar
HES692.description: Consideration of graduate education in health and exercise science.

HES693.title: Seminar
HES693.description: Current topics and issues in health and exercise science.

HES698.title: Research
HES698.description: Non-thesis research in health and exercise science.

HES700.title: Professional Skills in Bioenergetics
HES700.description: Grant writing, authorship, peer review process, responsible conduct of science, research ethics, professional conduct, career opportunities.

HES704A.title: Advanced Topics in Bioenergetics: Movement
HES704A.description: Advanced topics in physiology, biochemistry, biomechanics, and neural control exploring pathogenesis and treatment of chronic disease.

HES704B.title: Advanced Topics in Bioenergetics: Physiology
HES704B.description: Advanced topics in physiology, biochemistry, biomechanics, and neural control exploring pathogenesis and treatment of chronic disease.

HES710.title: Exercise in Disease Prevention
HES710.description: Role of exercise/physical activity in the prevention, pathophysiology and treatment of chronic diseases.

HES735.title: Human Cardiovascular Control
HES735.description: Dynamics of cardiovascular control in human health and disease.

HIST100.title: Western Civilization, Pre-Modern (GT-HI1)
HIST100.description: Historical development of Western civilization from antiquity to the early modern era (c. 1600 C.E.)

HIST101.title: Western Civilization, Modern (GT-HI1)
HIST101.description: Historical development of Western civilization from c. 1600 C.E. to the contemporary era.

HIST115.title: The Islamic World: Late Antiquity to 1500
HIST115.description: Religion, society, and culture in the Islamic world from late antiquity to the Ottoman conquest of Constantinople and the Reconquista in Spain.

HIST116.title: The Islamic World Since 1500
HIST116.description: Religion, society, and culture in the Islamic world since 1500.

HIST120.title: Asian Civilizations I (GT-HI1)
HIST120.description: Major traditional intellectual and cultural patterns of Asia during the formative years.

HIST121.title: Asian Civilizations II (GT-HI1)
HIST121.description: Transformation of major intellectual and cultural patterns and the process of globalization in modern Asia.

HIST150.title: U.S. History to 1876 (GT-HI1)
HIST150.description: Major issues and themes in the early invasion of North America and the United States from the colonial period through Reconstruction.

HIST151.title: U.S. History Since 1876 (GT-HI1)
HIST151.description: Major issues and themes in the historical development of the United States since Reconstruction.

HIST170.title: World History, Ancient-1500 (GT-HI1)
HIST170.description: Historical developments and interactions of world societies from the ancient to modern periods.

HIST171.title: World History, 1500-Present (GT-HI1)
HIST171.description: Historical developments and interactions of world societies from 1500 to the present.

HIST201.title: Seminar – Approaches to History
HIST201.description: Introduces students to professional historical skills including research methods, citation, and writing via intensive investigation of a historical time period or theme. Topic varies by instructor.

HIST300.title: Ancient Greece to 323 B.C.E.
HIST300.description: From the Bronze Age to the death of Alexander the Great, emphasizing political, social, intellectual, and cultural developments.

HIST301.title: Roman Republic
HIST301.description: Roman history from the monarchy to the fall of the republic; special emphasis on political, cultural, and social history.

HIST302.title: Roman Empire
HIST302.description: Roman history from the principate of Augustus to the reign of Constantine; special emphasis on political, intellectual, cultural, and social history.

HIST303.title: Hellenistic World: Alexander to Cleopatra
HIST303.description: From Alexander the Great to Cleopatra VII, emphasizing intellectual, social, military, political, and cultural developments.

HIST304.title: Women in Ancient Greece and Rome
HIST304.description: Comparative study of roles of women and gender in Ancient Greece and Rome.

HIST308.title: Ancient Christianity to 500 A.D.
HIST308.description: Growth of Christian Church from 1st to 5th century; emphasis on its role in Roman Empire; development of ecclesiastical institutions and literature.

HIST309.title: Medieval Christianity, 500-1500
HIST309.description: Christian Church in Eastern and Western Christendom emphasizing its role in medieval society, relationship with the state, and its institutions.

HIST310.title: Medieval Europe
HIST310.description: Political, legal, socioeconomic development of Europe from 300-1500 emphasizing emergence of major states.

HIST311.title: Medieval England
HIST311.description: Political, social, and intellectual development of England from Romans to end of Middle Ages.

HIST312.title: Women in Medieval Europe
HIST312.description: Women in the European Middle Ages; political, social, economic, religious, and cultural developments.

HIST315.title: Tudor Stuart England, 1485-1689
HIST315.description: Political, economic, and social history of England from 1485-1689 emphasizing religious movements, revolution, and constitutional development.

HIST317.title: Renaissance and Reformation Europe
HIST317.description: Development of European society during Renaissance and Reformation eras; religion, society, and the rise of nation-states.

HIST318.title: The Age of the Enlightenment
HIST318.description: Development of European society from settlement of religious wars to French Revolution emphasizing political, economic, and intellectual trends.

HIST319.title: Early Modern France, 1500-1789
HIST319.description: Political, social, economic, religious, and cultural developments in France (16th-18th centuries) emphasizing formation of the absolutist state.

HIST320.title: Women and Gender in Europe, 1450-1789
HIST320.description: Women and gender in western Europe (15th-18th centuries); political, social, economic, religious, and cultural developments.

HIST321.title: Industrial Society in Europe, 1600-1871
HIST321.description: Causes and consequences of European industrialization and its impact on European Societies between 1600 and 1871.

HIST322.title: Industrial Society in Europe, 1871-1989
HIST322.description: Causes and consequences of industrialization and its impact on European societies between 1871 and 1989.

HIST323.title: Russia Before 1700
HIST323.description: Russia's political predecessors; contacts with Byzantium, Western Europe, and the Mongol Empire, and resulting cultural, religious, and social change.

HIST324.title: Imperial Russia
HIST324.description: Tsarist Russia from its beginnings to the November 1917 Revolution; emphasis on modern period.

HIST325.title: Ireland: Culture, Politics, Society and Nation
HIST325.description: Creation of modern Ireland from the 18th century to the present, with brief opening overview of the Celtic and Medieval periods.

HIST328.title: Modern Europe, 1815-1914
HIST328.description: Europe in 19th century emphasizing growth of liberalism, nationalism, and industrialism.

HIST329.title: Europe in Crisis, 1914-1941
HIST329.description: Political, social, economic developments since 1914; consequences of world wars, Great Depression, spread of totalitarianism, decline of imperialism.

HIST330.title: Eastern Europe Since 1918
HIST330.description: Breakup of Austrian, German, Russian, Turkish Empires; successor states between wars; communist revolutions and character of East European socialist regimes.

HIST331.title: The Soviet Union
HIST331.description: Formation of Soviet system in 1918 to its demise in 1991 emphasizing emergence of an advanced socialist state.

HIST332.title: Germany Since World War I
HIST332.description: German history, culture, and everyday life from 1914 to present.

HIST333.title: Contemporary Europe
HIST333.description: Political, economic, social, and cultural history of major European nations since World War II.

HIST334.title: European Culture in the 20th Century
HIST334.description: Cultural developments since World War I emphasizing science, art, clash of ideologies, existentialism, youth culture, and environmental issues.

HIST335.title: Britain in the 20th Century
HIST335.description: Political, economic, and social developments emphasizing role of Britain in world affairs and internal changes that led to welfare state.

HIST336.title: Germany from Napoleon to WWI
HIST336.description: Modern Germany from the late eighteenth to the early twentieth centuries.

HIST338.title: The Holocaust in Historical Perspective
HIST338.description: Comprehensive introduction to the Holocaust as a defining event of modern Jewish, European and world history. Strong emphasis on historical context, including the evolution of modern antisemitism and the rise of fascism. While the course will focus on Hitler’s singular war against European Jewry, it also examines Nazi campaigns against other targeted populations, including the disabled, Roma/Sinti, homosexuals, communists, Jehovah's Witnesses, and others.

HIST339.title: World War II in Europe
HIST339.description: WWII in Europe (1939-1945): military strategy, tactics; political and diplomatic events; economic and social impacts; ethnic and gender consequences.

HIST340.title: Colonial American Borderlands--1492-1800
HIST340.description: New World encounters between Native Americans, Europeans, and Africans, and the colonial societies they built.

HIST341.title: Empire, Race, Revolution--America 1700-1815
HIST341.description: Politics, culture, and society in Colonial British America and the new United States, 1700-1815.

HIST344.title: Antebellum America
HIST344.description: National growth, 1800 to 1860, emphasizing political, social, and economic developments.

HIST345.title: Civil War Era
HIST345.description: U.S. history between 1848 and 1865 emphasizing causes and results of the Civil War.

HIST346.title: Reconstruction and the New South
HIST346.description: Reconstruction Era, 1865-1877, and the South to present with emphasis on purposes and results of Reconstruction.

HIST347.title: United States, 1876-1917
HIST347.description: Victorian way of life; rise of industry; reform movements; imperialism; World War I.

HIST348.title: United States, 1917-1945
HIST348.description: World War I, the 1920s, the Great Depression, and World War II.

HIST349.title: United States Since 1945
HIST349.description: History of the United States during the post-World War II era, including the Cold War, foreign and domestic affairs from the Truman era to the present.

HIST350.title: United States Foreign Relations Since 1914
HIST350.description: Main problems in U.S. foreign relations in the 20th century; especially causes and consequences of the two world wars, Great Depression and the Cold War.

HIST351.title: American West to 1900
HIST351.description: Social, political, economic, environmental developments and intercultural relations in trans-Mississippi West to 1900.

HIST352.title: American West Since 1900
HIST352.description: Social, political, economic, environmental developments and intercultural relationships in trans-Mississippi West since 1900.

HIST353.title: U.S.-Mexico Borderlands
HIST353.description: Borderlands, northern Mexico, southwestern U.S.; intercultural relationships among Indian, Spanish, Mexican, U.S. cultures.

HIST354.title: American Architectural History
HIST354.description: Broad historical interpretation of the North American built environment from 1500 to present.

HIST355.title: American Environmental History
HIST355.description: Interaction of humans and nature in American history with emphasis on relationships between environmental, social, and cultural change.

HIST356.title: American Cultural and Intellectual History
HIST356.description: Role of American cultural and intellectual developments in American society and the world.

HIST358.title: American Women's History to 1800
HIST358.description: History of Indian, African, and European women in North America from early colonial contact through the American Revolution and into Early Republic.

HIST359.title: American Women's History Since 1800
HIST359.description: Social, cultural, economic, and political history of women in the United States since 1800.

HIST360.title: United States Immigration History
HIST360.description: Central themes of U.S. immigration from perspective of major immigrant groups and within context of U.S. immigration policy.

HIST361.title: American Indians in the Age of Conquest
HIST361.description: American Indian history from pre-contact to the era of Indian removal (1840s) focused on the impact of colonization.

HIST362.title: American Indian Renaissance in Modern America
HIST362.description: American Indian history from the reservation era to the present with a focus on cultural and political renewal.

HIST363.title: Colorado History
HIST363.description: History of Colorado from pre-history to present.

HIST365.title: American West Field Study
HIST365.description: Explore western U.S. history through primary sources and field trips to sites in Colorado and the West. Topic varies by semester and instructor.

HIST366.title: African-American History to 1865
HIST366.description: African-American history from the colonial era to the end of the Civil War.

HIST367.title: African-American History Since 1865
HIST367.description: African-American history from the end of the Civil War to the late twentieth century.

HIST368.title: The American South
HIST368.description: The American South, 1607 to the present; plantation system, slave culture, secession, Civil War, Reconstruction, Jim Crow, Civil Rights, and the modern South.

HIST369.title: History of Sexuality in America
HIST369.description: History of sexuality in North America and the United States from the pre-colonial period to the present.

HIST370.title: United States History Through Film
HIST370.description: Examining American history through the medium of film with an emphasis on changing depictions of critical events and people. Strong emphasis on historical context, including how changing social, political, cultural, and environmental ideas and practices shaped the production and consumption of film.

HIST370C.title: Study Abroad--South Korea: Cinema, Culture, and History

HIST371.title: Civil Rights in America
HIST371.description: A survey of the various civil rights movements in American history, including the efforts of African Americans, women, Chicanos, Native Americans, and the LGBTQ community to gain equality.

HIST379.title: Economic History of the United States

HIST382B.title: Study Abroad: The Normandy Campaign
HIST382B.description: Study abroad experience focused on understanding WWII in Europe, specifically the Normandy Campaign and its implications for the western front.

HIST382C.title: Study Abroad - South Korea: Cinema, Culture, and History
HIST382C.description: A survey of post-1945 South Korean cinema from Golden Age classics of the 1950s and 1960s to the rise of new blockbuster hits and art-house films throughout the contemporary period. Cinematic texts are examined within various historical, sociopolitical, and cultural contexts of postcolonial South Korea, with attention to the issues of Japanese colonialism, national division, civil war, U.S. neocolonialism, military dictatorships, the democratic movement, and globalization.

HIST382E.title: Study Abroad--Rome: Roman History
HIST382E.description: Develop an understanding of Roman history, specifically from the collapse of the Republic through the 4th century AD.

HIST410.title: Colonial Latin America
HIST410.description: Spanish and Portuguese America from pre-Columbian times through independence (c. 1825).

HIST411.title: Latin America Since Independence
HIST411.description: Major trends in the social, cultural, political, and economic evolution of Spanish America and Brazil since independence.

HIST412.title: Mexico
HIST412.description: Social, economic, and political development of Mexican people from pre-Columbian times to present.

HIST414.title: Revolutions in Latin America
HIST414.description: Historical and theoretical issues arising from revolutionary episodes in Latin America, with emphasis on 20th century case studies.

HIST415.title: Study Abroad--Mexico: History, Community, and Environment in Mexico
HIST415.description: Explore history, identity, community, and human relationships to the environment in Baja California Sur, Mexico. Employ the analytic frameworks and tools of public history and environmental history with particular emphasis on oral history methodologies.

HIST420.title: Africa: Precolonial States and Empires
HIST420.description: Origins of societal and political development in Africa before 1800; technology, the environment, human migrations, and trade.

HIST421.title: Africa: Colonialism to Independence
HIST421.description: Africa from abolition of the slave trade to independence, focusing on economic, social, and political change under colonialism.

HIST422.title: Modern Africa
HIST422.description: Colonial roots of modern Africa focusing on the period since 1935. Case studies of social and political change in Africa since World War II.

HIST423.title: South African History
HIST423.description: South African history from human origins to the end of Apartheid.

HIST424.title: East African History
HIST424.description: Overview of East African history from human origins to modern times, focusing on Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda.

HIST430.title: Ancient Near East
HIST430.description: Neolithic period to 500 B.C.E. emphasizing political, social, intellectual, and cultural developments.

HIST431.title: Ancient Israel
HIST431.description: Ancient Israel and the Near Eastern world of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament.

HIST432.title: Sacred History in the Bible and the Qur'an
HIST432.description: Conceptions of sacred history in the Biblical and Qur'anic traditions, emphasizing pre-modern historiography and exegesis.

HIST433.title: Muhammad and the Origins of Islam
HIST433.description: Emergence of Islam and growth of the Islamic community from time of Muhammad to decline of the Arab Caliphate.

HIST435.title: Jihad and Reform in Islamic History
HIST435.description: Jihad and reform in classical and modern Islamic thought and practice.

HIST436.title: The Land of Israel-Past and Present
HIST436.description: Diverse physical geography, rich material culture, and complex history of the land of Israel--ancient, medieval, and modern.

HIST438.title: The Modern Middle East
HIST438.description: Historical developments in the Middle East in the 19th and 20th centuries.

HIST439.title: Environmental History of the Middle East
HIST439.description: Explores the social, political, and ecological consequences of past human interactions with the environment in the Middle East and North Africa.

HIST440.title: Modern South Asia: Colonialism and Nationalism
HIST440.description: Major political, social, economic, and cultural developments in South Asia from the 17th century to the present.

HIST441.title: South Asia Since Independence
HIST441.description: Major political, social, economic, and cultural developments in South Asia after independence.

HIST450.title: Ancient China
HIST450.description: Development of civilizations in China from Neolithic times to 200 B.C.E.

HIST451.title: Medieval China and Central Asia
HIST451.description: Historical developments in China and Central Asia from 200 B.C.E. to 1300 C.E.

HIST455.title: Tokugawa and Modern Japan, 1600-Present
HIST455.description: Focus on issues related to Japan’s historical developments in “feudalism,” Confucianism, constitutionalism, imperialism, liberalism, socialism, fascism, totalitarianism, militarism, democracy, capitalism, and post–modernism. Contemporary issues related to war, peace, and Japan’s international role are also discussed.

HIST456.title: East Asia in the Age of Empire, 1800-Present
HIST456.description: Rise of modern imperialism in East Asia, both from without (the "West") and from within (Japan), 1800-present.

HIST460.title: Slavery in the Americas
HIST460.description: Slave labor; Atlantic world economy; African contributions to American culture; gender and racial dynamics; emancipation movements.

HIST461.title: Rise and Fall of British Empire 1600-1947
HIST461.description: Beginnings of globalization; its origins in the spread of the British Empire; major causes of expansion, forms of control, long-term effects.

HIST463.title: Science and Technology in Modern History
HIST463.description: Impact of science and technology on industry, agriculture, medicine, education, etc. Issues in science and technology policy.

HIST464.title: Pacific Wars: Philippines-WWII
HIST464.description: Diplomatic, ideological, political, cultural, and military aspects of war in the Pacific from the Philippines war through WWII.

HIST465.title: Pacific Wars: Korea and Vietnam
HIST465.description: Diplomatic, ideological, political, cultural, and military aspects of war in the Pacific from the war in Korea through the war in Vietnam.

HIST466.title: U.S.-China Relations Since 1800
HIST466.description: United States-China relations as represented in travel narratives, memoirs, journalistic and diplomatic writing, biography, and autobiography.

HIST467.title: Modern Jewish History
HIST467.description: Political, social, cultural, and economic dimensions of modern Jewish history from both a regional and global perspective.

HIST469.title: The Crusades
HIST469.description: The Crusades, emphasizing religion, politics, and warfare in Western Europe, Byzantium, the Near East, and the Mongol world empire, c. 1050-1300.

HIST470.title: World Environmental History, 1500-Present
HIST470.description: World environmental history since 1500, emphasizing the dynamic interaction of nature, culture, and human activity.

HIST471.title: History of Antarctica, 1800-Present
HIST471.description: History of Antarctica from discovery in the early nineteenth century to the present.

HIST472A.title: Study Abroad: WWII in Europe - The Normandy Campaign
HIST472A.description: Focuses on understanding World War II in Europe, specifically the Normandy Campaign and its implications for the western front. The class travels to England, crosses the English Channel, tours the D-Day invasion beaches along the French coast, and then travels to Paris. Also, visit cultural sites in both London and Paris.

HIST475.title: Methods in Digital History
HIST475.description: Digital history theory and practice as part of the historical discipline and the larger digital humanities landscape.

HIST476.title: History of America's National Parks
HIST476.description: The national park system and its development from concept to design to implementation.

HIST477.title: Teaching History
HIST477.description: Teaching history, emphasizing teaching historical literacy, research, and writing at the middle and high school levels.

HIST479.title: Practice of Public History
HIST479.description: Public history methods and career paths into interpretation, museums, archives, historic preservation, oral history, and other fields.

HIST484.title: Supervised College Teaching
HIST484.description: Assisting the instructor in teaching introductory history courses; relevant readings and discussions.

HIST487.title: Internship
HIST487.description: Application of historical methods in museums, libraries, and at historic sites.

HIST492.title: Capstone Seminar
HIST492.description: Seminar involving critical reading, writing, research, and discussion. Topics vary by instructor.

HIST501.title: Historical Method: Historiography
HIST501.description: Historiographical skills and methods, emphasis on research, writing, and interpretation.

HIST502.title: Historical Method: Archives
HIST502.description: Historiographical skills and methods; emphasis on fundamentals of archival science.

HIST503.title: Historical Method: Preservation
HIST503.description: Historiographical skills and methods; emphasis on theory and practice of historic preservation.

HIST504.title: Historical Method: Museums
HIST504.description: Historiographical skills and methods; emphasis on philosophy and practices of history museums.

HIST505.title: Historical Method - Digital History
HIST505.description: Historiographical skills and methods; emphasis on theory and practice of digital history.

HIST511.title: Reading Seminar: U.S. to 1877
HIST511.description: Readings on United States history to 1877.

HIST512.title: Reading Seminar: U.S. Since 1877
HIST512.description: Readings on United States history since 1877.

HIST515.title: Records Management
HIST515.description: Basic records management techniques and concepts such as retention, vital records, disaster planning, and electronic records.

HIST530.title: Reading Seminar: Africa
HIST530.description: Readings on major historiographical issues in African history.

HIST531.title: Reading Seminar: Latin America
HIST531.description: Readings on major historiographical issues in Latin American history.

HIST532.title: Reading Seminar: Middle East
HIST532.description: Readings on major historiographical issues in Middle East history.

HIST533.title: Reading Seminar: East Asia
HIST533.description: Readings on major historiographical issues in East Asian history.

HIST534.title: Reading Seminar: South Asia
HIST534.description: Major historiographical issues in South Asian history.

HIST539.title: Reading Seminar--World Environmental History
HIST539.description: Major works in the field of world environmental history and the major historiographical debates.

HIST540.title: Material Culture
HIST540.description: Social, cultural, economic, and political developments in history as interpreted through artifacts.

HIST587.title: Internship
HIST587.description: Work-oriented instruction involving implementation of classroom and laboratory experiences coordinated by a faculty member.

HIST640.title: Research Seminar: State and Local History
HIST640.description: Research in and interpretation of state and local history within the broader context of United States history.

HIST684.title: Supervised College Teaching
HIST684.description: Discussions and readings to enhance teaching proficiency.

HONR192.title: Honors First Year Seminar
HONR192.description: Humanistic and scientific studies; emphasis on literate activities, written communication; student development and transition to university life.

HONR193.title: Honors Seminar
HONR193.description: Humanistic and scientific studies with emphasis on rigorous literate activities, especially written communication.

HONR197.title: General Honors Colloquium
HONR197.description: Students from all major fields meet in small groups to focus on a problem of concern to all.

HONR292A.title: Honors Seminar: Knowing in the Sciences
HONR292A.description: Exploration of science as a way of knowing. What counts as scientific knowledge; methods employed to gain or affirm scientific knowledge; values attributed to scientific knowledge; and ethical and aesthetic implications of what one gains and does with the acquisition of knowledge. Integrates history and philosophy of science with content of, and approaches used, in a scientific discipline in discussions.

HONR292B.title: Honors Seminar: Knowing in Arts and Humanities (GT-AH2)
HONR292B.description: Knowledge systems and the human experience. Ways of knowing in the arts and humanities.

HONR292C.title: Honors Seminar: Knowing Across Cultures (GT-SS3)
HONR292C.description: Identities, social contexts, global relations, and knowledge systems. Ways of knowing across cultures.

HONR392.title: Honors Seminar
HONR392.description: Various topics in humanistic and scientific studies.

HONR397.title: General Honors Colloquium
HONR397.description: Students from all major fields meet in small groups to focus on a problem of concern to all.

HONR492.title: Honors Senior Seminar
HONR492.description: Variable topics on humanistic and scientific studies.

HONR495.title: Independent Study
HONR495.description: Individual projects developed by the student and the major adviser at the upper-division level but which transcends basic course content.

HORT100.title: Horticultural Science
HORT100.description: Principles of plant science and related disciplines as the base and context for the introduction of horticultural practices.

HORT221.title: Landscape Plants
HORT221.description: Identification, landscape features, cultural requirements, and landscape use of coniferous and deciduous trees and shrubs, vines, and evergreens.

HORT231.title: Landscape Graphics Studio
HORT231.description: Mechanical and freehand graphic techniques for landscape design. Use of pencil, ink, and colored markers. Plan, sectional, and perspective views.

HORT232.title: Principles of Landscape Design
HORT232.description: Basic concepts in the art and process of landscape design.

HORT260.title: Plant Propagation
HORT260.description: Theories, principles, and techniques of sexual and asexual propagation.

HORT270.title: Fundamentals of Horticultural Therapy
HORT270.description: Theory and practice of horticultural therapy in health care and human services; applications, settings, and professional career topics.

HORT310.title: Greenhouse Management
HORT310.description: Design and use of enclosed structures to manipulate controlled environments, effects on growth as applied to crops, production, and marketing costs.

HORT321.title: Nursery Production and Management
HORT321.description: Nursery industry organization, management, equipment, field and container production, storage, shipping, marketing, and business management practices.

HORT322.title: Herbaceous Plants
HORT322.description: Identification, landscape features, cultural requirements, and uses of ornamental annual, perennial, and bulb plants.

HORT330.title: Computers for Landscape Design
HORT330.description: Applications and techniques of computer software utilized in small-scale landscape design-build.

HORT331.title: Landscape Design
HORT331.description: Fundamentals of landscape design theory and plant composition as presented in simple problems.

HORT335.title: Landscape Structures
HORT335.description: Design and construction methods for structures commonly used in residential landscaping. Preparation of construction documents.

HORT336.title: Landscape Grading and Drainage Studio
HORT336.description: Basic design principles for grading, drainage, and earth forms for small-scale projects.

HORT341.title: Turfgrass Management
HORT341.description: Principles and practices of turfgrass propagation and maintenance.

HORT344.title: Organic Greenhouse Production
HORT344.description: Fundamentals of greenhouse production using organic production methods.

HORT345.title: Diagnosis and Treatment in Organic Fields

HORT347.title: Hydroponics
HORT347.description: Hydroponics, hydroponic systems, and hydroponic process from concept to application.

HORT367.title: Landscape Irrigation
HORT367.description: Practical design of sprinkler and trickle irrigation systems for commercial and residential landscapes.

HORT370.title: Landscape Irrigation
HORT370.description: Necessary skills to design and manage irrigation systems used in the landscape industry.

HORT401.title: Medicinal and Value-Added Uses of Plants
HORT401.description: Chemical, biochemical and ethnobotanical perspective on the medicinal and value-added uses of plants.

HORT410.title: Postharvest Biology and Technology
HORT410.description: Storage and quality maintenance of harvested fruits and vegetables.

HORT412.title: Floriculture Crops
HORT412.description: Commercial production and marketing of bedding plants, potted container crops, and cut flowers.

HORT417.title: Indoor Crop Production and Physiology
HORT417.description: Advanced principles and practices specific to the production of horticultural crops in controlled environments. Explore strategies for the management of environmental factors (e.g., light intensity, spectrum, temperature, relative humidity, carbon dioxide) and the resulting impact on plant growth and development. Review recent advancements in research and technology specific to production in controlled environments.

HORT421.title: Horticultural Therapy Techniques
HORT421.description: Clinical skills in horticultural therapy; communication, safety, leadership, therapeutic relationships, adaptation of tools and activities.

HORT423.title: Horticultural Therapy Programming
HORT423.description: Methods for individual treatment planning, intervention, documentation, and reporting within therapy, social, and vocational HT programs.

HORT425.title: Horticultural Therapy Management
HORT425.description: Horticultural therapy program and site design, proposals, funding, marketing, management, and evaluation.

HORT431.title: Planting Design Studio
HORT431.description: Functional and aesthetic values of plant materials; their creative use in landscape design.

HORT432.title: Intensive Landscape Design Studio
HORT432.description: Site planning and design for landscape projects of a limited scale. Problems of increasing complexity. Emphasis on real sites and clients.

HORT441.title: Turfgrass Science
HORT441.description: Examination of turfgrass management practices from a scientific perspective; discussion of advanced turfgrass management technologies.

HORT451.title: Vegetable Crop Management
HORT451.description: Physiological, environmental, and cultural aspects of vegetable crop production, including conventional and certified organic approaches.

HORT452.title: Viticulture-Grape Production
HORT452.description: Grape production in temperate zone climates.

HORT453.title: Principles of Fruit Crop Management
HORT453.description: Understanding the fundamentals of fruit tree biology is essential to making sound orchard management and business decisions in the tree fruit industry. Explore the basics of tree and small fruit production, including site, cultivar and rootstock selection, cropping trends and cultural practices such as planting, pruning, training, irrigation, nutrition, harvesting, and postharvest handling and technology of specific temperate fruit crops.

HORT454.title: Horticulture Crop Production and Management
HORT454.description: Production and management of horticulture crops.

HORT462.title: Viticulture Practices in Grape Production
HORT462.description: Biology of grape vines and cultural practices including planning, training, pest control, pruning, and harvesting; special emphasis on Colorado.

HORT464A.title: Arboriculture
HORT464A.description: Practices used by arborists and landscape managers to plant, appraise and maintain landscape trees.

HORT465.title: Landscape Estimating
HORT465.description: Landscape construction estimating and bidding, contract documentation and other business practices relevant to landscape design-build and contracting.

HORT476.title: Environmental Plant Stress Physiology
HORT476.description: Plant growth, development and physiology, major sources of stress in plants, global issues in environment and plant stress.

HORT479.title: Professional Landscape Practices
HORT479.description: Business skills involved in a successful career in the green industry.

HORT486A.title: Practicum: Floriculture
HORT486A.description: Directed experience in applications of floriculture technique. Fall: pest, energy, and production. Spring: production and experimentation.

HORT486B.title: Practicum: General
HORT486B.description: Directed experiences in applications of horticulture techniques and procedures.

HORT511.title: Green Roof Culture
HORT511.description: Understand the relevance of green roofs in North America, especially the process, from concept to project completion and maintenance.

HORT521.title: Horticulture and Human Health and Well-Being
HORT521.description: Impact of principles and practices of horticulture on human health and well-being.

HORT522.title: Horticulture and Human Health Issues
HORT522.description: Horticulture is an essential instrument of public health, but often professionals in these fields view themselves as opponents. Examine issues arising in the production of foods for human consumption that human health professionals often encounter. Overcome the barriers that divide horticulture and human health professionals.

HORT523.title: Screening Crops for Human Health Traits
HORT523.description: Principle and methods of screening food crops for traits related to human health.

HORT524.title: Food Pharmacology, Horticulture, and Health
HORT524.description: Application of the principles of pharmacology to the production of food combinations that promote human health. Horticultural food crops are emphasized.

HORT571.title: Soil-Plant-Water Relations/Water Stress
HORT571.description: Movement of water in the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum. Instrumentation for measuring plant-water relations. Plant responses to drought and salinity.

HORT576.title: Advanced Environmental Plant Stress Physiology
HORT576.description: Advanced aspects of plant growth, development and physiology, major sources of stress in plants, global issues in environment and plant stress.

HORT579.title: Mass Spectrometry Omics-Methods and Analysis
HORT579.description: A survey of experimental designs and workflows to generate, computationally process and analyze metabolite and protein data using mass spectrometry. Course format includes lecture, computer homework assignments with real data, literature review, and student presentations.

HORT588.title: Supervised Extension Practices
HORT588.description: Field experiences in extension practices in horticulture.

RRM101.title: Hospitality Industry
RRM101.description: Food service, lodging, and tourism industries; exploration of various industry segments and career opportunities.

RRM200.title: Hotel Operations
RRM200.description: Front office and room management as related to resorts and hotels. Computer application, financial controls, employee and guest relations.

RRM310.title: Food Service Systems-Operations
RRM310.description: Technical operations: menu planning, evaluation, recipe standardization, forecasting, food cost, sanitation, hospital food distribution systems.

RRM311.title: Food Service Systems-Production and Purchasing
RRM311.description: Quantity food production principles, purchasing specifications, market channels.

RRM312.title: Hospitality Human Resource Management
RRM312.description: Principles and practices of employee management in the hospitality industry including employment process, training, legal aspects, performance.

RRM330.title: Alcohol Beverage Control and Management
RRM330.description: Classification, production, and service of controlled beverages; management of facilities and people; safe service training; financial controls.

RRM340.title: Restaurant Operations
RRM340.description: Principles, practices, philosophies, systems for daily operation of casual or fine dining restaurant; focus on developing solutions to problems.

RRM345.title: Food, Beverage, and Labor Cost Control
RRM345.description: Cost control for food, beverage, and labor in the hospitality industry.

RRM350.title: Hospitality Marketing
RRM350.description: Operations marketing, including consumer behaviors, marketing strategies, and marketing plans in the hospitality industry.

RRM382A.title: Study Abroad--Thailand: Hospitality and Tourism
RRM382A.description: International focus on hospitality and tourism contexts. Emphasis on hospitality consumers/travelers and the current industry trends. Visit one of the most popular tourism destinations in Southeast Asia, Thailand.

RRM400.title: Food and Society
RRM400.description: Exploration of the influence of food, dining, and nutrition on cultural aspects of the human experience.

RRM410.title: Food Safety Management
RRM410.description: Management and practical applications of safe food service including sanitation, food borne illness, worker hygiene, proper food temperatures and handling, hazard analysis critical control points, local/state/federal health rules and regulations. ServSafe® Manager Certification.

RRM415.title: Catering Techniques and Culinary Arts
RRM415.description: Management of advanced techniques in culinary technique; catering of food and beverages for special functions.

RRM450.title: Leadership in the Hospitality Industry
RRM450.description: Exploration of leadership skills, their relationship to ethics through self-analysis, and leading change in the hospitality industry.

RRM460.title: Event and Conference Planning
RRM460.description: Overview of event planning and management. Explores key concepts critical to the success of any event and current trends in the industry.

RRM487.title: Internship in Hospitality Management
RRM487.description: Supervised off-campus experience in food and beverage, lodging, or event planning focusing on management tasks and responsibilities.

RRM492.title: Seminar on Hospitality Management
RRM492.description: Applying and synthesizing service knowledge and management functions; project discussions, benchmark presentations, execution of a capstone project.

RRM500.title: Understanding Food
RRM500.description: Role of food in the creation of identity, as a driver of technology, and the prominent role food plays in the media.

RRM510.title: Foodservice Management
RRM510.description: Analysis of a wide variety of foodservice operations, including procurement, forecasting, operational design, and menu planning.

RRM520.title: Lodging Management
RRM520.description: Operating standards and practices essential to the profitability of a hotel, lodging, and accommodation enterprise.

RRM686.title: Practicum-Food Service Management
RRM686.description: Food production, menu planning, nutritional analysis and food costing.

HDFS101.title: Individual and Family Development (GT-SS3)
HDFS101.description: Principles of life-span human development in the context of the family. Theory and research on the influence of family systems on individuals.

HDFS201.title: Perspectives in Gerontology
HDFS201.description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on a variety of issues in human aging; exploration of careers in gerontology; service-learning with older adults; emphasis on applied gerontology.

HDFS217.title: Creative Experiences for Children
HDFS217.description: Theories of play and creativity provide the foundation for examining the role of art, music, and literature in early childhood development. Exploration of creative techniques appropriate for young children and how these techniques enhance the child’s self-expression, creativity, and development in educational, medical, and therapeutic settings.

HDFS277.title: Introductory Seminar in HDFS
HDFS277.description: Introduction to human development and family studies field, major and concentration requirements, resources, and career exploration. An inclusive environment to develop and practice the necessary skills to transition to the major and academic expectations of the department and college.

HDFS286.title: Practicum-Professional Skills
HDFS286.description: Observational and applied experience with children, adolescents, adults, or families. Exploration of professional skills and opportunities.

HDFS302.title: Marriage and Family Relationships
HDFS302.description: Preparation for and adjustment to marital and family relationships throughout the life cycle.

HDFS310.title: Infant and Child Development in Context
HDFS310.description: Physical, cognitive, and socioemotional development from conception through middle childhood in context of family, relationships, and culture.

HDFS311.title: Adolescent/Early Adult Development in Context
HDFS311.description: Physical, cognitive, and socioemotional development of adolescents and young adults in context of family, relationships, and culture.

HDFS312.title: Adult Development-Middle Age and Aging
HDFS312.description: Developmental issues and processes pertaining to middle and later adulthood. Contexts in which adult development and aging occur are emphasized.

HDFS315.title: Disability across the Lifespan and Culture
HDFS315.description: Use of interdisciplinary perspective to understand individuals who have disabling conditions relevant to careers in health, educational, rehabilitation, and human service professions. Causes, outcomes, and intervention of commonly occurring disabilities and health conditions (e.g., congenital disabilities, diabetes, spinal cord injuries).

HDFS317.title: Disabilities in Early Childhood Education
HDFS317.description: Recommended practices for fostering development of young children with disabilities. Knowledge of atypical development in early childhood (birth through grade 3). Practices for assessment, intervention, adapted instruction and materials, and inclusive environments to facilitate children's attainment of educational goals.

HDFS318.title: Infancy and Toddlerhood
HDFS318.description: Physical, cognitive, language, and socio-emotional development from pre-birth through 36 months, with an emphasis on applied settings.

HDFS332.title: Death, Dying, and Grief
HDFS332.description: Developmental processes of death and dying related to the dying individuals and their families and for human service agencies.

HDFS334.title: Family and Parenthood Across the Life Cycle
HDFS334.description: Parenthood as a developmental process and in the context of family relationships throughout the life cycle.

HDFS350.title: Applied Research Methods
HDFS350.description: Interpret, apply, and write about research findings in human development.

HDFS375.title: Lifespan Intervention and Prevention Science
HDFS375.description: Intervention and prevention approaches and skills to improve the health, mental health, and well-being of families and individuals across the lifespan.

HDFS402.title: Couple and Family Studies
HDFS402.description: Theory and research concerning couple and family processes; social contexts in which couples and families change over time.

HDFS403.title: Families in the Legal Environment
HDFS403.description: The intersection of individuals, children, families and the legal system, including the balance between the right to privacy and government intervention, and social disparities in the legal system. Topics include: establishing the legal parent relationship, adoption, the rights of children and parents, marriage, divorce, dependency and neglect, family violence, disability and estate planning, juvenile delinquency, legalities of gender, and landlord/tenant and housing policy.

HDFS404.title: Child Life Theory and Practice
HDFS404.description: Theories and skills related to effective child life practice in hospitals.

HDFS410.title: Promoting Early Socioemotional Development
HDFS410.description: Social and emotional development in children ages 3-8: atypical and typical development, developmental theories and models, risk and protective factors, evidence-based programs, and empirically validated teaching strategies for preventing challenging behaviors and fostering adaptive social skills and emotion regulation.

HDFS411.title: Developmental Transitions in Adolescence
HDFS411.description: Examination of biological, socio-emotional, cognitive, and behavioral changes during adolescence.

HDFS412.title: Mental and Physical Health in Adulthood
HDFS412.description: Mental and physical health of adults, contextual factors of development, and implications for prevention, intervention, and public health planning.

HDFS434.title: Risk and Resilience Across the Lifespan
HDFS434.description: Why some individuals are at high risk for poor developmental outcomes, and why certain individuals fare well despite such risks or adversities. Strong developmental emphasis because resilience is viewed as a process, the results of which may not be manifest for years. There is an ecological emphasis because protective and vulnerability factors often reside in families, schools, neighborhoods.

HDFS439.title: Administration of Early Childhood Programs
HDFS439.description: Center administration related to program development and operations, budgeting, state regulations and licensing, and personnel issues.

HDFS445.title: Early Childhood Health, Safety, and Nutrition

HDFS470A.title: Campus Connections–Mentoring At-Risk Youth: Youth Mentor
HDFS470A.description: Service-learning course engaging students as mentors with local at-risk youth.

HDFS470B.title: Campus Connections–Mentoring At-Risk Youth: Mentor Coach
HDFS470B.description: Serve as mentor coach in a service-learning course engaging students as mentors with local at-risk youth.

HDFS470C.title: Campus Connections–Mentoring At-Risk Youth: Program Administration
HDFS470C.description: Provide administrative support to a service-learning program for local at-risk youth.

HDFS475.title: Entrepreneurs and Leaders in Human Services
HDFS475.description: Skills and knowledge about leadership and entrepreneurship in areas pertinent to human development and family studies, as human services, non-profits, and other enterprises related to helping individuals, couples, and families.

HDFS477.title: HDFS Professional Preparation
HDFS477.description: Exploration of professionalism, workplace issues, leadership and communication skills, goal setting, self-management, and building a professional identity in person, writing, and online. Completion of steps to secure an internship.

HDFS478.title: HDFS Professional Development
HDFS478.description: Exploration of professionalism, workplace issues, leadership and communication skills, goal setting, self-management, and building a professional identity in person, writing, and online. Understand the skills and attributes required to become a successful HDFS professional.

HDFS488A.title: Internship: Human Development and Family Studies
HDFS488A.description: Provides an opportunity to integrate HDFS classroom knowledge into real-world experiences. Students complete between 200-320 hours (5-8 credits) at an internship site established and approved by the HDFS Department. Weekly meetings with internship site supervisors foster the development of professional skills and feedback to enhance students’ performance, conduct, ethics, and communication skills for the workplace.

HDFS488B.title: Internship: Early Childhood
HDFS488B.description: Provides an opportunity to integrate HDFS classroom knowledge into real-world experiences. Students complete between 200-320 hours (5-8 credits) at an internship site established and approved by the HDFS Department. Weekly meetings with internship site supervisors foster the development of professional skills and feedback to enhance students’ performance, conduct, ethics, and communication skills for the workplace.

HDFS488C.title: Internship: Pre-Health
HDFS488C.description: Provides an opportunity to integrate HDFS classroom knowledge into real-world experiences. Students complete between 200-320 hours (5-8 credits) at an internship site established and approved by the HDFS Department. Weekly meetings with internship site supervisors foster the development of professional skills and feedback to enhance students’ performance, conduct, ethics, and communication skills for the workplace.

HDFS488D.title: Internship: Prevention/Intervention Science
HDFS488D.description: Provides an opportunity to integrate HDFS classroom knowledge into real-world experiences. Students complete between 200-320 hours (5-8 credits) at an internship site established and approved by the HDFS Department. Weekly meetings with internship site supervisors foster the development of professional skills and feedback to enhance students’ performance, conduct, ethics, and communication skills for the workplace.

HDFS488E.title: Internship: Leadership/Entrepreneurship
HDFS488E.description: Provides an opportunity to integrate HDFS classroom knowledge into real-world experiences. Students complete between 200-320 hours (5-8 credits) at an internship site established and approved by the HDFS Department. Weekly meetings with internship site supervisors foster the development of professional skills and feedback to enhance students’ performance, conduct, ethics, and communication skills for the workplace.

HDFS492.title: Capstone--Evidence-Based Program Proposals
HDFS492.description: Research, development, and oral presentations of evidence-based prevention or intervention program proposals from a contextual and developmental perspective.

HDFS493.title: Specialized Seminar
HDFS493.description: Advanced study of theory, research, and application in a specialized area.

HDFS497A.title: Group Study: Peer Advising
HDFS497A.description: Serve as an active member of the Peer Advising Team by providing assistance to undergraduate students and support to the HDFS advisors to enhance the services provided by the HDFS Undergraduate Advising Office.

HDFS497B.title: Group Study: Undergraduate Outreach and Leadership
HDFS497B.description: Application of human development skills in a variety of settings.

HDFS497C.title: Group Study: Student Respect/Wellness Education
HDFS497C.description: Application of human development skills in a variety of settings.

HDFS497D.title: Group Study: Asian/Pacific American Cultural Center
HDFS497D.description: Application of human development skills in a variety of settings.

HDFS497E.title: Group Study: Rites of Passage Mentoring Program
HDFS497E.description: Peer mentoring, assisting with a retreat for incoming first year students, attending seminars/community building forums, community service involvement, providing academic resource information, and leadership development. The goal of this course is to improve the academic performance and retention rate of African American first-year and transfer students.

HDFS497F.title: Group Study: Honors Human Development
HDFS497F.description: Application of human development skills in a variety of settings.

HDFS497G.title: Group Study: Human Development
HDFS497G.description: Application of human development skills in a variety of settings.

HDFS499.title: Thesis
HDFS499.description: Independent research project presented to a faculty committee.

HDFS500.title: Issues in Human Development & Family Studies
HDFS500.description: A selected, broad issue in human development and family studies emphasizing principles of research.

HDFS501.title: Readings in the Discipline
HDFS501.description: Research in human development and family studies content areas; skills in writing an extended literature review.

HDFS505.title: Human Development for Helping Professionals
HDFS505.description: An advanced overview of lifespan development, focusing on wellness promotion and developmental influences on case conceptualization and treatment.

HDFS515.title: Family Systems and Psychopathology
HDFS515.description: Assessment and diagnosis of mental illness within the context of family systems.

HDFS520.title: Family Therapy Practice: Treatment Planning
HDFS520.description: Integration of family/couple therapy theories and practice related to treatment planning and internal family systems therapy.

HDFS521.title: Family Therapy Practice: Common Factors
HDFS521.description: Application of common factors - e.g., therapeutic alliance - in family and couple therapy.

HDFS524.title: Family Theory
HDFS524.description: Major theories and conceptual frameworks for family analysis.

HDFS545.title: Program Evaluation Methods and Statistics
HDFS545.description: Introduction to program evaluation methods, empirical research, data analysis, and interpretation in prevention science.

HDFS549.title: Research Methods I
HDFS549.description: Introduction to empirical research, data analysis, and interpretation in Human Development and Family Sciences.

HDFS592.title: Grant Writing-Human Services and Research
HDFS592.description: Writing grant proposals that support client services or for research.

HDFS593.title: Seminar–Human Services Leadership
HDFS593.description: Investigates issues relevant to human development and family studies, such as human services, non-profits, and other enterprises related to helping individuals, couples, and families.

HDFS607.title: Prevention Science Across the Lifespan
HDFS607.description: Theory, methods, interventions, and standards of evidence in preventing mental, emotional, and behavioral disorders.

HDFS608.title: Program Planning and Implementation
HDFS608.description: Design or adapt research-based prevention programs from a family-centered, developmentally appropriate perspective.

HDFS609.title: Prevention Program Evaluation
HDFS609.description: Concepts and practices of program evaluation in prevention science.

HDFS610.title: Risk and Resilience
HDFS610.description: Risk and resilience processes in human development.

HDFS611.title: Early Child Development
HDFS611.description: Advanced study of developmental changes from conception through age ten; research-based applications to practice.

HDFS612.title: Adolescent Development
HDFS612.description: Classical and contemporary theory; review of research related to major developmental processes.

HDFS613.title: Adult Development and Aging
HDFS613.description: Advanced study of developmental change and adaptation during adult years.

HDFS620.title: Family Therapy Practice: Addictions
HDFS620.description: Application of marriage and family therapy theories to clinical practice with a focus on addiction and self-of-the-therapist.

HDFS621.title: Family Therapy Practice: Topics in Sexuality
HDFS621.description: Integration of family therapy theories and practice related to topics in sexuality, termination and referral, and one's personal theory of change.

HDFS624.title: Skills and Techniques in Family Therapy
HDFS624.description: Elaboration of techniques and therapy skills based on theory and research.

HDFS636.title: Aging and the Family
HDFS636.description: Theory and research relating to topics on aging during middle and late years of family life cycle.

HDFS644.title: Foundations in Family Therapy
HDFS644.description: Contemporary research and treatment strategies for parenting problems, family violence, and substance abuse.

HDFS676.title: Professional Skills Development
HDFS676.description: Fundamental skills of marriage and family therapy; clinic procedures; case assessment, planning, and management.

HDFS677.title: Ethical and Legal Issues
HDFS677.description: Ethical and legal issues in field of human development and family studies.

HDFS686A.title: Practicum: Human Development
HDFS686A.description: Application of human development skills in a variety of professional settings.

HDFS686B.title: Practicum: Family Studies
HDFS686B.description: Application of human development skills in a variety of professional settings.

HDFS686D.title: Practicum: Developmental Assessment
HDFS686D.description: Application of human development skills in a variety of professional settings.

HDFS686E.title: Practicum: Early Childhood Education
HDFS686E.description: Application of human development skills in a variety of professional settings.

HDFS687A.title: Internship: Human Development
HDFS687A.description: Application of advanced human development skills in professional settings.

HDFS687B.title: Internship: Family Studies
HDFS687B.description: Application of advanced human development skills in professional settings.

HDFS687C.title: Internship: Marriage and Family Therapy
HDFS687C.description: Application of advanced human development skills in professional settings.

HDFS692A.title: Family Issues: Intimacy and Human Sexuality
HDFS692A.description: Current issues in the family with implications for intervention, therapy, and policy.

HDFS692B.title: Family Issues: Parenting
HDFS692B.description: Current issues in the family with implications for intervention, therapy, and policy.

HDFS692C.title: Family Issues: Family Policy and Programming
HDFS692C.description: Current issues in the family with implications for intervention, therapy, and policy.

HDFS692D.title: Family Issues: Contemporary Family Issues
HDFS692D.description: Current issues in the family with implications for intervention, therapy, and policy.
HDFS692D.terms: Fall, Spring, Summer. Offered as needed.

HDFS710.title: Theories of Applied Developmental Science
HDFS710.description: Theories of applied developmental science, and implications for intervention and policy.

HDFS750.title: Multivariate Research Methods II
HDFS750.description: Applications of multivariate methods to research in applied developmental science.

HDFS772.title: Marriage and Family Therapy Supervision
HDFS772.description: Prepares professionals to supervise marriage and family therapists in a variety of settings.

HDFS792A.title: Seminar: Lifespan Socioemotional Development
HDFS792A.description: Current issues in applied developmental science involving a synthesis of theory, research, and application.

HDFS792B.title: Seminar: Lifespan Cognitive Development
HDFS792B.description: Current issues in applied developmental science involving a synthesis of theory, research, and application.

HDFS792C.title: Seminar: Special Topics
HDFS792C.description: Current issues in applied developmental science involving a synthesis of theory, research, and application.

INTD110.title: Visual Expression of Interior Environments (GT-AH1)
INTD110.description: Introduction to interior environments conceptualizing the interior architectural environment in the context of an interrelated system of spaces. Observation and analysis of spatial environments as a way of understanding how spatial environments produce and communicate culture as well as are shaped by those who design, navigate, and participate in these spaces.

INTD129.title: Introduction-Interior Architecture & Design
INTD129.description: Industry perspective to the profession of interior architecture and design through commercial and residential interiors with a focus on the role of key elements such as lighting, color, texture, and pattern on shaping interior architectural environments. Emphasis will be on disciplinary professional values and design process in interior architecture and design.

INTD166.title: Visual Communication-Drawing
INTD166.description: Hand drafting, free-hand drawing and conceptualization to communicate interior architecture and design concepts visualizing two- and three-dimensional  representations.

INTD200.title: Housing Values in America
INTD200.description: Housing issues in the U.S.; values, norms, roles of government and building professions; interaction of issues with U.S. public values to meet housing needs.

INTD201.title: Two-Dimensional Fundamentals-Interior Design
INTD201.description: Demonstration of 2-dimensional elements and principles of design incorporating creative thinking, design fundamentals, design communication skills.

INTD210.title: Studio I-Interior Architecture and Design
INTD210.description: Applying basic concepts of human behavior, anthropometrics, ergonomics, space planning, and furniture arrangement to residential and commercial interiors.

INTD236.title: Three-Dimensional Thinking
INTD236.description: Demonstration and application in visualizing interior space in three dimensions.

INTD255.title: Residential Interiors
INTD255.description: Theories, issues, and planning elements that impact the design of residential interiors.

INTD256.title: Computer-Aided Design for Interior Designers
INTD256.description: Use of computer-aided design (CAD), specifically two-dimensional and three-dimensional drafting using PC software.

INTD266.title: Visual Communication-Digital Multi-Media
INTD266.description: Visual communication using design software applications and multi-media techniques for expressing design ideas.

INTD276.title: Studio II-Interior Architecture and Design
INTD276.description: Introduction to small-scale interior architecture and design projects, including residential, educational, and commercial dining spaces.

INTD296A.title: Group Study: Space Planning and Application

INTD310.title: Studio III-Interior Architecture and Design
INTD310.description: Create a comprehensive design that reflects the integration of knowledge of structural and building systems. The design project is guided by a clear brief and developed through an Integrated Design Process, informed at each stage by data and analysis. The project is documented through working drawings, annotated diagrams, and information graphics.

INTD330.title: Lighting Design
INTD330.description: Application of lighting design in interiors.

INTD335.title: Interior Architecture and Design Technologies
INTD335.description: Principles and procedures required in building information modeling for digital design, detailing, documentation, and visualization in interior architecture and design.

INTD336.title: Color
INTD336.description: Color theories, principles, trends and application in design.

INTD340.title: Interior Materials and Products
INTD340.description: Analysis of materials, finishes, furnishings, objects, and resources for interior architecture and design.

INTD350.title: Codes-Health and Safety
INTD350.description: Health, safety, and wellness issues in interiors, including laws, codes, standards, regulations, and guidelines.

INTD359.title: History of Interior Architecture and Design
INTD359.description: Survey of interior architecture and design history from ancient times through the present.

INTD376.title: Studio IV-Interior Architecture and Design
INTD376.description: Applications of creative problem-solving, digital and design skills to develop innovative interior design projects with a focus on medium-scale commercial interiors.

INTD400.title: Interior Design Research Proposal
INTD400.description: Research, development, and presentation of a programming proposal for a large scale interior design project with service learning component.

INTD410.title: Evidence-based Design Theory
INTD410.description: Theory and application of evidence-based design processes including research, development, and presentation of a programming proposal for a large scale interior project.

INTD456.title: Professional Practice-Interior Arch & Design
INTD456.description: Current design and business practices, project management and communication, exposure to multi-disciplinary ways of working in design. Emphasis on several key aspects of professional practice including entrepreneurship, ethics, and socially mediated communication.

INTD476.title: Capstone-Interior Architecture and Design
INTD476.description: Large scale projects representing research-based design solutions, illustrating synthesis and analysis of entry level professional competencies in interior architecture and design.

INTD482A.title: Study Abroad--Austria: Alpine Architecture and Sustainable Design
INTD482A.description: Investigation of prominent examples that capture the breadth and sustainability aspects of architecture and interior practices in the alpine region of Europe, with a specific focus on Tirol and Vorarlberg in Austria, St. Gallen in Switzerland, and Germany.

INTD550.title: Universal Design
INTD550.description: Analysis and evaluation of universal design as it applies to diverse population segments and interior environments.

IE179.title: Globalization: Exploring Our Global Village (GT-SS3)
IE179.description: Analysis and implications of social, cultural, economic, and political change in the context of globalization and transnational relationships.

IE272.title: World Interdependence - Current Global Issues
IE272.description: A global perspective focusing on an international topic receiving current media coverage.

IE282A.title: Study Abroad--Dominican Republic: Global Perspectives
IE282A.description: Focus on preparation for a short-term international experience. Opportunities for community engagement, discussions on the impact of student groups coming into a new culture, and learning how to prepare for integrating with another culture without causing harm.

IE300.title: Global Studies
IE300.description: Traditional and changing institutions, systems, values and identities in selected cultures and how they are perceived, portrayed, and experienced.

IE352A.title: Study Abroad--Morocco: Education and Culture
IE352A.description: Explores the education system of Morocco, including high school and secondary education. Gain understanding of educational and individual identity. Visit local schools, engage with guest lectures, service learning, cultural activities, guided reflections, learn about historical and political history of Rabat.

IE352B.title: Study Abroad--Costa Rica: Global Perspectives
IE352B.description: Focus on the history, society, and culture of Costa Rica and engagement in a variety of perspectives and concepts related to social identity and multicultural competence. Preparation for a short-term immersive international experience in Costa Rica. Community engagement, discussions on impact of student groups in a new culture, and preparation for integrating with another culture without causing harm.

IE352C.title: Study Abroad--Croatia: International Medical Shadowing
IE352C.description: Explore healthcare fields and systems, and participate in a medical shadowing experience in a Croatian hospital. Provides a framework to compare cultural influences of medical fields and first hand observations of medical practitioners. Engage with health professions interests in relevant and immersive intercultural experiences.

IE379.title: Integrating Global Learning Post Study Abroad
IE379.description: Introduces theories of cultural adjustment and intercultural communication, and facilitates activities to enhance learning after an international experience. Students will describe and deepen their intercultural learning and self-understanding. Provides an opportunity to develop and effectively communicate personal, professional, and academic goals.

IE382A.title: Study Abroad: Community Engagement in Nicaragua
IE382A.description: Exploration of the history and culture of Nicaragua. Fair trade processes, issues, and organizations.

IE382B.title: Study Abroad--Costa Rica: Global Service Learning
IE382B.description: What does it mean to become culturally competent as a college student? How does it impact community building? How do identities inform and impact perspectives about self and community? Explore these questions and more through interactive simulations, critical writing, and in class activities. This immersion into Costa Rica, an international crossroads of history, culture, language, and im/migrations, helps develop cultural competency about self and community.

IE382C.title: Study Abroad--Mexico: Community Engagement
IE382C.description: Exploration of the history and culture of Mexico. Fair trade and community development processes, issues, and organizations.

IE382D.title: Study Abroad--Morocco: Educational Access
IE382D.description: Explores the education system of Morocco, including high school and secondary education. Gain understanding of educational and individual identity. Visit local schools, engage with guest lectures, service learning, cultural activities, guided reflections, learn about historical and political history of Rabat.

IE382E.title: Study Abroad--Croatia: International Medical Shadowing
IE382E.description: Explore healthcare fields and systems, and participate in a medical shadowing experience in a Croatian hospital. Provides a framework to compare cultural influences of medical fields and first hand observations of medical practitioners. Engage with health professions interests in relevant and immersive intercultural experiences.

IE382F.title: Study Abroad--Panama: Community Engagement
IE382F.description: How do Panamanian communities respond to economic, political, social, and environmental challenges in today’s world? What are the strategies utilized to protect livelihoods, lands, cultures, and communities? Engage with peasant organizations, indigenous communities, Afro-Panamanians, an artist collective, and other groups to learn how they navigate a variety of pressures and challenges. Develop an understanding for their creative response and resiliency tactics.

IE387.title: Intercultural Internship
IE387.description: Supervised work experience in an intercultural setting.

IE470.title: Women and Development
IE470.description: Research and policy issues related to women in developing countries.

IE471.title: Children and Youth in Global Context
IE471.description: Global issues affecting children and youth are examined in cultural context.

IE472.title: Education for Global Peace
IE472.description: Peacekeeping, peacemaking and peace-building on micro and macro levels, and education's role in them, as key components for sustaining global peace.

IE478.title: Managing International Development Programs
IE478.description: Build practical skills for international development practitioners in project design and management.
