PHIL100.title: Appreciation of Philosophy (GT-AH3)
PHIL100.description: Basic issues in philosophy including theories of knowledge, metaphysics, ethics, and aesthetics.

PHIL103.title: Moral and Social Problems (GT-AH3)
PHIL103.description: Contemporary ethical issues in the United States, such as abortion, euthanasia, and genetic engineering.

PHIL104.title: Values, Culture, and Food Animal Agriculture

PHIL110.title: Logic and Critical Thinking (GT-AH3)
PHIL110.description: Identify, analyze, and evaluate real arguments in everyday life, politics, the sciences, and the professions.

PHIL112.title: Reasoning and Problem Solving
PHIL112.description: Creative and critical techniques in problem solving and decision making.

PHIL120.title: History and Philosophy of Scientific Thought (GT-AH3)
PHIL120.description: Historical case studies designed to illuminate methods, theory choice, and progress in scientific disciplines.

PHIL145.title: Environmental Justice and Sustainability
PHIL145.description: Introductory philosophical examination of the idea of fairness through an exploration of environmental justice and sustainability.

PHIL171.title: Religions of the West
PHIL171.description: Major religions of the Near East and West emphasizing their classical development; Judaism, Zoroastrianism, Christianity, Islam.

PHIL172.title: Religions of the East
PHIL172.description: Major religions of India and the Far East emphasizing their classical development; Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Taoism.

PHIL173.title: Philosophy of Traditional Judaism
PHIL173.description: Concepts and essentials of Jewish philosophy and Judaism, including overview of Jewish lifecycle, history, law, literature, ethics, and mysticism.

PHIL174.title: World Religions
PHIL174.description: Philosophical survey of several major world religions in terms of their historical development, worldviews, and practices.

PHIL205.title: Introduction to Ethics
PHIL205.description: Problems and theories concerning values and standards, right action, and the good life.

PHIL206.title: Knowledge and Existence-An Introduction
PHIL206.description: Problems and theories concerning knowledge, being, nature of the world.

PHIL210.title: Introduction to Formal Logic
PHIL210.description: Elementary principles, techniques in propositional and predicate logic.

PHIL240.title: Philosophies of Peace and Nonviolence
PHIL240.description: Classic and contemporary religious and philosophical work on peace and nonviolence.

PHIL270.title: Issues in the Study of Religion
PHIL270.description: Contemporary religion, its nature, types, forms of expression.

PHIL300.title: Ancient Greek Philosophy
PHIL300.description: Philosophy of ancient Greece emphasizing Plato and Aristotle.

PHIL301.title: 17th and 18th Century European Philosophy
PHIL301.description: Philosophy from the scientific revolution through Kant.

PHIL302.title: 19th Century Philosophy
PHIL302.description: Major figures, movements, concepts in Europe and America from about 1800 to early 20th century.

PHIL303.title: Medieval Philosophy
PHIL303.description: In the Medieval period, philosophers in the Pagan, Jewish, Christian, and Islamic traditions simultaneously influenced and opposed one another. Focus on the important debates in these traditions and determine to what extent the cross-cultural philosophical dialogues of the Medieval period can serve as models for cross-cultural philosophical dialogue in our own time.

PHIL305A.title: Philosophical Issues in the Professions: Business Ethics
PHIL305A.description: Philosophical problems, theories relevant to business.

PHIL305B.title: Philosophical Issues in the Professions: Medical Life Science
PHIL305B.description: Philosophical problems, theories relevant to medical-life science professions.

PHIL305C.title: Philosophical Issues in the Professions: Caring Professions
PHIL305C.description: Philosophical problems, theories related to caring professions.

PHIL305D.title: Philosophical Issues in the Professions: Engineering
PHIL305D.description: Philosophical problems, theories relevant to engineering.

PHIL305E.title: Philosophical Issues in the Professions: Animal Science
PHIL305E.description: Philosophical problems, theories relevant to professions in animal science.

PHIL305F.title: Philosophical Issues in the Professions: Information Science
PHIL305F.description: Philosophical problems, theories relevant to professions in information science.

PHIL305G.title: Philosophical Issues in the Professions: Research Ethics
PHIL305G.description: Philosophical problems, theories relevant to professions in information science.

PHIL310.title: Writing and Reasoning
PHIL310.description: Logic-based, analytic and critical writing and reading of complex argument and explanation types.

PHIL312.title: Philosophy of Law
PHIL312.description: Philosophical concepts, theories, and problems concerning the law.

PHIL315.title: Philosophy of Language
PHIL315.description: Basic concepts and principles in the theory of language.

PHIL318.title: Aesthetics-Visual Arts
PHIL318.description: Central, traditional, and contemporary theories of the nature of visual arts.

PHIL320.title: Ethics of Sustainability
PHIL320.description: Ethical and conceptual issues surrounding creation of sustainable societies and lifestyles.

PHIL322.title: Biomedical Ethics
PHIL322.description: Assorted topics at the intersection of ethics, the biological sciences, medicine, and health policy. Topics may include ethical problems at the beginning and end of life (e.g., abortion, euthanasia), cloning, research ethics, genetic engineering, human enhancement, informed consent, disability, justice in health care, the doctor-patient relationship, conflicts of interest, and others.

PHIL325.title: Philosophy of Natural Science
PHIL325.description: Structure of theories; basic concepts and assumptions; methods of explanation and confirmation; emphasis varies between physical and life sciences.

PHIL327.title: Philosophy of Behavioral Sciences
PHIL327.description: Structure of theories; basic concepts; explanation and confirmation; reductionism and values; emphasis varies between psychology and social sciences.

PHIL333.title: Latin American Philosophy
PHIL333.description: Major figures, problems, and traditions in Latin American philosophy.

PHIL335.title: Islam: Cosmology and Practice
PHIL335.description: Cosmological, spiritual, ritual, and practical aspects of Islam.

PHIL345.title: Environmental Ethics
PHIL345.description: Scientific, philosophical, and religious concepts of nature as they bear on human conduct; an ecological perspective.

PHIL348.title: Philosophy of Literature and the Arts
PHIL348.description: Aesthetic and philosophical issues in literature and the arts.

PHIL349.title: Philosophies of East Asia
PHIL349.description: Philosophical traditions of East Asia, including Confucianism, Daoism, and Zen Buddhism.

PHIL350.title: Social and Political Philosophy
PHIL350.description: Moral relationships between persons and institutions.

PHIL351.title: Interpreting the New Testament
PHIL351.description: Contemporary methods of New Testament interpretation.

PHIL353.title: Feminist Philosophies
PHIL353.description: Conceptual, moral, and social analysis of women's issues from a variety of philosophical feminist perspectives.

PHIL354.title: Philosophy and Science Fiction
PHIL354.description: Science fiction offers students the chance to consider difficult philosophical questions with real-world relevance. Students will read science fiction to stimulate thinking about three questions: (1) What does it mean for human technology to be natural or unnatural, and how should technology and nature be related? (2) What constitutes possession of rationality and/or intelligence? (3) What are space and time, and how should humans understand the spatiality and temporality of our own lives?

PHIL355.title: Philosophy of Religion
PHIL355.description: Philosophical analysis of nature of religion and structure of meaning in religious discourse.

PHIL359.title: Philosophy of Human Nature
PHIL359.description: Philosophical study of theories of human nature.

PHIL360.title: Topics in Asian Philosophy
PHIL360.description: Examination of major philosophical topics from ethics, sociopolitical philosophy, metaphysics, aesthetics.

PHIL363.title: Social Metaphysics
PHIL363.description: Exploration of the nature of social groups and their metaphysical, epistemological, and ethical significance.

PHIL366.title: Philosophy of Aging
PHIL366.description: Philosophical problems related to experience of growing old.

PHIL370.title: Contemporary Western Religious Thought
PHIL370.description: Contemporary interpretations of significant Western religious traditions.

PHIL371.title: Contemporary Eastern Religious Thought
PHIL371.description: Transformation of Indian and Chinese religious thought in the modern period.

PHIL372.title: Meaning and Truth in Religion
PHIL372.description: Nature, variety, functions, interpretation, evaluation of religious language.

PHIL375.title: Science and Religion
PHIL375.description: Encounter of religious belief with Western science, influences on each other, present relations.

PHIL379.title: Mysticism East and West
PHIL379.description: Varieties of mystical experience in selected Eastern and Western representatives.

PHIL407.title: Phenomenology and Existentialism
PHIL407.description: Methods, epistemology, metaphysics, axiology, ethics of 20th-century phenomenologists and existentialists.

PHIL409.title: 20th Century Philosophy
PHIL409.description: Major figures, trends, and concepts in 20th-century philosophy.

PHIL410.title: Gödel's Incompleteness Theorems
PHIL410.description: The proofs in detail of Gödel's two incompleteness theorems, two of the most important results in modern logic, along with the necessary mathematical and logical background. This includes basic set theory, axiomatic formal systems and axiomatizations of elementary first-order arithmetic in particular, recursive functions, computability, and metamathematics and the arithmetization of syntax.

PHIL411.title: Logic in Philosophy and Beyond
PHIL411.description: Logical tools used in a variety of areas, including but not limited to philosophy, computer science, linguistics, and information theory. Example topics include modal logic, type theory, and nonmonotonic logic.

PHIL415.title: Logic and Scientific Method
PHIL415.description: Approaches to analysis, assessment of scientific inference, problems of induction; applications to natural, behavioral, social sciences.

PHIL425.title: Epistemology
PHIL425.description: Concepts, problems, and theories of knowledge.

PHIL435.title: Metaphysics
PHIL435.description: Philosophical problems concerning nature, structure, and basic constituents of reality.

PHIL438.title: Philosophy of Mind
PHIL438.description: Nature and status of mind, mental states, mental activity; the mind-body problem, mind and human sciences, mind and self, nature of human action.

PHIL447.title: Ethical Theory
PHIL447.description: Fundamental problems and options in ethical theory.

PHIL455.title: Islamic Philosophy
PHIL455.description: Development of philosophical thought in early, middle, and late Muslim civilization.

PHIL460.title: Seminar in Great Philosophers
PHIL460.description: Works of one major figure in the history of philosophy.

PHIL461.title: Seminar in Philosophical Issues and Problems
PHIL461.description: Thorough examination of a major philosophical problem or issue.

PHIL462.title: Capstone Seminar
PHIL462.description: In-depth, integrative study of major topics, texts, and problems in both philosophy and religion.

PHIL479.title: Topics in Comparative Religions
PHIL479.description: Comparative study of topics in world religions and philosophy or religion.

PHIL500.title: Seminar in Major Philosophical Texts
PHIL500.description: Intensive study of one or two major works in the history of philosophy.

PHIL501.title: Seminar: Topics in History of Philosophy
PHIL501.description: Selected figures and periods from the history of western philosophy, from ancient to modern. Topics change from semester to semester.

PHIL525.title: Seminar in Epistemology
PHIL525.description: Analysis of contemporary theories of knowledge.

PHIL527.title: Seminar in Philosophy of Science
PHIL527.description: Systematic survey of major 20th-century philosophies of science.

PHIL545.title: Concept of Natural Value
PHIL545.description: Philosophical analysis of nature as a value carrier. Types of value associated with nature, their interrelations.

PHIL547.title: Seminar in Meta-Ethics
PHIL547.description: Systematic and historical overview of contemporary theories of meta-ethics.

PHIL548.title: Seminar in Normative Ethical Theory
PHIL548.description: Major topics in contemporary theories of normative ethics.

PHIL555.title: Seminar in Philosophical Models of Nature
PHIL555.description: Comparative inquiry into the "nature" of nature as viewed by philosophers of the past and present.

PHIL564.title: Seminar in Animal Rights
PHIL564.description: Contemporary issues concerning nature and moral status of nonhuman animals.

PHIL565.title: Seminar in Environmental Philosophy
PHIL565.description: Aesthetic appreciation of nature, duties concerning fauna, flora, endangered species, ecosystem.

PHIL566.title: Seminar in Applied Philosophy
PHIL566.description: Application of philosophical ideas and methods to analyze practical problems such as distributive justice, abortion, human rights conflicts.

PHIL570.title: Seminar in Contemporary Philosophical Theory
PHIL570.description: Major concepts and problems in current philosophical theory.

PHIL601.title: Master of Profess. Natural Sciences Ethics

PH110.title: Physics of Everyday Phenomena (GT-SC2)
PH110.description: Fundamental concepts of physics and elementary quantitative reasoning applied to phenomena in everyday life and beyond.

PH111.title: Physics of Everyday Phenomena Laboratory (GT-SC1)
PH111.description: Experiments dealing with basic physics concepts including explorations of everyday phenomena.

PH121.title: General Physics I (GT-SC1)
PH121.description: Concepts of force, torque, energy, momentum, work used to cover fluids, waves, sound, temperature, heat; biological, physical examples (noncalculus).

PH122.title: General Physics II (GT-SC1)
PH122.description: Electricity including electrostatics and simple circuits; magnetism; optics; nuclear physics, radiation; biological, physical examples (noncalculus).

PH141.title: Physics for Scientists and Engineers I (GT-SC1)
PH141.description: Forces, energy, momentum, angular momentum, oscillations, waves, heat, thermodynamics (calculus based).

PH142.title: Physics for Scientists and Engineers II (GT-SC1)
PH142.description: Electricity and magnetism, circuits, light, optics (calculus based).

PH245.title: Introduction to Electronics
PH245.description: AC circuits, physical bases and applications of electronic devices.

PH293.title: Selected Topics in Physics
PH293.description: Selected topics in physics with emphasis on depth of understanding.

PH314.title: Introduction to Modern Physics
PH314.description: Relativity; quantum mechanics; atomic structure; applications to solid-state, nuclear, and elementary particle physics.

PH327.title: Analytical Techniques for Physics
PH327.description: Applications to physics of curvilinear coordinate systems, line/surface integrals, linear algebra, ordinary/partial differential eqs., probability.

PH341.title: Mechanics
PH341.description: Particle dynamics, translation and rotation of rigid bodies, moving coordinate systems, Lagrangian mechanics, matrix and tensor methods.

PH351.title: Electricity and Magnetism
PH351.description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, currents, time-dependent electric and magnetic fields, radiation.

PH353.title: Optics and Waves
PH353.description: Geometrical optics; wave optics; interference, diffraction, and polarization; quantum optics.

PH361.title: Physical Thermodynamics
PH361.description: Laws of thermodynamics; thermodynamic potentials; applications such as fluids, phase transitions, electrical and magnetic systems, binary mixtures.

PH425.title: Advanced Physics Laboratory
PH425.description: Advanced experiments in electricity and magnetism, statistical physics and quantum mechanics.

PH451.title: Introductory Quantum Mechanics I
PH451.description: Schrodinger's theory of wave mechanics, potential wells, harmonic oscillators, wave packets, operators, angular momentum.

PH452.title: Introductory Quantum Mechanics II
PH452.description: Approximation techniques, perturbation theory, identical particles and spin, structure and spectra of atoms and molecules, hydrogen atom.

PH462.title: Statistical Physics
PH462.description: Maxwell-Boltzmann, Fermi-Dirac, and Bose-Einstein distribution functions; kinetic theory; applications to solids, metals, semiconductors, and gases.

PH492.title: Seminar
PH492.description: Preparation and presentation of seminars on selected modern topics.

PH517.title: Chaos, Fractals, and Nonlinear Dynamics
PH517.description: Strange attractors, fractal dimensions, Lyapunov exponents, multifractal spectrum, period doubling, universality, intermittency, time-delay embedding.

PH521.title: Introduction to Lasers
PH521.description: Stimulated emission; laser resonators; theory of laser oscillation; specific laser systems; applications.

PH522.title: Introductory Laser Laboratory
PH522.description: Experiments providing hands-on experiences with lasers.

PH531.title: Introductory Condensed Matter Physics
PH531.description: Crystal structures and bonding, electronic levels and vibrations, dielectric, optical and magnetic properties, quasiparticles, superconductivity.

PH561.title: Elementary Particle Physics
PH561.description: Particle interactions and detection techniques. Quark model, scattering models and standard model of electroweak interactions, physics of colliders.

PH571.title: Mathematical Methods for Physics I
PH571.description: Vector analysis, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, infinite series, method of Frobenius, complex variables, contour integration.

PH572.title: Mathematical Methods for Physics II
PH572.description: Partial differential equations, Sturm-Liouville theory, special functions, Green's functions, Fourier series, Fourier and Laplace transforms.

PH621.title: Classical Mechanics
PH621.description: Central forces, scattering, noninertial reference frames, Coriolis force, Lagrange's and Hamilton's equations, small oscillations, continuum mechanics.

PH631.title: Modern Topics in Condensed Matter Physics
PH631.description: Selected topics in modern condensed matter physics. Examples include topological phases of matter, superconductivity, heavy fermions, density functional theory, surfaces and interfaces.

PH641.title: Electromagnetism I
PH641.description: Electrostatics in a vacuum and a medium, general solution of Laplace's equation, Green's functions, magnetostatics in a vacuum and a medium.

PH642.title: Electromagnetism II
PH642.description: Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, radiation by accelerated charges, special relativity, Lagrangian formulation of electromagnetism.

PH651.title: Quantum Mechanics I
PH651.description: WKB theory, Heisenberg picture, 3D wells, hydrogen atom, time-independent perturbation theory, angular momentum and spin, Clebsch-Gordan coefficients.

PH652.title: Quantum Mechanics II
PH652.description: Wigner-Eckhart theorem, symmetries, density matrix, identical particles, interaction picture, time-dependent perturbation theory, scattering.

PH671.title: Statistical Mechanics
PH671.description: Canonical and grand-canonical ensembles; Maxwell-Boltzmann, Bose-Einstein, and Fermi-Dirac statistics; density operator; Bose-Einstein condensation.

PH722.title: Quantum Electronics
PH722.description: One- and two-photon spectroscopy; broadening mechanisms; nonlinear optics; coherent phenomena; experimental methods.

PH731.title: Condensed Matter Theory
PH731.description: Second quantization; electrons; phonons; electron-phonon interaction; superconductivity; magnetism; spin waves; density-functional methods; symmetry.

PH762.title: Elementary Particle Theory
PH762.description: Symmetries, electrodynamics, renormalization, and the running coupling constant. Hadron structure, QCD, gauge symmetry and electroweak interaction.

PH770.title: Quantum Theory
PH770.description: Formal scattering theory; relativistic quantum mechanics, quantum theory of radiation, symmetries and statistics, many-body theory.

PH784.title: Supervised College Teaching
PH784.description: Supervised teaching of general physics laboratory and recitation sections.

POLS101.title: American Government and Politics (GT-SS1)
POLS101.description: Principles, structures, and processes of American national government.

POLS103.title: State and Local Government and Politics (GT-SS1)
POLS103.description: Principles, organization, and operation of American state and local government.

POLS131.title: Current World Problems (GT-SS1)
POLS131.description: Historical background and theoretical perspectives explaining current international political and economic events.

POLS232.title: International Relations (GT-SS1)
POLS232.description: Basic concepts and approaches to international relations.

POLS241.title: Comparative Government and Politics (GT-SS1)
POLS241.description: Major foreign political systems stressing cross-national comparison of political forces, parties, ideologies, and institutions.

POLS302.title: U.S. Political Parties and Elections
POLS302.description: Foundational, institutional, and behavioral features of American political parties and elections.

POLS303.title: Politics of Organized Interests
POLS303.description: Role of interests in varied forms: social movements, institutions, associations, and membership groups in American politics.

POLS304.title: Legislative Politics
POLS304.description: Structure, organization, behavior, processes, and policy implications of U.S. legislatures.

POLS305.title: Judicial Politics
POLS305.description: Allocation of powers among judicial structures in American federal system.

POLS306.title: Executive Politics
POLS306.description: Structure, organization, behavior, processes, and policy implications of U.S. executive leadership.

POLS309.title: Urban Politics
POLS309.description: Governmental structures and political processes in urban government.

POLS321.title: Empirical Political Analysis Laboratory
POLS321.description: Laboratory applications of empirical research methods.

POLS331.title: Politics and Society Along Mexican Border
POLS331.description: Analysis of U.S.-Mexican relations and domestic politics as these affect regional characteristics and development of U.S.-Mexican border region.

POLS341.title: Western European Government and Politics
POLS341.description: Politics in Western European countries such as Britain, France, and Germany, and countries influenced by European traditions.

POLS345.title: Russian, Central, and East European Politics
POLS345.description: Political structures and processes in Russia, Central and East Europe, and selected post-Communist countries.

POLS347.title: Comparative Authoritarianism
POLS347.description: Explore non-democratic regimes in the world and the dynamics precipitating the emergence and breakdown of authoritarianism.

POLS351.title: Public Administration
POLS351.description: Government organization and management; decision processes; political and intergovernmental relations in administration.

POLS361.title: U.S. Environmental Politics and Policy
POLS361.description: Public and contemporary issues relating to U.S. environmental policy.

POLS362.title: Global Environmental Politics
POLS362.description: Cross-national and international contexts of environmental politics and policy.

POLS364.title: Air, Climate, and Energy Policy Analysis
POLS364.description: Discussion and analysis of air quality, climate, and energy nexus, with a focus on policy impacts on the economy and the environment under future scenarios.

POLS370A.title: Study Abroad--Amazon: Global Environmental Politics
POLS370A.description: Explore global environmental politics in the Brazilian Amazon. Through lectures, site visits, and meetings with local decision-makers, stakeholders and activists, apply international relations theories and concepts to understand various social, economic, political and ecological dimensions of global environmental problems, such as biodiversity loss and climate change, and efforts to address these problems from the global to local levels.

POLS371A.title: Study Abroad--London : Comparative UK and US Policy
POLS371A.description: Study and practice of public policy and law in the US and UK. In-depth comparative study of the central features of the American and UK policy-making process, administration, and legal system. Review a variety of substantive policy issues and existing public policies from a comparative perspective.

POLS392.title: Washington DC Semester Seminar
POLS392.description: Topics vary each semester, but each focuses on some aspect of politics and government in Washington, DC.

POLS405.title: Race and Ethnicity in U.S. Politics
POLS405.description: Relationships among American racial/ethnic groups, political attitudes, behavior; race and ethnicity roles in elections; implications for public policy.

POLS409.title: Urban and Regional Politics
POLS409.description: Governance processes and public policies in metropolitan regions.

POLS410.title: American Constitutional Law
POLS410.description: Allocation of powers among structures in American federal system.

POLS413.title: U.S. Civil Rights and Liberties
POLS413.description: U.S. Constitutional provisions and cases pertaining to the rights and liberties of individuals.

POLS420.title: History of Political Thought
POLS420.description: Issues and texts related to tradition of political thought from the ancient through the modern period.

POLS421.title: Contemporary Political Theories
POLS421.description: Major political theories and ideologies of contemporary times.

POLS422.title: Democratic Theory
POLS422.description: Competing approaches to the theory and practice of democracy, both locally and globally.

POLS423.title: American Political Theories
POLS423.description: Major American theories and ideologies: their development and present uses.

POLS431.title: International Law
POLS431.description: Rules and obligations for conduct of relations among states and other international entities.

POLS433.title: International Organization
POLS433.description: History, development, structure, process, and activity of selected public international organizations.

POLS435.title: United States Foreign Policy
POLS435.description: Institutions, responsibilities, processes, and issues in formulation and execution of U.S. foreign policy.

POLS436.title: Comparative Foreign Policy
POLS436.description: Effect of varying international and domestic contexts on foreign policy choices and outcomes across different countries, cultures, issues, and time.

POLS437.title: International Security
POLS437.description: Examines the conditions that make for war and peace in international relations.

POLS442.title: Environmental Politics in Developing World
POLS442.description: Examines environmental politics in developing countries and evaluates climate change, natural resource governance and environmental justice.

POLS443.title: Comparative Social Movements
POLS443.description: Reviews major works dealing with conceptual and theoretical foundations of social movements and examines a number of cases across regions.

POLS444.title: Comparative African Politics
POLS444.description: African political systems focusing on precolonial, colonial influences; rise of nationalism; approaches to new political order; influences of development.

POLS445.title: Comparative Asian Politics
POLS445.description: East and South Asian political systems emphasizing issues of development, political culture, and institutional change.

POLS446.title: Politics of South America
POLS446.description: South American political actors and institutions with emphasis on themes of development, democracy, revolution, and international affairs.

POLS447.title: Politics in Mexico, Central America, Caribbean
POLS447.description: Mexican politics with comparison to one or more Central American and Caribbean countries.

POLS448.title: Comparative Racial/Ethnic Politics
POLS448.description: Comparative examination of politics of race and ethnicity and role it plays in formation of nation-states.

POLS449.title: Middle East Politics
POLS449.description: Political issues of the Middle East, including the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, Islamism, and democratization.

POLS451.title: Public Policy Design and Governance
POLS451.description: Examination of governance institutions outside the scope of traditional bureaucratic organizations and accountability.

POLS459.title: Program Evaluation for Public Administrators
POLS459.description: An overview of research methods and statistical methods for public administrators.

POLS460.title: Public Policy Process
POLS460.description: Explanations of U.S. policy formation, implementation, and impact.

POLS462.title: Globalization, Sustainability, and Justice
POLS462.description: Public and private policies to promote sustainability and social justice in a globalizing world.

POLS463.title: Urban Policy and Management
POLS463.description: Policy choices and management issues associated with urban government.

POLS465.title: Public Policy Analysis
POLS465.description: Methods and tools used in the practice of policy analysis and evaluation of current public policy; emphasis on applied analysis.

POLS482A.title: Study Abroad: Politics and Culture in Turkey
POLS482A.description: Politics, history and material culture of Turkey. A study abroad experience.

POLS482B.title: Study Abroad: Comparative UK and US Policy - London
POLS482B.description: Study and practice of public policy and law in the US and UK. In-depth comparative study of the central features of the American and UK policy-making process, administration, and legal system. Review a variety of substantive policy issues and existing public policies from a comparative perspective.

POLS482C.title: Study Abroad: London Experience
POLS482C.description: Study and practice of public policy and law in the US and UK. In-depth comparative study of the central features of the American and UK policy-making process, administration, and legal system. Review a variety of substantive policy issues and existing public policies from a comparative perspective.

POLS482D.title: Study Abroad--Spain and Morocco: Politics of Food in the Mediterranean
POLS482D.description: Examine the politics of food in Spain and Morocco, namely Spain and Morocco, by investigating the policies regarding agriculture and food systems. Explore the roles of women in the food systems and understanding new and innovative food economies alternative to the industrialized food systems.

POLS487.title: Internship – Washington DC Semester
POLS487.description: Students in The Washington Center semester programs will work with an organization in Washington DC. Most internships are for 4 days/week and individually tailored for each student. The Washington Center ensures that all internships are "substantive and challenging." At least 80% of the student's work is non-clerical. Supervised by a professional academic program advisor.

POLS496.title: Washington DC Semester Colloquium Group Study

Portfolio creation of a student's work documenting and reflecting on their experiences.

PBHL516.title: Public Health Foundations
PBHL516.description: Introduction to public health history, concepts, principles, and current trends.

PBHL520.title: Health Systems Policy and Management
PBHL520.description: Overview of the organization and financing of U.S. healthcare systems, how health policy is developed and implemented, and key principles of leadership and management for public health professionals.

PBHL530.title: Environmental Public Health and Policy
PBHL530.description: Major concepts, methodologies and issues in the field of environmental public health.

PBHL534.title: Public Health Data Management Using SAS
PBHL534.description: Introduction to the basic concepts and skills needed to create programs for data management and analysis using SAS software. Explores how to manipulate and prepare data for analysis in SAS (including inputting, recoding, reformatting, subsetting, and merging data), and perform data analysis and write reports.

PBHL540.title: One Health in Public Health
PBHL540.description: One Health history and concepts for public health professionals.

PBHL550.title: Applied Behavior Change Theory
PBHL550.description: Introduction and application of community public health strategies and interventions including systems level changes.

PBHL560.title: Quantitative Methods in Public Health
PBHL560.description: Introduction to the major concepts and applications in public health data interpretation and analysis.

PBHL570.title: Epidemiology for Public Health
PBHL570.description: Descriptive and analytic methods in epidemiology and their application to research and practice in the field of public health.

PBHL575.title: Epidemiological Research for Public Health
PBHL575.description: Concepts, principles and skills needed for conducting epidemiological research in public health.

PBHL630.title: Field Methods for Disease Investigation
PBHL630.description: Application of epidemiologic tools to collect, analyze, and interpret data and test results important for disease surveillance and investigation.

PBHL644.title: Physical Activity and Public Health
PBHL644.description: Explore the role of physical activity (PA) in public health (PH). History of physical activity in public health, basic exercise physiology and kinesiology principles, and effectively promote and measure physical activity in a variety of populations. Discuss physical activity in various settings, and explore how programs are effectively planned, implemented and evaluated.

PBHL692A.title: Seminar: Animals, People, and the Environment
PBHL692A.description: Current public health issues related to interactions among people, animals, and our environment.

PBHL692C.title: Seminar: Global Health & Health Disparities
PBHL692C.description: Current public health issues concerning disparate populations and global health trends.

PBHL692D.title: Seminar: Health Communication
PBHL692D.description: Current issues and trends in health communication.

PBHL692E.title: Seminar: Physical Activity & Healthy Lifestyles
PBHL692E.description: Current public health issues concerning exercise, the built environment, and health promotion.

PBHL692F.title: Seminar: Public Health Nutrition
PBHL692F.description: Current issues and trends concerning the impact of nutrition on public health.

PBHL692G.title: Seminar: Current Issues in Public Health
PBHL692G.description: Current public health issues and trends.

PBHL696.title: Public Health Group Study
PBHL696.description: Group study on current public health issues; topics will vary.

PBHL698.title: Public Health Capstone
PBHL698.description: Capstone project for Master of Public Health students.

PPA500.title: Research Methods for Public Policy and Admin
PPA500.description: Introduction to the design, logic, and ethics of research methods appropriate for the evaluation of policies and programs before, during, and after implementation.

PPA501.title: Program Evaluation and Quantitative Methods
PPA501.description: Overview of program evaluation and hands-on application to managerial decision making in public administration. Topics include program evaluation, data collection and measurement in public administration, descriptive statistics, measures of association and other bivariate statistics, index variable construction, regression analysis, and an overview of selected other methods applied to problems of public administration and policy.

PPA530.title: Civic Engagement
PPA530.description: Focus on public engagement directed at the tools, theories, and processes relevant to public policy and administration. Introduction to the role citizens play in democracy, decision making, public administration, and public policy. Trends of engagement are explored alongside strategies useful to manage, encourage, and facilitate public participation in public policy and administration. Practice is emphasized.

PPA540.title: International Policy Toolkit
PPA540.description: Provides a valuable toolkit for those interested in working for an intergovernmental organization, international non-governmental organization, or for the U.S. foreign policy-making apparatus. Topics covered include regime change, civil society, political culture, terrorism, and international organizations.

PPA541.title: Principles & Processes of International Mgmt
PPA541.description: Policy-making and policy-implementation processes of intergovernmental organizations and international non-governmental organizations.

PPA542.title: Policy Accountability--Non-Democratic Regimes
PPA542.description: Theoretical knowledge and practical, real-world applications that navigate the complex political and economic terrain of non-democratic regimes.

PPA543.title: Evidence-Based Decision Making
PPA543.description: A survey of evidence-based decision making, including tools, constraints, and opportunities for public servants.

PPA544.title: Ethics and Efficacy--Global Policymaking
PPA544.description: In-depth study of international policymaking success and failure with a focus on ethics and cross-border issues. Provides the expertise and awareness necessary for leadership in international policy and management.

PPA551.title: Public Personnel Administration
PPA551.description: Study of public sector human resource methods and practices. Focus on modern personnel systems, laws, and policies related to the management of human resources in the public sector.

PPA552.title: Public Budgeting and Finance
PPA552.description: Overview of public budgeting concepts, tools, and techniques. Focus is placed on understanding and analyzing public budget proposals and modern techniques for public budgeting processes.

PPA553.title: Public Organization Theory
PPA553.description: Theories of behavior of individuals and organizations in government bureaucracies.

PPA555.title: Environmental Law and Policy
PPA555.description: Explores different methods of setting environmental goals, economic incentives, and the roles of federal, state, and local governments in protecting the natural environment. Focus on substantive policy areas to connect theory with practice.

PPA587.title: Internship
PPA587.description: Supervised professional work experience related to public policy and administration.

PPA592.title: Special Topics in Public Policy and Admin
PPA592.description: Current topics in public policy and administration.

PPA670.title: Capstone in Public Policy and Administration
PPA670.description: Opportunity to reflect, integrate, and synthesize what has been learned in the MPPA program. Completing the capstone demonstrates mastery of the knowledge gained in the core curriculum, selected specialization, and internship experience.

RS300.title: Rangeland Conservation and Stewardship
RS300.description: Conservation and management of rangeland-ecosystem values using sustainable practices.

RS312.title: Rangeland Plant Identification Lab
RS312.description: Identification of characteristic grasses, forbs, and shrubs common to North American rangelands.

RS329.title: Rangeland Assessment
RS329.description: Five-day intensive field-based course on principles of rangeland ecosystem assessment.

RS331.title: Wildland Plants and Plant Communities
RS331.description: Distribution of non-forested wildland plant communities and important plant species in the western United States.

RS351.title: Wildland Ecosystems in a Changing World
RS351.description: Understanding and conserving non-forested wildland ecosystems, processes, and services under changing environmental conditions.

RS378.title: Disturbance Ecology
RS378.description: Foundational knowledge of ecological disturbances, the role of disturbance in biotic communities and ecosystems, and how various communities and ecosystems recover from disturbances.

RS400.title: Rangeland Improvements
RS400.description: Improvement of rangelands through biological and cultural methods; management of improved rangelands.

RS420.title: Grass Taxonomy
RS420.description: Anatomy, morphology, and identification of grasses.

RS432.title: Rangeland Measurements and Monitoring
RS432.description: Vegetation sampling and field measurements emphasizing applications for monitoring and adaptive management.

RS452.title: Rangeland Herbivore Ecology and Management
RS452.description: Ecology and management of large ungulate herbivores including consumer functions at organismal and ecosystem levels.

RS470.title: Rangeland Economics and Analysis
RS470.description: Economics of rangeland resource use; analytical techniques for allocation of rangeland resources.

RS471.title: Rangeland Planning and Grazing Management
RS471.description: Definition of grazing management, grazing systems. Synthesis of animal, plant responses to grazing management. Structure, function of rangeland planning.

RS472.title: Rangeland Ecosystem Planning
RS472.description: Range allotment, ranch, and restoration planning.

RS478.title: Ecological Restoration
RS478.description: Analysis of environmental factors influencing restoration of disturbed lands and practices for successful restoration of disturbed ecosystems.

RS531.title: World Grassland Ecogeography
RS531.description: Distribution, climate, and structure of the world's major grasslands with emphasis on North America.

RS532.title: Rangeland Ecosystem Sampling
RS532.description: Measurement, analysis techniques for rangeland vegetation. Applications to management emphasized.

RS552.title: Range Animal Production and Management
RS552.description: Biological and ecological basis for production of meat from rangelands.

RS565.title: Riparian Ecology and Management
RS565.description: Analysis of interactions among biotic and abiotic processes as relates to the ecology and management of riparian systems, emphasizing case studies.

RS630.title: Ecology of Grasslands and Shrublands
RS630.description: Distributions and climatic controls on grassland and shrubland plant communities.

REL360.title: Real Estate Principles
REL360.description: Broad survey of real estate emphasizing land use, urban structure and growth, market analysis, real estate finance and valuation, and property rights.

REL367.title: Real Estate Law
REL367.description: Legal regulations applicable to real property ownership and transfer, to real estate agents, and to use of real property.

REL430.title: Real Estate Market Analysis
REL430.description: Analysis of real estate markets, including development feasibility and managing risk, and their relation to urban economic trends.

REL455.title: Real Estate Finance
REL455.description: Residential mortgage origination, mortgage loan amortization, mortgage decision making, secondary mortgage markets, mortgage backed securities, REITs.

REL460.title: Real Estate Investment
REL460.description: Financing of real estate assets: real estate markets, policies; use of leverage and real estate investment analysis in real estate investment.

REL601.title: Fundamentals of Real Estate Finance
REL601.description: Valuation-oriented study of real estate concepts and principles, including legal, regulatory, finance, market and financial analysis.

REL602.title: Real Estate Finance and Investments
REL602.description: Major aspects of real estate finance and investment from the perspective of corporate, private, and public owners and investors.

SOWK110.title: Contemporary Social Welfare
SOWK110.description: Principles, values and institutions of U.S. social welfare in context of human need within family, groups, and society.

SOWK120.title: Academic and Career Success
SOWK120.description: Skills for general academic success, personal growth, self-management, and knowledge of campus/community resources. Examination of professional opportunities within the field of social work.

SOWK150.title: Introduction to Social Work
SOWK150.description: Introduction to generalist social work, including the history of social welfare in the U.S. and the knowledge, values, skills, practice settings, and populations served across the profession with special emphasis on vulnerable groups. The broad range of theoretical approaches and intervention strategies required are introduced. Practice roles discussed are advocate, broker, counselor, mediator, researcher, and community change agent.

SOWK286A.title: Practicum I
SOWK286A.description: Introductory social work practice skills in communication, relationship development, and professional behavior in the community setting.

SOWK286B.title: Practicum II
SOWK286B.description: Introductory social work practice skills in communication, relationship development, and professional behavior in the community setting.

SOWK300.title: Research in Applied Professions
SOWK300.description: Basic understanding of the research process and research methodologies, including skill in finding, understanding, interpreting, and applying research findings using critical thinking skills. Major emphasis on the steps and procedures to investigate various social problems and interventions that are central to contemporary social work practice while learning how research can be used to improve social work practice and to foster social and economic justice.

SOWK330.title: Dismantling Privilege and Oppression
SOWK330.description: Knowledge and skill in deconstructing one’s own identity, privilege and oppression to apply that process of understanding to a client's unique intersecting identities creating culturally sensitive social work practices.

SOWK333.title: Human Behavior in the Social Environment
SOWK333.description: Historic and contemporary theoretical foundations as contributions to practice knowledge in social work. Uses ecological and systems theory as organizing frameworks with critical thinking as a skill for identifying and challenging assumptions. Understanding human behavior theory relevant to social work practice.

SOWK340.title: Generalist Practice-Individuals and Families
SOWK340.description: Knowledge and techniques used in applying the generalist planned change process to individual and family system assessments and interventions.

SOWK341.title: Generalist Practice-Small Groups
SOWK341.description: Knowledge, skills and competencies needed for the planned change process in groups within a generalist framework.

SOWK343.title: Generalist Practice-Organizations
SOWK343.description: Knowledge, values, and skills for the planned change process with organizations.

SOWK370.title: Addictions - A Social Work Perspective
SOWK370.description: Applying a bio-psychosocial lens to the system of addictions and substance abuse from a social work perspective.

SOWK371A.title: Social Work with Selected Populations: Children and Families
SOWK371A.description: Application of practice processes with children and families.

SOWK371B.title: Social Work with Selected Populations: Juvenile Offenders
SOWK371B.description: Application of practice processes with juvenile offenders.

SOWK371C.title: Social Work with Selected Populations: Adult Offenders
SOWK371C.description: Application of practice processes with adult offenders.

SOWK371E.title: Social Work with Selected Populations: Social Gerontology
SOWK371E.description: Application of practice processes with selected populations.

SOWK384.title: Supervised College Teaching
SOWK384.description: Assist instructor in teaching selected classes, group training, or discussion group leadership.

SOWK400.title: Generalist Practice-Communities
SOWK400.description: Knowledge and skills to engage with communities, create culturally sensitive change, and evaluate the planned change process.

SOWK410.title: Social Welfare - Policy, Issues, and Advocacy
SOWK410.description: Issues and processes shaping social welfare institutions; definitions of social welfare policy; analytical framework for policy analysis.

SOWK482A.title: Social Work in Costa Rica
SOWK482A.description: International social work practice through exposure to culturally diverse communities in Costa Rica. Examine social problems, social action, and social injustice in the context of global interdependence.

SOWK482B.title: Study Abroad: Social Work in India
SOWK482B.description: International social work practice through exposure to culturally diverse communities in India. Examine social problems, social action, and social injustice in the context of global interdependence.

SOWK488.title: Field Placement
SOWK488.description: Integrate and apply social work competencies (Council on Social Work Education accreditation standards) learned across coursework through direct practice in an agency setting for field education. Demonstrate competency in professional knowledge, values, skills, and affective and cognitive processes for beginning social work practitioners.

SOWK492.title: Seminar
SOWK492.description: Integrates the knowledge, values, skills, cognitive and affective processes, and behaviors, that develop social work competency while in field placement.

SOWK500.title: Principles and Philosophy of Social Work
SOWK500.description: Establish larger framework for graduate social work study, and beginning professional practice. Provide an understanding of the nature, history, values, ethics, and practice contexts for social work. Evaluate their goodness-of-fit with the profession, the knowledge base required, and the diverse people, organizations, and communities served by social work.

SOWK511.title: Small Systems Practice Skills
SOWK511.description: Foundational practice knowledge and skills for engagement, assessment, intervention, and evaluation with individuals and families within a systems framework.

SOWK515.title: Theoretical Foundations for Social Work
SOWK515.description: Historical and contemporary theoretical foundations for social work practice. Ecological and systems theories are presented as organizing frameworks and critical thinking is developed as a skill for identifying and challenging assumptions.

SOWK520.title: Social Welfare Policy and Advocacy
SOWK520.description: Analysis of how social welfare policies affect the well-being of people and the tools that can be used to advocate for social change.

SOWK530.title: Anti-Oppressive Social Work Practice
SOWK530.description: Developing anti-oppressive practice with a focus on multiculturalism and social justice advocacy. Critically evaluate personal traits, attitudes and values regarding diversity and identity formation while exploring theoretical frameworks for understanding oppression. Analyze the relationships among power, privilege and oppression. Acquiring strategies for combating injustice.

SOWK550.title: Animal Assisted Therapy and Human-Animal Bond
SOWK550.description: The nature of the human-animal bond and animal-assisted interventions including animal-assisted activities and animal-assisted therapy presented as intervention methods. Includes various theories, protocols, and therapeutic practice methodologies with people across the lifespan.

SOWK551.title: Fundamentals of Mediation
SOWK551.description: Knowledge and skills essential to the successful application of mediation for a wide variety of interpersonal conflicts.

SOWK552.title: Conflict Management: Health and Elder Care
SOWK552.description: Knowledge, values and skills necessary for the practice of conflict resolution in healthcare and eldercare settings.

SOWK553.title: Multi-Party Conflict Resolution
SOWK553.description: Theories, models, and skills required for design and guidance of multi-party conflict resolution in group, community and organizational settings.

SOWK554.title: Conflict Resolution in the Workplace
SOWK554.description: Knowledge, values and skills necessary for the practice of conflict resolution in the workplace.

SOWK556.title: Divorce and Family Mediation
SOWK556.description: Knowledge and skills essential to the practice of family mediation including divorce and child custody.

SOWK560.title: Social Work Practice in Schools
SOWK560.description: Knowledge and skills essential to the practice of social work in educational settings. Topics include historical, legal, structural, and cultural context of practice in schools, the impact of disability on an individual and a family including special education processes and law, current issues challenging the practitioner in school settings, specific assessment practices covering Functional Behavior Assessment (FBA) and development of Behavior Intervention Plans (BIP).

SOWK561.title: School/Community: People with Disabilities
SOWK561.description: Teamwork approach to serving persons with special needs; values, issues and best practices related to creating desirable futures for them.

SOWK588.title: Field Placement
SOWK588.description: Students integrate and apply professional competencies learned across coursework through direct practice in an agency setting for 270 hours of field education. Students will demonstrate competency in professional knowledge, values, skills, and affective and cognitive processes for beginning social work practitioners.

SOWK592.title: Integrative Foundation Field Seminar
SOWK592.description: Integration of field placement experiences with foundation year MSW knowledge to enhance skills and shape social work best practices. Each session will focus on integrating students’ field placement experiences with knowledge, values, skills, behaviors, and cognitive and affective processes for professional social work practice.

SOWK600.title: Methods of Research
SOWK600.description: Emphasis on delivering evidence-based practice as well as conducting research to improve social work practice and policy by being effective consumers of research for social work practice and understanding diverse research types, study designs, sampling, measures, and research ethics.

SOWK601.title: Methods of Research II
SOWK601.description: Data analysis, computer processing in social work research, and methods for evaluating one's own practice.

SOWK603A.title: Direct Practice: Assessment and Evaluation
SOWK603A.description: Selection and application of techniques for monitoring and evaluating interventions with individuals, families, and groups.

SOWK603B.title: Direct Practice: Assessment and Evaluation
SOWK603B.description: Selection and application of techniques for monitoring and evaluating interventions with individuals, families, and groups.

SOWK630.title: Advanced Generalist Practice with Individuals
SOWK630.description: Knowledge, values, and skills to engage, assess, intervene, and evaluate individuals using an advanced generalist practice approach.

SOWK631.title: Advanced Community Practice
SOWK631.description: Preparing students to engage in and lead community practice that improves the well-being of individuals, families and communities; positively impacts the availability and impact of services and service delivery systems; and seeks to achieve social, economic, and environmental justice.

SOWK633.title: Contemporary Issues in Social Welfare Policy
SOWK633.description: Application of social welfare policy analysis models, normative aspects of policy analysis and assessment skills.

SOWK634.title: Advanced Practice with Families and Groups
SOWK634.description: Apply engagement, assessment, and intervention skills, theoretical models, and evidence-based practice approaches in work with families and groups.

SOWK640.title: Contemporary Issues in Military Culture
SOWK640.description: Exploration of multiple issues informing social work practice with military and veteran populations including ethical decision making in military social work, resources for veterans, challenges faced by women in the military, secondary trauma, and problems veterans face, such as homelessness, addiction, reintegration, mental illness, suicide. Military culture, the different branches of the military, and generational differences among military personnel will be examined.

SOWK641.title: Military Family Systems
SOWK641.description: Exploration of effectively engaging with military families. Strategies to assess and intervene with military and veteran couples, children, and families will be examined. Exploration of topics of integration and reintegration; grief, loss, and bereavement; family-centered programs; support of guard/reserve families; deployment; support of veteran caregivers; and effective interventions through a systems framework.

SOWK642.title: Clinical Intervention with Military Personnel
SOWK642.description: Clinical framework for working with members of the military including active duty, veterans, and military families, applied to examine common diagnoses and effective interventions, including post-traumatic stress disorder, traumatic brain injury, substance abuse, and suicide. Cognitive behavioral therapy, reactive exposure behavioral therapy, exposure therapy, rehabilitation, animal-assisted therapy, and additional therapies will be investigated.

SOWK660.title: Nonprofit Program Development
SOWK660.description: Application of the tools, knowledge, and understanding of how to provide strength-based nonprofit program development and management.

SOWK661.title: Nonprofit Financial Development
SOWK661.description: Application of the tools, knowledge, and understanding of how to provide strength-based nonprofit financial development.

SOWK662.title: Nonprofit Volunteer Development & Management
SOWK662.description: Theoretical framework for understanding volunteerism and practice skills for building and managing an effective volunteer program.

SOWK675.title: Psychopathology and Community Health
SOWK675.description: Foundation for diagnosing mental and emotional disorders relevant to community behavioral health practice with individuals.

SOWK676.title: Psychopharmacology and Community Health
SOWK676.description: Foundation in psychopharmacology (i.e. prescribed psychotropic drugs) for non-medically trained professionals practicing in behavioral health.

SOWK677.title: Trauma-Informed Care
SOWK677.description: Establishes a foundation for providing trauma mental health services to individuals, families, groups and organizations.

SOWK688.title: Field Placement
SOWK688.description: Integrate and apply advanced generalist professional competencies learned across coursework through direct practice in an agency setting completing 675 hours. Demonstrate competency in professional knowledge, values, skills, and affective  and cognitive processes for advanced generalist  social work practitioners.

SOWK698.title: Advanced Research and Social Work Capstone
SOWK698.description: Applied research project designed and implemented in groups to culminate knowledge and skill application. May be conducted with field agency, a community organization, or in alignment with specific School of Social Work faculty research. Groups will evaluate, research, and/or analyze a topic relevant to social work practice at the micro, mezzo, or macro level.

SOWK701.title: Contemporary Issues in Social Work
SOWK701.description: Issues and trends currently impacting social work research, professional education, and practice.

SOWK702.title: Social Welfare Policy
SOWK702.description: Social policy analysis and impact on social welfare systems and programs.

SOWK703.title: Pedagogical Approaches in Social Work
SOWK703.description: Pedagogy and practices for teaching social work curriculum.

SOWK704.title: Theory for Applied Social Sciences
SOWK704.description: Nature and processes of theory building in social sciences. Issues of epistemology, logic, political and moral philosophy.

SOWK705.title: Systematic Research for Scientific Inquiry
SOWK705.description: Systematic research in areas of interest that summarizes findings from available studies and provides a critique of the current body of evidence in this area.

SOC100.title: General Sociology (GT-SS3)
SOC100.description: Analysis of human societies in the U.S. and abroad; major institutions, groups, and interaction patterns from the sociological perspective.

SOC105.title: Social Problems (GT-SS3)
SOC105.description: Examines social problems related to differences in power and privilege. Investigates how social problems emerge and the people and communities they harm, as well as how people contest social problems and develop and implement solutions.

SOC205.title: Contemporary Race-Ethnic Relations (GT-SS3)
SOC205.description: Introduction to concepts, theories, and research studies pertaining to the sociological study of race and ethnicity. Examine the nature and causes of racism, stereotypes, prejudice, discrimination, and exploitation. Analyze the consequences of racial inequality, and explore different strategies for increasing intergroup awareness and working toward racial justice.

SOC210.title: Quantitative Sociological Analysis
SOC210.description: Application of quantitative concepts and methodology to investigation of social problems.

SOC220.title: Global Environmental Issues (GT-SS3)
SOC220.description: Focus on understanding social causes, consequences, understandings, and reactions to global environmental issues. Analyze critical questions about capitalism, economic growth, sustainable development, ideologies of gender and race, social inequalities and injustices, and knowledge production.

SOC253.title: Intro to Criminology and Criminal Justice
SOC253.description: Criminal justice as a system. Addresses the concept of crime, how crime is measured, the correlates of crime (such as race, age, gender, and social class), policing, sentencing, prisons, and corrections.

SOC270.title: Social Production of Reality (GT-SS3)
SOC270.description: Explores how humans shape and are shaped by society. Examines how communication, interactions, and perceptions of society shape identities, attitudes, small groups, and collective behavior.

SOC271.title: Body and Society (GT-SS3)
SOC271.description: Examines the body by focusing on its relationship with society. Explores the role of social structures and social norms on how physiques and figures fit or don't fit into broader expectations. Ties the social context to embodied self-perceptions and experiences.

SOC301.title: Development of Sociological Thought
SOC301.description: Central themes in sociological thought from Enlightenment to present.

SOC302.title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
SOC302.description: Theoretical approaches and models in sociology.

SOC311.title: Methods of Sociological Inquiry
SOC311.description: Application of sociological concepts to sociological problems including problem formulation, data gathering, and research design.

SOC313.title: Computer Methods in Sociology
SOC313.description: Experimental introduction to typical uses of computers in sociology with emphasis on data analysis.

SOC314.title: Sociological Approaches to Quantitative Data
SOC314.description: Quantitative data acquisition, cleaning, management and analysis. Using an analytical software package, students will clean, merge, and manage data from various sources, perform quantitative analyses, and present their data and results through tables and figures.

SOC315.title: Applications of Qualitative Research
SOC315.description: Qualitative research practices in contemporary contexts, including unobtrusive observation, content analysis, in-depth interviewing, and immersive participant observation.

SOC320.title: Population-Natural Resources and Environment
SOC320.description: Population studies; world growth patterns and their relationship to natural resources and environment.

SOC322.title: Introduction to Environmental Justice
SOC322.description: Unequal distribution of environmental risks, benefits, policies, and regulatory practices across different populations.

SOC323.title: Soc. of Environmental Cooperation & Conflict
SOC323.description: Roles of government and civil society in creating environmental problems and in developing effective responses to those problems.

SOC324.title: Food Justice
SOC324.description: Food justice strives to eliminate exploitation and oppression by challenging the structural drivers within and beyond the food system. As a practice, food justice advocates for the right to healthy food that is justly and sustainably produced, recognizes diverse cultural foodways and histories, and promotes democratic participation and equitable distribution of resources in the food system.

SOC330.title: Social Inequality
SOC330.description: Theories of social inequality and mobility and their ramifications in American society.

SOC332.title: Comparative Majority-Minority Relations
SOC332.description: Discrimination, ideology, power, policy issues in the U.S. and selected societies; application of basic concepts in student's self appraisal.

SOC333.title: Gender and Society
SOC333.description: Analysis of social organization of gender in contemporary society, emphasizing gendered experiences and institutional linkages.

SOC334.title: Sociology of Intersectionality
SOC334.description: Multiple and intersecting ways race, class, gender, and sexuality shape society, individual life-chances, and daily social interactions.

SOC340.title: Bureaucracy and Modern Organizations
SOC340.description: Structure and function of large-scale organization; coordination of activities between organizations and society.

SOC341.title: Sociology of Rural Life
SOC341.description: Rural life in U.S. and third world societies; analysis of sociocultural systems, social differentiation, social institutions, and problems of social change.

SOC342.title: Leisure and Society
SOC342.description: Nature and purpose of leisure and work in society; influences of culture and social structure on leisure values and behavior.

SOC343.title: Sport and Society
SOC343.description: Analysis of sports as social phenomena with a focus on the social implications of sports in everyday life.

SOC344.title: Health, Medicine, and Society
SOC344.description: The impact of sociocultural factors like social class, gender, and race/ethnicity on health and illness in society and the social organization of healthcare delivery. The U.S. health care system.

SOC351.title: Corporate and State Crime
SOC351.description: A comprehensive exploration of the nature, causes, and control of corporate, state, and state-corporate crime. Examples of environmental crime, financial crime, corruption, and war crime.

SOC352.title: Criminology
SOC352.description: Crime in contemporary society; behavioral, causation, prevention, and justice issues.

SOC353.title: Criminal Investigations
SOC353.description: Examination of the social, organization, and applied facets of the criminal investigation process.

SOC354.title: Law Enforcement and Society
SOC354.description: Rise and development of law enforcement as a societal reaction to crime.

SOC356.title: Inequality in Criminal Sentencing
SOC356.description: Examines the structure and process involved in the prosecution, adjudication, and sentencing of criminal defendants, and how that structure and process can produce disparities in criminal justice outcomes.

SOC357.title: Women, Crime, and Victimization
SOC357.description: Issues related to women as offenders, victims, and professionals in the criminal justice system.

SOC358.title: Punishment and Society
SOC358.description: Social and organizational issues in the administration of punishment and correction.

SOC359.title: Green Criminology
SOC359.description: Environmental offenses, victims, and responses to environmental crimes and harms.

SOC360.title: Political Sociology
SOC360.description: Analysis of power as a sociological concept, emphasizing competing theories of the state and power.

SOC362.title: Social Change
SOC362.description: Sources of stability and stress in changing societies, consequences of planned and unplanned change; future trends.

SOC364.title: Food, Agriculture and Global Society
SOC364.description: Analysis of relationships between global food, agriculture and social change.

SOC372.title: Sociology of Deviance
SOC372.description: Description, comparison, and analysis of theories and research of deviance.

SOC373.title: Visual Sociology
SOC373.description: Blends theory, methods, and practice to provide grounding in the role of images in sociological inquiry. Applies sociological principles to understanding photographs, from an area of interest, to provide a deeper level of understanding of the role of the photographer, through the focus of the intended audience, and how they contribute to an understanding of society at large.

SOC375.title: Sociology of Religion
SOC375.description: Descriptions and analyses of the roles and relationships of religion as a modern social institution.

SOC403.title: Capstone Seminar
SOC403.description: Student demonstration of central concepts and procedures currently employed in sociology discipline.

SOC431.title: Community Dynamics and Development
SOC431.description: Nature of community; its institutions, problems and processes, including growth, disintegration, and development.

SOC455.title: Sociology of Law
SOC455.description: Social origins, functions, and procedures of law in society.

SOC460.title: Society and Environment
SOC460.description: Technology as a social phenomenon interacting with social organization and the natural environment.

SOC461.title: Water, Society, and Environment
SOC461.description: Social aspects of water resource utilization; interface of social organization with physical environment.

SOC462.title: Applied Social Change
SOC462.description: Applied sociology with a focus on research and practice designed to foster social change.

SOC463.title: Sociology of Disaster
SOC463.description: Determinants and consequences of behavior and response to environmental extremes including floods, earthquakes, wind, severe storms, and technological emergencies.

SOC474.title: Social Movements
SOC474.description: Theory and research on causes, organizational structure, and outcomes of social movements.

SOC482A.title: Travel Abroad: Comparative Criminal Justice
SOC482A.description: International and comparative issues in sociology.

SOC482B.title: Travel Abroad: Crime and Deviance
SOC482B.description: International and comparative issues in sociology.

SOC487.title: Internship
SOC487.description: Academic-based work experience with selected organizations or agencies.  Supervised application of sociological principles and seminar participation.

SOC492.title: Seminar
SOC492.description: Examination of work-oriented instruction in seminar setting where sociological principles are analyzed using internship experience.

SOC500.title: The Sociological Profession I
SOC500.description: Examination of issues and values affecting sociology as a profession.

SOC501.title: The Sociological Profession II
SOC501.description: Examination of the activities and procedures critical to the socialization of professional sociologists.

SOC502.title: Foundations of Theoretical Sociology
SOC502.description: Contributions of major sociological theorists prior to mid-20th century.

SOC503.title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
SOC503.description: Contributions of major sociological theorists since mid-20th century.

SOC510.title: Sociological Methods I
SOC510.description: Linkage of sociological theory and conceptual models; case studies; data-gathering techniques.

SOC511.title: Sociological Methods II
SOC511.description: Linkage of sociological theory and conceptual models; case studies; data-gathering techniques.

SOC540.title: Community Sociology
SOC540.description: Intellectual roots of community sociology and contemporary community studies.

SOC555.title: Society, Deviance, and Crime
SOC555.description: Sociological perspectives and research in the areas of deviance and crime, including classical, positivist, and critical approaches.

SOC562.title: Sociology of Food Systems and Agriculture

SOC564.title: Environmental Justice
SOC564.description: Unequal distribution of environmental risks, benefits, policies, and regulatory practices across different populations.

SOC610.title: Seminar in Methods of Qualitative Analysis
SOC610.description: Examination and application of qualitative techniques of analysis.

SOC612.title: Seminar in Methods of Evaluational Research
SOC612.description: Quantitative and qualitative techniques of evaluating social action programs.

SOC613.title: Seminar in Multiple Regression and Path Analysis
SOC613.description: Analysis and application of techniques for multiple regression and path analysis.

SOC614.title: Comparative Sociology
SOC614.description: Examination of problems and prospects in extending and carrying out sociological research across social systems.

SOC630.title: Social Stratification
SOC630.description: Theory and research on class structure, status attainment, ideology, and social change.

SOC631.title: Sociology of Rural Development
SOC631.description: Rural social organization and development, modernization, and social change as it relates to rural social systems; underdeveloped regions of world.

SOC633.title: Theories of Modern Organizations
SOC633.description: Comparison of various theoretical perspectives on functioning of modern large-scale organizations.

SOC639.title: Technology Assessment and Social Forecasting
SOC639.description: Interrelationship between technology and society emphasizing procedures for evaluating impacts and forecasting alternatives.

SOC660.title: Theories of Development and Social Change
SOC660.description: Central concepts, issues, and approaches in sociology of development.

SOC661.title: Gender and Global Society
SOC661.description: Gender relations and social change in global society.

SOC662.title: Seminar in Sociological Policy Analysis
SOC662.description: Examination of sociological perspectives on formulation and impact of policies to deal with social problems.

SOC663.title: Sociology of Sustainable Development
SOC663.description: Social dimensions of sustainable Third World development and implications for policy.

SOC664.title: Sociology of Water Resources
SOC664.description: Social organization, conflict, and power in arid environments.

SOC665.title: Sociology of Science and Technology
SOC665.description: Examination of connections among science, technology, and social development in national and global context.

SOC666.title: Globalization and Socioeconomic Restructuring
SOC666.description: Sociological theories and issues in globalization; socioeconomic restructuring of the world economy.

SOC667.title: Theories of State, Economy, and Society
SOC667.description: Major classical and contemporary sociological theories of state-economy-society relations emphasizing development.

SOC668.title: Environmental Sociology
SOC668.description: Connections between social organizations, the environment, and science and technology.

SOC669.title: Global Inequality and Change
SOC669.description: Major issues in global inequality and change from a historical and contemporary perspective.

SOC671.title: Metatheoretical Issues in Sociology
SOC671.description: Analysis of metatheoretical concepts and issues in sociological theory.

SOC752.title: Seminar in Utopian Thought
SOC752.description: Sociological analysis of major utopian writings.

SOCR100.title: General Crops
SOCR100.description: Production and adaptation of cultivated crops; principles affecting growth, development, management, and utilization.

SOCR177.title: Applied Information Technology in Agriculture
SOCR177.description: Introduction to database and project management, GIS/GPS and remote sensing, as they apply to agriculture, the environment, and business management.

SOCR192.title: Water in the West
SOCR192.description: History and current status of water resources management and policy in the western United States.

SOCR200.title: Seed Anatomy and Identification
SOCR200.description: Principles of seed anatomy including reproduction, identification, and seed characteristics of plant families.

SOCR201.title: Seed Development and Metabolism
SOCR201.description: Basic processes controlling seed development, maturation, dormancy, storage, germination, and how these factors relate to seedling growth.

SOCR240.title: Introductory Soil Science
SOCR240.description: Formation, properties, and management of soils emphasizing soil conditions that affect plant growth.

SOCR300.title: Seed Purity Analysis
SOCR300.description: Fundamentals for determining physical purity of a seed lot using established rules and procedures.

SOCR301.title: Seed Germination and Viability
SOCR301.description: Seed viability tests including standard germination and tetrazolium, seed viability, dormancy, parameters of viability and evaluation.

SOCR310.title: Agronomic Plant and Seed Identification
SOCR310.description: Evaluate characteristics needed to identify agronomic plant and seed species.

SOCR311.title: Seed Quality--Seed Production and Genetics
SOCR311.description: Importance of seed production and genetics to seed quality. The value of seed quality to field crop production.

SOCR320.title: Forage and Pasture Management
SOCR320.description: Fundamentals of establishment, management, and utilization of cultivated forages including hay, silage, and pasture production.

SOCR322.title: Principles of Microclimatology
SOCR322.description: Principles of microclimatology including energy balance concepts for soil and vegetation surfaces, and their application.

SOCR330.title: Principles of Genetics
SOCR330.description: Transmission, population, and molecular genetics; practical applications.

SOCR331.title: Genetics Laboratory
SOCR331.description: Experimental techniques in transmission and molecular genetics.

SOCR341.title: Microbiology for Sustainable Agriculture
SOCR341.description: Functional roles and management of soil organisms in organic agriculture, emphasis on ecological interactions with plants and plant pathogens.

SOCR343.title: Composting Principles and Practices
SOCR343.description: Fundamentals of compost production, use, and regulation.

SOCR344.title: Crop Development Techniques
SOCR344.description: Conventional and transgenic approaches to crop variety development.

SOCR345.title: Diagnosis and Treatment in Organic Fields

SOCR350.title: Soil Fertility Management
SOCR350.description: Managing soil fertility and fertilizers to meet plant nutrient requirements in an environmentally sound manner with emphasis on nutrient cycling.

SOCR351.title: Soil Fertility Laboratory
SOCR351.description: Soil chemical analyses and development of fertilizer recommendations for crops.

SOCR370.title: Irrigation Principles
SOCR370.description: Determination of irrigation water requirements based on the estimation of storage and movement of water in the soil-plant-atmospheric system.

SOCR371.title: Irrigation of Field Crops
SOCR371.description: Management of irrigation systems for field crops with emphasis on irrigation methods, irrigation scheduling and strategies for water conservation.
